Think our group of 30 would have had a much better time if we had known that ahead of time.  Oh wait, we did know that ahead of time.  Oops.

That being said, the waitresses were super nice and accommodating to our huge, sloppy group.
author: Jennifer L.

description:
Sushi was okay for AYCE, but service ruined it for us.

Obviously, my girlfriend and i came with empty bellies to eat and service in the beginning was acceptable. By the end however, it seemed like they were trying to make us leave. The waitresses kept asking us if we were done yet, etc.
author: Ben L.

description: We were a hopeful group and sadly mislead. The sushi was NOTHING to write home about. The service really lagged and we even got a lame apology. I'll pay twice as much for somewhere with an attentive staff and eclectic flavor
author: Niccole D.

description:
Came here last night after leaving another sushi restaurant up the street for being way over priced. I loved the atmosphere it was really centered around a younger crowd with sports games, popular music and a nice modern spacious layout. The all you can eat is a good deal at $30 bucks considering it is San Francisco. The menu was on the small side with not a huge array of rolls but enough for 3 people to try something new each time. ANOTHER PLUS is they have choices on appetizers and a few other things that is included with the all you can eat. If you want some of the more popular and complex rolls or hand rolls you will have to fork over another $15. It was slow for a Friday night because of some rain so our service was charming and attentive. The one thing I didn't understand was we didn't have a server both girls where taking our table so we where checked on maybe too much. Plus I like building a connection with the people that serve me and value there opinion, it seemed like one of our servers knew the menu really well and had a lot of great suggestions but the other might have been new. 

In any case it was a nice find probably won't be back anytime soon just because I feel like I have tried everything on the menu with the all you can eat.
author: Jennifer F.

description:
Ate 114 piece of sushi. Power went out before finished.

Didn't offer a discount on the meal.
author: Ninja R.

description:
I've been here a few times and it was never a good experience. But this particular time is by far the worst. The restaurant is empty and me and my friend have been seated at the tiniest table possible at the door. We asked if we can move to a different table, any other table, since the place was empty and the waitress says "no either here or you can go". What the hell. We don't deserve your stinky attitude, maybe this is the reason why you guys have such bad reviews. 

Needless to say, we will never be returning.
author: Henry C.

description: Came for "all-you-can-eat." Waited 50 min for our first roll, although they did not appear to be especially busy. Reminded 3 different waitresses, without success. I usually don't rate sushi places on service, but this requires an exception.
author: Luke C.

description:
Very slow service. We definitely needed time with such a large menu but was way more time then needed and they could have at least taken our drink order. Sushi was ok but with all the other choices in the city I'm
Not sure id go here again. Overall not a terrible experience
author: Pamela R.

description: Very poor service. Sushi quality is terrible. It's very bland. They say the chicken katsu is their most popular item, but it is disgusting. Price is outrageous. Server made it seem like the mochii was comped and then charged us for it.
author: Austin C.

description: This place was a little disappointing. Service was not good to say the least. It was really busy and I only saw two waiters, but no excuse for bad service. Ordered all you can eat sushi for $30, but didn't end up getting half the rolls we ordered. The sushi wasn't anything special, not bad, but definitely not great. People seemed to be having, but you could barely hear the people at your table over the noise of other parties.
author: Eric M.

description: The sushi is medics at best, but the service is horrible. Don't go here unless you have all the time to waste. We waited over 30 minutes between rolls. When I brought it up the first time to the waitress, I was quickly dismissed. There are too many other great sushi places in the city.
author: Joustin C.

description: If I could give them less than 1 star I would have!! The person that was serving us has been very super rude to me!! Her name is Christy and she is the manager. Absolutely the worst customer service I have ever witnessed in my life!! And the sushi was not good at all! I have definitely tried better sushi than this!! Me and my family have been throwing up and got food poisoning after eating here.  My advice to you, DO NOT COME HERE!!
author: Sandy S.

description: The sushi quality is good and if I can do all you can eat Nigiri for 30 bucks you bet I'll keep coming back.
author: Austin L.

description: Read some bad reviews, but decided to try anyway. It was great quality sushi and friendly staff, we didn't have all you can eat and was happy with the value of buying it by the roll.
author: Bethany L.

description:
Great place for all you can eat sushi and sake.  I usually sit at the bar.  Despite the sometimes loud large drunken groups there the acoustics are such that the space itself doesn't get unbearably loud.  The service is great.

Don't expect the best sushi you've ever had but if you're not too picky the sushi is good enough to make the all you can eat enjoyable and it's in a great location.
author: Theron L.

description:
Sushi Hunter screams trendy.  The walls are washed a cool blue, the bar glows, cute decor, and the music was bumping.  Unfortunately, the dining experience was average and not as wow-worthy as the restaurant itself.

My two friends came for the AYCE experience, but I was not as hungry.  The unwritten rule here is that all individuals in your party have to order AYCE.  However, since the restaurant was so empty I was able to order a bento dinner and skirt the rule.  

The selection and quality was average.  My bento contained curry tonkatsu, saba shioyaki, and negi hama (yellow tail and green onion).  The curry on the tonkatsu was bland and the meat, poorly breaded.  Saba shio made up for it though - quite tasty!  And the negi hama was nothing to rave about.  

My counterparts on the AYCE menu had many items to choose from, but since we're talking AYCE you have to maximize the fish and minimize the carbs to get your money's worth ($28/person).  They were able to find enough favorites to be stuffed silly!  :P  

If you ask me...these rolls, nigiri, entrees, and appetizers do not compare to my favorite AYCE sushi place in Daly City - Kome.  The sushi is fresher, the rolls are SPECTACULAR (and huge), they have tons of seafood, dim sum, etc at a lower price of $22.95/person.  If it came down to the two, I would select Kome in a heartbeat.
author: Kathleen W.

description:
I ordered the hamachi nigiri and it was so chewy I had to spit it out. :(

Service was eh too, but it was just one waitress for the whole restaurant so whatever. With that being said we got our food 25 minutes after we ordered. 

Do not have high expectations coming here. Won't be coming back.
author: Angie H.

description:
I really don't get the 1 star reviews on this place... I went very early on wednesday, so it was pretty much just me and 3 other tables there. the staff was absurdly friendly. I tried EVERY nigiri sushi on the AYCE menu and was not disappointed by any of them. Also managed to eat some of the hot plates and they were very nice and warm. Only tasted 2 of the rolls they offer and they also tasted very good. 
I don't know why the experience differs so much between the people that visit this place, I just can say that for me it was one of the best that I had of its kind so far and can't complain of the value at all. Hope to return soon!
author: Victor F.

description:
Came here, but still hunting for sushi...

I would never come back here and would give no stars if possible. For the "all you can eat" menu option they take your order but it is 20+ mins before you get 1 plate of food to share among 4+ people. You have to constantly reorder the same menu items, because it never comes. The waitress also tries to avoid taking new orders. 

I had to re-order something as simple as miso soup 3 times over the course of 2 hours.

Additionally, the plates of food are tiny and not high quality. In the end, you leave dissatisfied and feeling cheated.
author: Heather L.

description:
I regularly travel to San Francisco for business.  Sushi Hunter is still one of my favorite sushi restaurants in the city.  The food is great and reasonably priced and the service is consistently good.

I will be back!  :)
author: Michael S.

description:
Great buy for all you can eat sushi in San Francisco! For less than $30/person, you can get all you can eat sushi and appetizers.When I arrived at Sushi Hunter, I was wary at first because the restaurant was almost empty, but I guess I just arrived early because within an hour it was completely full with a line of people waiting. The sake and beer wasn't as extensive as my friends, who also came to drink, not just eat, would have liked, but they decided on a cold sake that the waitress recommended and they loved it. 

The appetizer menu was awesome and had a lot of traditional Japanese appetizers and small dishes. We ordered the dumplings, shrimp tempura, edamame, and seaweed salad. Everything was good, except the dumplings which were just okay in my opinion. As for the sushi selection, they had a good sized list of rolls, however, I thought many of them were pretty similar to each other- a lot of rolls that were "spicy", such as several "spicy tuna/salmon" rolls. Not too much originality all together, but they may have had more on the regular menu (not all you can eat menu). The rolls we did get were really delicious, especially the NB roll, that was my favorite. 

The service was a slow, even at the beginning, before the waitresses were busier, but I think that can be expected sometimes at all you can eat places to keep you from eating more. Overall, great buy if you want to pig out on sushi and japanese appetizers. Sushi quality was not the absolute best I've had, but definitely delicious and worth the money if you're hungry!
author: Cara B.

description:
If you've read any of my other reviews you will see a trend.  I love Sushi Buffets!

Don't judge me while I judge Sushi Hunter. I love the value of it and I love Sushi. Sorry.
:)

The waitress was super nice and even gave suggestions as to some good things to try. she never made me feel like I was bothering anyone by ordering more and kept my beverage full.   

Another cool thing is that they have other things available on the AYCE menu other than just sushi.  

great for people who might be a bit squeemish about sushi in the first place. 

Overall great experience.  

Fun name.  It's like a movie name.  Pacific Rim 2: the Sushi Hunter
author: frank K.

description: The worst option if you're vegetarian. The rolls came covered in eel sauce. I had to ask what it was that my rolls were covered in, and they did not understand that a vegetarian roll should not have eel sauce on it. So yes, this place stinks.
author: Jessica M.

description: I love this place! Came here with my grandpa on a Friday night and the atmosphere and vibe was amazing. Great service too and their unagi is to die for. Our waitress is very kind, sweet and personable and genuinely cares for her customers. The location is cool too because its in north beach and there are mostly Italian restaurants there so it's nice that there's this cute little sushi place. Can't wait to come back soon! (:
author: Shan M.

description:
So i must admit that it's not the best sushi, however they have my card on file and know my order every time I call so they must be doing something right since I keep coming back for more. 

To be honest, this is my go to sushi when I want delivery. I mean how many sushi restaurants can you find that deliver and have no fee? I always get the same rolls, the tiger eye, the oyishi and the scallop roll. I've tried a couple other ones to branch out but these are my fave. The chicken kaarage is good, but don't order it if you are getting it for delivery- you will be disappointed. 

i've eaten in the restaurant a couple times as well and it's a good place to come for sake before going out.
author: Jordan S.

description:
I used to come in here once every few months with an Ex that loved the place. Decided to come in on a friday and to my shock and pleasant surprise they were packed! They'd always had trouble filling the place up so I was genuinely glad the place was doing well. We asked about how long the wait was and she said we could go next door and grab a drink and t leave my number and she would text me.

Unfortunately, that was where the pleasantries ended. After two drinks at Square and no text we came back and a different lady was working the front. She informed us they don't take numbers and text people and acted like I was crazy. Luckily the same girl that told us to leave the number popped by and offered to sear us but the original lady was super rude. We ordered the all you can eat menu, which in the past has been good. I realize the all you can eat items are going to be a bit smaller and a bit rice-ier for lack of a better term. But i wasn't ready for the horrible service and terrible food we got. I ordered a fried spicy tuna roll and from a cross section it was 95%+ rice and the alleged 5% tuna wasn't red at all it was orange from all the spicy sauce (mayo and sriracha) they used to cut the tuna down further. Hell I'm not even sure it had ANY TUNA in it. 

The ultimate Insult beyond the low quality food was when the bill came. Party of four with all you can eat and fed a bunch of tuna flavored spicy rice and the total came to $225 dollars. This wasn't a deal it was straight up robbery. I also learned why the service was so absolutely terrible... THEY ADD 18% AUTOMATICALLY TO ANY PARTY OF FOUR! 

Is that even legal? 

I have no clue, but I realized the service wasn't just grossly inadequate to keep us from ordering all you can eat items too often, it was so bad because THEY DIDN'T FUCKING CARE BECAUSE THEY KNEW THEY WERE ADDING 18% AUTOMATICALLY so they had no incentive to provide any level of acceptable service.

Used to love this place as a happy hour spot but I will never go back. It was always a 3.5 star food spot with okay food and decent prices and great srvice. Now it's food is barely a 2 and the service is a negative 1 star.
author: Nic T.

description: Hands down - this place is absolutely stunning. Michelle the waitress is absolutely amazing. This place has incredible service, stellar food and an energetic atmosphere.
author: Andrew C.

description: Mediocre sushi, horrible service. I honestly just wanted something to eat...the slow service here totally killed what was otherwise a nice night out with friends. Steer clear...unless you have 4 hours to kill, and some Safeway sushi to quench your appetite while you wait.
author: Bina T.

description:
Fresh high quality fish that's on par with Elephant Sushi however not the technique.  Although they have a good selection of mainstream sushi rolls at the lowest price in town.  As for the 3 star rating...perhaps a recent ownership change or the gf did say the shrimp tempora roll was a little heavy on rice and light on ingredients but at $7.5/roll..order two.

Satisfactory service, atmosphere, etc. Can't wait to try the all you can eat special.
author: Tyler G.

description: We had sushi all you can eat there. But there are about 50 ppl full in the whole restaurant that night, only two sushi chif are making suahi for all of us. I only ate 50% what I ordered. And it took my 2 hours. Most of time I just wait. Not worth it at all.
author: Carol Y.

description: Came here with my work team. All you can eat sushi and all you can drink Sake. Amazing experience, wonderful staff-- I will come back I love this place!
author: Valerie M.

description:
There are a lot of wonderful sushi restaurants in SF.. this one was ok. 

Positives: 
- No problem making a reservation for 8 people on a Friday night. 
- Our server was very friendly and helpful. 
- Option for all you can eat sushi and drink sake. 
- Pretty good special rolls. 

Negatives: 
- Not GREAT fish... I really enjoyed the roll I ordered (deep sea swimmer), the rest were ok... not super distinctive from each other. 
- Not much atmosphere. 
- Do not get the salad... the ginger dressing was weird and not good. 

I would go here again, but its not on the top of my list.
author: Jess K.

description:
I don't consider myself a sushi connoisseur by any means, but this place was a huge disappointment.  

I came here with three other people and we all agreed it was one of the worst sushi experiences we have ever had.  Despite the fact that the restaurant was only about half full on an early Sunday evening, service was ridiculously slow. We did not receive our first round for nearly 30 minutes. The sushi rolls, which lacked any remarkable flavor, contained too little fish and way too much rice.  

The only half decent thing was the nigiri.  But I'm not sure if it was actually good, or if it was the best thing about a thoroughly underwhelming dinner.

To top it all off, two members of my party ended up having stomach issues later than night, with one actually throwing up.  You have been warned.
author: Chris V.

description: Sushi hunter totally surpassed our "whatever let's just eat sushi in this neighborhood" expectations. The food was of the highest quality and the service was dope. We absolutely loved the sake bomb experience (thanks michelle) and we left with every intention of coming back again soon. Itchy knee son sake bomb!!
author: Hannah F.

description: Defenitely a NO. This was my worst experience because of the very rude server christie and she said she is the manager.  She wanted to get me food that i didn't order and when i asked her what if i do not like it do i have to pay for it ? She said '' this is the popular items if you didn't eat it i will eat it ''. She said she will eat my food if i don't like it. WEIRD!!! She was very super rude to us. Also they added alot of money to the check. The food was not that good. You can get better quality and a better customer service in different places. My advice is NEVER go there.
author: Liza M.

description: All you can eat for $30 on a Friday and Saturday. Cheaper on the other days. Service is horrible and it's slow. They won't seat you till most of your party is here even if the place is empty. Had to ask for water 4 times. Food just sucks and I'm so happy I didn't get a tummy ache. My friend picked this place cuz she was moving. Whatever my friend wanted. Food is bland, rice is hard, and everything starts tasting the same. Kitaro is wayyyyyyy better and that says alot. The only thing that was decent was the tempura, tofu, and gyoza. Parking is hard. Don't waste money or time here.
author: Karen H.

description: Highly recommend Salmon Kama, Grilled Ama Ebi and Butter Fish.One of the best sushi restaurant in the Bay Area!
author: Vivian L.

description: Went for the all-you-can-eat menu option.  Food came out quickly despite the relatively large size of our party.  Salmon nigiri was great.  I like that you can order non-sushi items within the package as well.
author: Victor M.

description:
It A-OK.  Not horrible and not fantastic either.  Reasonable prices.  Decent service and decent fish.

Minus 2 stars for a limited menu.  I got a lot of menus with almost same things.  Just takes time to read stuff over. 

A-OK as indicated.
author: Alex R.

description:
The nigiri was just OK. I think I was disappointed because I assumed being so close to the Marina the raw fish would have been better. It was not as cold as I would've liked it to be and that kind of threw off my opinion from the start. However, for 25$ all you can eat I definitely got my money's worth.

I started out with a piece of fried tofu, seaweed salad and two egg rolls. I tried the scallop and spicy mayo roll, the spicy salmon and cucumber roll, and the mixed tempura. The rolls were also just ok, but pretty typical for all you can eat rolls. I finished with the green tea ice cream which had an incredible toasted sesame flavor to it (and sesame seeds on top). I would potentially go here again if I was in the mood for all you can eat for a good price, but not any time soon.
author: Darcy S.

description:
The decor in here is really nice. The walls are halfway covered with what seems like fluffy pillows. The rest of the wall is clean and simple blue shade. There are also a lot of lighting but they're set to be dim. 

Service here is okay. Came here during dinner time on a Saturday night and it took about 10 minutes for the server to come take our order and give us our drinks. It wasn't that busy but I guess it's hard with just one waitress. I later saw one of the chefs taking orders too. After we got our food, the waitress never came back to check up on us or refill our drinks...

Anyways, my bf and I ordered the plate for two. It was $30 for 6 pieces of sashimi, 8 pieces of nigiri, and 12 pieces of rolls. Sashimi was tuna and salmon. The nigiri was salmon, tuna, unagi, I think hamachi. The rolls were of a California roll and spicy tuna roll. 

The meal was decent. The sashimi was really tender, or fatty as my bf put it. I've been noticing that lately, when I eat nigiri, the rice has been kind of really sweet/vinegary. Not sure if I'm noticing now just because it's been a while since I've had it or it was always like that. Also felt that the California roll had too much mayo mixed into the crab. I didn't like it that much. 

Would I come back? Maybe. Everyone talks about how the all you can eat menu is great here, so I might want to try that later on in the future.
author: Cathie N.

description:
Oh my god oh my god oh my god sushi hunter was amazing!!!

Just came back from a TON of deliciousness with my boyfriend. $25 for all you can eat, $28 on Fri-Sun, $18 for kids. 

Check my picture for a glimpse of their all you can eat menu. There's a large variety of stuff you can get.

Ok so my advice: go in a huge group, maybe 4-6. Order everything on the menu, share it amongst the group. I feel kinda bad ordering a lot when it's just me and my boyfriend. I peel off the rice and eat the nigiri as sashimi to conserve stomach space. 

The appetizers:
The edamame's really good. Nice and warm, nicely salted, good portion, 1 order is enough for 3 people. 
Fried tofu's not as good. They should've used egg tofu instead of the gamey tofu. The sauce for the fried tofu could've been more savory too, it's very watered down. Nori and fish shavings would be a nice touch to it too. The horenzo's yummy! It doesn't have the tart feeling on your tongue after you eat normal spinach. The sauce is nice and not too sweet. 
The wakame salad was amazing. Loads of sesame, nice tangy taste, just the right amount of sauce and chili. We had 4 orders of it. The funny thing was the order portion got bigger and bigger as we got them.
Miso soup was amazing. Lots of tofu, lots of seaweed, and the sprinkled spring onion makes it perfect. 

Sushi:
Nigiri's come in 2 pieces per order. Rolls come in 6 pieces per order. Salmon, tuna, ika, eel were yummy. Don't get the seared tuna, it's just tasted like a lower quality tuna, seared, and powered with pepper. The white tuna wasn't nice either, it was very fishy, gamey, and didn't taste fresh at all. The rolls are nice. Small portions but it's nice cuz you can order more. Philadephia was better than San Francisco, the cream cheese adds a nice tangy taste to it. 

Other stuff:
Udon was nice. Good portion for 1-2 people. Broth is clear, noodles were chewy. The crunchy stuff (i forgot what it's called) is really nice in it.
Teriyaki beef was yummy too. The sauce was tangy.
The tempuras weren't my favorite, but my bf liked it. They were missing the raddish stuff that goes in the sauce. The shrimps were teeny and it was over-coated with batter. I'm not accustomed to broccoli and carrot tempura, so that was a bit weird. 
The curry tonkatsu was nice at first, but it was too much for a person. But it's nice and crispy, the curry wasn't bad either. 

Their plating on the appetizers and other stuff is nice and decent. They do a good job plating it like delicacies. 

Also note their bathroom signs (the boy sign and the girl sign) are a decapitated boy and a decapitated girl. I thought that was really funny. 

Overall it's a nice, clean restaurant. The ambiance is nice and relaxing, service was really good (didn't take long to bring our food out, waitresses were cute and on top of their stuff) and bathroom was really big (at least for the girls) and clean.
I would come here over a normal sushi place like the sushi boat because it's soooooooo much cheaper this way. And you get more choices of food. I'll see you again soon Sushi Hunter!
author: Erica L.

description:
Saddened by the 2-hour wait for AYCE Korean BBQ in Japantown, my friend and I ventured here for consolation. Of course it was packed on a Saturday night - the servers were definitely stressed out from accommodating customers' requests. Since they were preoccupied with serving tables with 50+ piece sushi plates, it took us 10+ minutes to get seated (despite there being 2 tables readily available). We could have just seated ourselves, gotten our own menus, and saved everyone the trouble...

Things I appreciated:
-The AYCE sushi option had a good combination of appetizers, nigiri, and rolls on the menu (favorites: salmon, surf clam, spicy scallop roll). There's no limit to order size as well - get as much as you want for the first round (or any round). Eat lots of nigiri to make it worth your $.
-Good place for groups of 8-10.
-We ate for 2 hours, but I never felt rushed in the process. 
-I liked the giant fish-shaped light fixture on the ceiling. Yep.

Things I didn't appreciate as much:
-The sushi was mediocre (in terms of freshness / flavor) - but at least it was plentiful!
-Rolls were much smaller/plainer than I expected. Pretty sure the non-AYCE rolls were much bigger.
-Service during peak hours. It got a lot better once people started leaving by 10-10:30pm (since there was no one else to serve but us, muahaha!).
-Parking was a complete nightmare. You'll definitely have an appetite by the time you find a spot around this area.

Overall: a decent SF alternative if you don't want to venture to Davis for AYCE sushi.
author: Aileen L.

description:
I should have gotten the all you can eat when I came here. 

Service here is slow. I came here with my girlfriend during dinner time on a Saturday night and it took about 10 minutes for the server to come take our order and give us our drinks. 

Anyways, we ordered the plate for two. It was $30 for 6 pieces of sashimi, 8 pieces of nigiri, and 12 pieces of rolls. The meal was decent. 

Would I come back? Maybe. Everyone talks about how the all you can eat menu is great here, so I might want to try that later on in the future.
author: Jason L.

description: The best sushi place in San Francisco! Always has great service and great food. I would recommend to anyone and their mom. When you go you have to have the mochi, absolutely killer!
author: Caitlin D.

description:
An unlikely find in the heart of North Beach, we were quite happy with the discovery. We went all out with the $25/person +$18 per child all you can eat dinner.  I was very happy to find the waitress showed no attitude when we ordered multiple dishes and sushi rolls. She didn't force us to order a set amount at a time before being allowed to order the next round.  We added dishes randomly every time she passed by and she had no problem with that and the service never slowed (another tactic ...as you get full waiting for the food).  We got so much food it was ridiculous and there is a full selection of appetizers, main dishes, sushi rolls and sushi (no sashimi on the all you can eat menu). 

The fish had a beautiful color and was fresh, but the fish was sliced small with a good sized ball of rice you're expected to eat. I loved the Potato Croquettes. The Spider Rolls, Alaska Rolls, California rolls and Tempura rolls were very good too.  You don't get a lot of variety in the rolls - no creative conncoctions, but still good enough.  I didn't like the Tempura. I wanted more shrimp, less veggies.  We also got a big bowl of Edemame Beans, 3 salads, 3 Miso soups, and Pork Katsu, but the waitress forgot the grilled Saba/Mackeral dish.  Since we ordered two or three of many dishes and rolls, it was probably good that she did forget it.  Dessert is extra but you'll be too full te order it.
author: Elizabeth S.

description: As we entered the restaurant, we stood there for a good 5 minutes and was not acknowledged at all. Not even by the guys slicing the fish at the bar. Ok... Do I put my name down? Fine, I did. Then we decide to go up to them instead to see how long the wait to get seated is because there were empty tables! They said soon.... Total of 10 minutes passed and still no acknowledgment. I'm out!
author: Nancy N.

description:
All you can eat sushi, $25 and $18 for kids.  

This was the best deal in town!!!  The sake list is a little light.

Quality of fish was great for the price, although you can find better sushi.  I don't think I would order a la carte.
author: Rich V.

description:
The titanic roll was very good. The service was excellent. A cozy neighborhood restaurant with friendly staff and pretty tasty sushi. 

I would recommend it for sure.
author: Randa G.

description: Been coming here for AYCE sushi for 2.5 years now. The AYCE selection is fairly large and respectable. Quality of the fish is solid - keep in mind this is AYCE, so those with a very refined palate for sushi shouldn't expect to have their minds blown. Christie, the owner, is very friendly and personable. As expected, wait times in-between orders can get long during peak dinner hours, especially on weekends. Overall, I recommend this place for anyone who is in the mood for AYCE sushi. Will definitely be returning in the near future as well!
author: Nolan S.

description: The food was alright, but the wait staff was horrible. Our waitress barely talked to us, and when she did, she was annoyed when I asked for her to repeat herself. I wouldn't wast your time or money at this spot. Go down the street off Columbus, to north beach sushi. Way better!
author: Evanthia K.

description: The Best All-You-Can-Eat Sushi in San Francisco all for the incredible price of $25!!
author: Avery J.

description: My boyfriend and I live in North Beach and have been coming to Sushi Hunter for the length of our tenancy ~ about 2 years!! Sushi Hunter is our go to place for a good meal. It just occurred to me that I should write this post, as we walk here so often, casually. Sushi Hunter is always great; the food is delish, the staff is WONDERFUL and you can always get in. I would recommend Sushi Hunter to anyone and be excited to bring any guest (old or young) here for a guaranteed wonderful meal!
author: Kelsey H.

description: This place is great! There aren't that many AYCE sushi places in the city and sushi hunter has a great selection for the price. The service was great, our waitress always came by to see of we wanted to order more.  Not only do they have rolls and sashimi, but you can also order things like tempura, miso soup, teriyaki, and all sorts of little dishes! My favorite was the sake nigiri. I could probably eat 50 of those in a sitting.
author: Linz C.

description: Good service tried the ayce sushi. Limited menu for sushi and rice dishes only. Not bad but quality could have been better.
author: AL P.

description: Sushi Hunter is the only place that offers all you can eat sushi however, it was not to my satisfaction. I understand for most all you can eat places, the quality isn't that great but I was expecting a bit better from Sushi Hunter. First of all, the rice was packed poorly in all the sushi rolls and nigiri that I had. It was soggy and didn't taste fresh. The sushi itself did not taste fresh. The staff was not as attentive since there weren't too many waitresses taking care of the tables. What turned out to be an hour dinner went to 3 hours because we were primarily waiting on the sushi. I would rather pay more for good sushi than all you can eat sushi. Quality means more to me than anything and I'm a bit disappointed that Sushi Hunter didn't get anything right. Not even down to their miso soup and edamame.
author: Cindy K.

description: Sad to give this place such a bad review.  Been coming to this place for years.  The new management is destroying what used to be a nice neighborhood sushi restaurant.  Let's see where to start.  Service was uncomfortable with our server trying to up sell us multiple times, overall not a positive service experience at all. We ordered the "all you can eat" and felt rushed off with our server bringing us our check before we gave any indication that we were done.  Seems like there has been a huge staff turnover and didn't recognize any of the staff.  Please turn it around or me and my friends won't be back. Dump the new management!
author: Matt B.

description:
Service was perfectly fine. With a coupon printed on the back of a Safeway receipt from Bay St, all-u-can-eat is $20.  Decor is a corny, dated attempt at futurism, but good effort!   

Nothing remarkable and nothing offensive about the food. For the deal, I wasn't shocked by the higher rice to fish ratio.  After all, wtf do you expect from all-u-can-eat???  Simply put, just shrug and go to another joint to pay more for more fish.  But if you're in the mood to sate a sushi fix and want to try some fun sounding, ultra Americanized rolls, this is the place to be.
author: Miran C.

description: Never go to that place! I was there just one week ago. It was my first night in San Francisco and my boyfriend and I decided to go there for all you can eat dinner. The place smelled weird but since there was people seated and we read good reviews we decided to try. The waiter gave us the menu but not the AYCE so we asked her. She told us that it was so late to order (9pm) but we didn't mind because we went there just for this menu. OK. We ordered super fast some sashimi and rolls. WORST SUSHI ON EARTH! it was neither fresh nor tasty. The soy sauce was incredibly salty. But this is not the end, when we saw the check it was $68! They added a 18% gratuity to a party of 2! But, now the most important fact is that I got FOOD POISONING. I spent my weekend in SF feeling terrible and without being able to eat anything apart from camomile. What I should have done is to report this restaurant to the Health Department!
author: Lucia T.

description:
Sushi hunter is not bad, but it's not write-home-about-it great either.

The interior is a bit of a surprise. It's a lot sleeker than I imagined it from the outside. And no complaints about the service.

My nigiri was adequate, but not necessarily memorable. The size and quality were commensurate with the price, which was reasonable.

My kid's bento box was also adequate, with the stand-out being the tempura. Very crisp and not at all greasy. I stole a few pieces and considered ordering more.

When the check arrived, I felt satisfied that I had gotten what I paid for. But I most likely wouldn't return. Again, not because it was bad, just not...great.
author: Valeria R.

description: All you can eat sushi was so good! It was really nice to be able to make reservations online, super quick and easy.  The service was good and the sake was flowing, what more could you ask for?! The crunch roll was my favorite!
author: Danielle B.

description:
I just moved back to North Beach after a 20 year absence and this place is only a block away so I thought I'd give it a try. I sat at the very small bar and was attended to quickly by the waitress only. The two sushi slicers never even looked up at me. I ordered my standard Hamachi sashimi  plate with 2 orders of Salmon nigiri. Sushi Hunter failed on both orders. The Hamachi sashimi was back, not belly. It was tough and watery, indicating it had been improperly stored or re-frozen. I told the waitress this grade of hamachi should be relegated to rolls or maybe poke style dishes only. The salmon nigiri was very skimpy and had no fat lines, so therefor was a very low grade. I told the waitress that a nigiri fish should always reflect in size relative to the person it is being served to, and this portion was more appropriate for a small girl.

The true rating would be 1/2 star. The waitress offered a blank lifeless smile in response to my complaints. There was never even a glance from the two stooges behind the fish cooler. I will tell all my North Beach buddies to never come here.
author: Mark B.

description:
Not too shabby for an all you can eat sushi place. I came here recently for a friend's birthday. We had a very big group of 20+ people and they were able to take a reservation for us. Despite our group being so big, the food came out quickly and the waitress did a good job managing all the food and drinks that were coming and going from our table. I thought that all the sushi were decent. Maybe someone of the sashimi were not as cold as thought they should have been, but nobody got sick at the end of the night. 

Don't know if I would return here on my own, but it's a good place if you have a big party.
author: Tran N.

description: Horrific service, stood inside the restaurant at the bar for ~15 mins before anybody even made an attempt to greet us. Waitresses were as ditzy as they come. Sushi is almost inedible (although they do get 1 star for having butterfish)
author: Bowen J.

description:
Back to back find? First it was the finest dim sum at The Great Eastern Restaurant, now it's AYCE sushi. Wow am I on a roll.

What I got from the Sushi Hunter was exactly what I expected: eat until I die.  Much like Midori Sushi in Southern California, I was able to all I can eat until I throw in the towel.

Secondly, most AYCE sushi spots have an one hour limit, not the hunter. You can just keep going.

I expected a little more variety and sushi itself is good for AYCE but mediocre overall. Will I go back? for $25 bucks you can count on it!
author: Dave K.

description: Came here STARVING, anticipating "all you can eat sushi" since early today. Unfortunately, the lack of service kept us waiting nearly an hour after ordering our first roll. In fact we nearly bailed to get some pizza down the street. Honestly, my worst all you can eat sushi experience to date l. Would not recommend, would not visit again - regardless of how bad I'm craving sushi.
author: Cara P.

description: Place will never come back...there are not so many choices，the tempura is not crispy at all， when the customers are more than 5 people in the restaurant，the service became slower and slower，i waited for 5 to 10minutes the asked them to check*****not a good experience at all
author: Yifei Z.

description:
All you can eat sushi menu was weak! The rolls were so basic (california roll, tempura roll, spider roll). The rolls were small & tasteless. Some of them even fell apart. Too expensive ($25/ person) for basic sushi.

Gave them 1 star because our waitress was nice. She checked up on us a lot & food was served fast. Just a disappointment with food.
author: Mimi B.

description:
A group of us (about six) decided on a whim to make reservations and give this all you can eat menu a try, which was easy and as soon as we showed up we were seated immediately, me likey. 

I deducted two stars for the following reasons

1. when we walked in, I was hit with a strong scent of what seemed like urine, all of us noticed this but as you walk towards the tables the smell wears off.

2.Our waitress was super friendly and accommodating but she overcharged us by almost $100. Not a complete deal breaker, and I get it mistakes happen but thats an awful lot to accidentally overcharge.

Other than that, the all you can eat menu was decent and we all jumped in on the unlimited hot sake for an extra $12 per person-- which was an awesome decision, until the morning after, I'm still recovering as I write this review. 

Any who, I wish there were more sushi options on the menu but with unlimited edamame, miso soup, dumplings, & seaweed salad made it worth while. The tempura was good and the sushi didn't seem all that fresh but it was still good enough in my drunken sake haze. Oh and definitely partake in a few sake bombs as they encourage you to yell and pound the table, fun stuff.

Probably won't go back on account my stomach was all sorts of messed up the following morning, I'm sure all the sake didn't help much either. But in a city full of sushi options I will probably give another spot a try next time around.
author: Dani A.

description:
It may be true that this is the best place for all you can eat sushi in town; but perhaps the only place.

I always understood sushi is a fresh, eatable fish but the after taste of what Sushi Hunter serves here is more like a brown herring or a sewer catfish.  Terrible food!  Don't be fooled by what appears to be a low price, many add-on's and the bill for two people is easily $80 plus.  I don't mind spending money but the food needs to be of quality. 

Besides the fish we sampled beef Teryaki and it was as tough as the sole of my shoes or maybe it was a guam tree.  Hot Sake was barely warm, but of course it was a free refill (that we wouldn't want even when it's free).

It's been over 24 hours since we dined there and I still cannot forget the terrible food quality.  

I would never recommend this place to anyone.
author: Darius A.

description: Dinner for 2 plate with assorted fish and two sushi rolls w/ two miso soup. only $30
author: Linda B.

description: Happy hour from 5 to 7 PM. Didn't open the doors until 5:15 PM. Wasn't serve my food until 7 PM. Where was your sushi chef? Nice try guys. I felt sorry for the waitress, she had to come up with excuses for the chef being gone for too long.
author: Mark R.

description:
2012 Drunkcathlon: San Fran Edition. Review #5

Drink requirement: Order one bottle of Premium Ginjo Cold Sake and whatever else you need to make Sake Bombs.

Didn't get a chance to try the sushi in the small little spot, but I will give a shout out to the awesome staff who not only fulfilled our hasty request for sake bomb ingredients, but actually sabotaged our competitors who showed up later by telling them that they were completely out of Sake. Rock on, ladies.

The space itself was small, well-located, and clean with, as previously mentioned, a really great staff. I would definitely go back to try their actual food at some point.
author: Kaity J.

description: Sushi hunter is overpriced, fish not fresh and not treat it right by chef...cooked food is also disappointment. Sushi rice is mushy and feel like sticky rice and mash potatoes. The soda they have are very watery and no carbonation. It's just seems that the owner just want to cut cost left and right, main focus to make profit and have no heart in making good food. One of Biggest mistake in my life coming here...should've read yelp or do research before coming here...
author: Robert L.

description: This place sucks. Parking around this area sucked as well. We came in Saturday for the AYCE at $28 per person. The menu for it was small and lacked variety. Katsu chicken was undercooked and the fish was low quality. I felt this was the worst restaurant I've ever been. Should of taken a hint that it was empty and smelled weird upon walking in. So disappointed by it I just wanted to get out so I paid at the cash register with my card to make it quick. Now I always tip cash to ensure the waiters get their share therefore I crossed out tip and started walking back to my table.. the girl rudely said we don't include tip. I said I know and proceeded with leaving half of what I intended to tip due to the rudeness. Would give 0 stars if possible.
author: Danielle E.

description:
The exterior does not do justice to the interior. It is very modern and like most Asian restaurants they play hip hop music. The plush white seats goes very well with the sharp blue walls. The sushi counter has this blue glow like those super fobby cars. 

We did the all-you-can-eat for 23 a person. The menu offers a lot! There are appetizers from edamame and gyoza. There are bento box stuff from fried tofu to pork cutlets. If you want rice they also offer a side of rice! You mind as well make your own bento box! There are a couple nigri to pick from and also a variety of rolls from spider roll, hot angel roll, california roll, etc. The rolls are average to me though but you get a lot of the 23 price. My friend is a advent customer of this place and he says that one time they didn't do the all-you-can-eat the price was more than 23 a person. 

They also offer ice cream/mochi for a cheaper price if you are doing the all-you-can-eat. The mochi comes with caramel on top which clashes with the mochi. =/

The waitresses are super nice and attentive especially the one with the tall hair. 

Awesome bathrooms that has a strange layout. There is two chairs in there if you want to take a break from the people you are eating with.
author: Sarah C.

description: Be careful what you order they have a passion for claiming that hey are an " all you can eat sushi when really they only serve half of what you ordered. I ordered 16 rolls and confirmed with the waiter after the first 7 the waiter had mentioned that it was the whole order. If your looking to get what you pay for this is not the place to go. The first 2 plates came quickly and as I waited for more sushi the wait became longer and longer. They waiters are quite unorganized and don't keep track of what they receive from an order. This was my test run for an all you can eat sushi spot and I can say that they miserably failed. When it came to paying on a $115.00 tab they also disclosed that it will cost me an additional .75 to use my card to pay. This is nothing crazy but it would be nice if they disclosed this to me prior to me paying.
author: Robert L.

description: We have been here twice. The sushi is okay but the service is what really makes it not worth it. We gave them the benefit of the doubt the first time as we enjoyed the sushi, not the service; but on our return trip it was the same, the quality of the sushi does not outweigh the slow service.
author: Mark B.

description: This place is the most disgusting sushi restaurant I have ever had. First I would like to start by saying that the management is so rude and disrespectful, when the food came out it was SO disgusting, it smelled like shit as if it came out of the garbage. It was ALL wrapped in seaweed (which was not stated) which made it even. Ore disgusting, we took ONE bite and it tasted just how it smelled, filthy. We ask to talk to the manager and she CALLS us. Doesn't have the audacity to come out and speak to us. Speaking INCREDIBLY rude to my friend when my friend was being BEYOND respectful, and yelling and screaming at her, interrupting her every word and she was not cooperating AT ALL. She refused to come out and talk to us like the respectful owner that she should be, and still charged us gratuity on top of that. She finally said that she can take 50 percent off of all that we ordered which came out to almost 20 for eating THREE pieces of sushi, and adds 18 percent gratuity no matter if you had 3 ppl ( which is what we were) or 1 person. Over all it was a waste of money on 3 pieces of sushi. DONT GO HERE. I DO NOT RECOMMEND THIS PLACE. OVER PRICED , NASTY FOOD, AND MOST OF ALL DISAPPOINTING FOOD.
author: Sandra T.

description: Great All You Can Eat deal. Come hungry and get rolled out of the restaurant. $30 per person on weekends with tax and no drink.
author: David S.

description:
The saving grace of this restaurant is the service and decor. It is bright blue inside with trendy looking tables and pretty good music playing. Everyone working there was super friendly and I never had to ask for refills or remind them of a request.

However the main reason I went was for the AYCE - the menu surprised me. Lots of non-sushi choices. Unfortunately those items were better than the sushi. The fish didn't seem fresh and my friend and I ended up with unhappy stomachs the next day. Maybe the specialty rolls would have been better but based on my stomach's reaction alone, I won't be returning.
author: Bri-Anna N.

description: They did the calculation of tips for you , which is 26% ,and kinda half force u to pay it .
author: George C.

description:
All their contemporary decor was a cover-up for their small and overpriced sushi portions they served. The restaurant is crammed up, just like the corner in which it is located. I didn't get any water refills. 

FYI: they've changed their "Restaurants.com" policy, so they don't accept it on Fridays and Saturdays anymore. She took ours because the new policy wasn't listed on there. Overall, I felt ripped off and had to pay the 18% gratuity even when the service was mediocre.
author: Moua L.

description: Decent sushi. I prefer really cold sushi but this was room temperature but the chef was making it fresh which was good. We did the all you can eat sushi for $28 and it was fantastic. Was annoyed about the enforced 18% gratuity (we had a party of 4) as the service was decent but not great.
author: Krissy O.

description: Quantity & Quality. This place has the best of both worlds. You wouldn't expect a sushi bar that offers all you can eat to have fresh fish but Sushi Hunter manages to keep up with the demand. The restaurant has a great vibe and waiters do a great job working the crowd. Those who complain about speed clearly either don't understand how sushi works and would sacrifice quality for speed. I look forward to coming back to for excellent food &  drink!
author: Benjamin H.

description: This place is awesome all around! Great place to go for mid-twenties groups for all you can eat sushi! Really nice wait staff , very responsive for drink and food orders, good all you can eat selection.  All you can eat also comes with unlimited sake.  Great pregame spot in prime location!
author: Maggie M.

description: Casual all you can eat sushi ($25) and unlimited hot sake ($11). All rolls and appetizers are made to order And fresh. They aren't the most extravagant rolls but are flavorful . The staff was helpful and accommodated us even though we came near closing time. I think this would be an awesome group spot. I will certainly be returning .
author: Evan P.

description:
So, i'm not really sure why previous people had an issue with this place, because my girlfriend and I came this past Friday night, and had a great time! 
We sat down at 7, and the place was already 3/4 full. The staff were prompt and nice, and the food was even better (minus the edemame -they sucked) 
I did the AYCE and my girlfriend ordered off the regular menu. She got rice, Gyoza, Tempura, and the Egg Rolls. All were really good according to her. I ordered two rolls. both were very good! I also ordered a pile of Nigiri; this was the best part! The fish was tasty and cut into perfect one bite sized pieces (big one bites though). The salmon was like butter, as was the tuna, makeral, snapper, and Yellowtale. 
I would recommend this place, and cant wait to go back! By far the best AYCE sushi place in the East Bay (that ive heard of or been to anyways)
author: Mike P.

description:
This cute little restaurant is hidden in a little corner of Little Italy.. As little as it was, our group came in a party pack of 23 and we all seemed to fit comfortably well at their tables. We didn't get to try their variety of rolls they offer, but what we did have was typical A-OK. Their "Salmon sashimi passion platter" and beef teriyaki were excellent appetizers. Other than that, we had the usual nigiri rolls that you'd be able to find at any other Japanese restaurant.  

Service was good and the Sapporo kept being refilled, so it was a good night. 

Would I travel all the way here for their sashimi though? Probably not. Good times nonetheless.
author: Summer R.

description:
We were a little surprised to find a sushi restaurant here. We looked at the menu posted outside and found limited vegetarian options (as is common at most sushi restaurants).  However, we did find a Mozzarella Roll (Tempura Mozzarella Cheese). That was gooooood.  But then again, fried things usually are! I usually stick to vegan sushi, but this just sounded so good. As it was. 

We got it to go, so I can't really speak for the dine-in service, but the service we got for take out was great;she even brought us water as we waited for our roll. 

Now whenever I go to a sushi restaurant, I scour the menu for a similar roll. But alas, this is the only place I have found it. So Sushi Hunter, I shall return.
author: Andrea V.

description:
Wasn't sure what to think after reading Yelp reviews, but I personally found the AYCE sushi to be fresh enough. $25 AYCE menu is a reasonable price, but the selection of rolls is quite limited - expect to eat only the basics (though the inclusion of nigiri is nice!).

They forgot our very last order for 45 minutes (we asked a couple of people, and then a birthday party came in and the sushi chef was going around asking people to sing), but they made it right with some green tea ice cream.

Not a bad option for a once-a-year AYCE sushi experience...
author: Conrad B.

description:
If I could award this place a 3-1/2 stars, I would. 

A few coworkers and I went out to a sushi dinner a couple of weeks ago, and after paying $30 for 2 rolls that left us wanting more, we decided to go on a hunt for AYCE sushi. It was actually pretty difficult to find one up here (I'm from So Cal, and there are AYCE places aplenty), so I was pleased to finally find this place.

We went on a Thursday night around 7pm, and thank goodness it didn't get busy until later because the service was sub-par. The AYCE sushi, however, definitely exceeded what little expectations I had for it. The rolls were on the small side, and the nigiri wasn't as fresh as I'd like, but for $25 it wasn't a bad deal at all. 

If you're looking for cheap AYCE sushi, this is the place to go.
author: Kylie T.

description: Meh.  Sushi Hunter would be in the bottom quartile of San Francisco sushi restaurants, more akin to something you would see in Kansas City (both the vibe and the food).  The all-you-can-eat menu is full of the typical cheapies, all done with a maximum of rice and a minimum of fish.  And the fish you do get tastes a bit like the boxed arrangements at Whole Foods--not terrible, but not particularly flavorful.  Once you have ordered, expect to wait a while to get your food, even if the chefs do not appear to be particularly busy.  The wait staff at times is not particularly attentive, sometimes requiring a lot of hand-waving to pay attention to you.  Everything screams "bargain," from the mediocre wines to the kitschy interior.  If you are looking for great sushi in North Beach, try Katsu on Columbus (a short walk north of Sushi Hunter).
author: Jordan B.

description: Some what disappointed. I don't mind paying $55 for sushi and sake but make it quality sushi and/ or sake. The sake was light in alcohol and the sushi was 90% rice and low quality fish. For what I paid, there are at least 10 better restaurants in the area let alone in SF
author: Dylan D.

description:
Sushi Hunter is one of the few AYCE Sushi joints I've found (I'm not counting those horrid buffet places where patrons gobble up all the good stuff as soon as it's put out, and their kids manhandle everything else- like Kome).  The AYCE menu is, not surprisingly, somewhat limited-  more so than their regular menu.   For example,  there's no salmon roe nigiri,  but there's enough other classics, and if the pieces seem  small, you can always place another order.    There's a larger list of rolls, but by swapping out avocado for cucumber or tuna for salmon you can see how combinatorics leads to a huge list with very few base ingredients.   They also provide a wide selection of other items (tempuras, salads, gyoza, etc), so you shouldn't run out of things to try.

The fish seems reasonably fresh, and they always make an effort to do a nice presentation (which can probably be daunting, given all the strange orders people make).  The downsides are that service can be slow- especially on a weekend night, and the ratio of rice:other ingredients is higher than ideal.    I'd recommend going on a weekday night and sitting at a larger table so you can order more than a plate of food at a time.   Just remember that you have to eat it all.
author: Susan C.

description:
Came here with a group of 11 for all you can eat sushi. Couple of limitations that were annoying but bearable:

1) All or nothing for your table when it comes to AYCE
2) All you can eat menu is much more limited in sushi choices than the regular menu (doesn't include the more pricey fish and rolls), and somewhat costly for the selection ($28 on a Friday)
3) All you can drink ($12) only includes hot sake, so though they encourage you to drink sake bombs, the beers add up fast.

Overall, the variety in food was fair though since it wasn't just sushi and we also ordered appetizers to start. I actually preferred the appetizers like assorted tempura, gyoza, mackerel, and beef teriyaki that we ordered to the actual fish as it wasn't terribly fresh. Out of the rolls on the AYCE menu, the roll with hotate was the only notable one. Ordered and tried all the nigiri, and maguro, ika, sake, and hokkigai we're the only ones that I re-ordered as the rest tasted too fishy to be very fresh.

Staff was friendly and attentive enough given how busy they were (there were multiple large groups). Took a few tries to get more water, and they missed a few items we ordered on a few of the rounds, so we had to ask for them again, but since it was AYCE, no harm done.

Ultimately you get what you pay for, fair and great for groups, but definitely not fit for a foodie.
author: Tina H.

description: Great for a sake bombing dinner. The sushi was decent and they let you get rowdy. I liked their specialty rolls a lot and the tempura ice cream.
author: Andrew K.

description: We had a great experience- the food was solid (fish was fresh and sake was delicious) and the staff was incredibly accommodating, especially Michelle. She took care of our party! Definitely coming back!
author: Laura H.

description: Sushi Hunter is a fantastic restaurant with friendly staff and an excellent selection; both on their made-to-order all you can eat, and à la carte menus. I really enjoyed the devil roll, and their gyoza were sinfully delicious.
author: Brian W.

description: I normally don't write good or bad review unless it's really good or really bad! This place is the worst sushi place I never been to! $28 for a BS sushi buffet, and only couple choices of fish, ok fine, so I was expecting for some good fish, but WTF, the fish tasted like shxt, I can't even put it close to my mouth, those weird smell, OMFG! If I can give negative star from -1 to -10, I will give it -10 no doubt!
author: Andy O.

description: Just went in to buy a beer so I could use the restroom.  The waitress was so rude to us that we started calling the place c@nter sushi.  Avoid this place and go spend your money someplace run by nice people.
author: tony b.

description:
I give this place 4 stars because it really is good sushi!  I grown with this place before they were that popular and they changed a bit.  Prices have gone up (bad) new sushi rolls have been created (good) but service was always a bit slow.  

I do the all you can eat sushi because its the only way i can actually get full and not spend over $100.  I do eat a lot of sushi so i constantly have to reassure them i know how many pieces i'm ordering.  This would be a familiar convo:

Waitress:  What do you like ?
Me:  4 Orders of the Seared Tuna, 3 Orders of the Albacore Tuna, 2 orders of the New York Roll, Um, I will also have the .....
Waitress :  You know each order has more than one sushi right ?
Me:  Yes i know that missy  - keep writing!  "One order of the rainbow roll"

But hey for the average bear - you'll get your free parking validation!  (I think they validate for 2 hours)

So next time your in North Beach and get stopped by the Italian restaurant owners every 12 seconds...Tel them your going to Sushi Hunter to fill your stomach will all you can eat Mercury!!!
author: Slim S.

description: I love this place and have probably eaten here over 30 times in the past 2 years. It's not the best sushi in the SF but it's pretty good and the price is not crazy like other places. The all you can eat menu is my jam. 5 stars!
author: Jill S.

description:
There are two terms that generally shouldn't be used in the same sentence. "All you can eat" and "sushi".

Y'see, when it comes to an all you can eat affair, it's generally quality over quantity. Seriously - think of the majority of all you can eat places you've been to, and you'll likely remember lots and lots of food, but none of it particularly good.

And when you take quality away from sushi, then... well, it often involves calling in sick, and setting up camp in the bathroom the next morning.

Sushi Hunter, tho, is in the minority in giving quality AND quantity. Their $23.95 all you can eat menu is a serious value if you go in there hungry - although in true all you can eat fashion, it evens out in the end. (My friend and I certainly wolfed down more than $24 worth of sushi. The girls, on the other hand, nowhere near it. So... balance!) Their nigiri was acceptable - not mind blowingly good, but I've CERTAINLY had worse (I've actually had FAR worse, which led to one of those affore mentioned sessions in the bathroom). Their tempura was actually quite good. Their gyoza was, in my admittedly limited opinion, excellent. Rolls are standard fare - none of the fancier varieties, but relatively solid California rolls, rock n rolls, spicy tunas and the like (check out the devil roll, my personal fave!)

The service, I have to say, can be a tad spotty - but when the chefs are whipping out unlimited goodies for tubbs like me, with two waitresses running hither and tither, I couldn't hold it against them.

Like I said. It's not the best sushi money can buy, but this little place in North Beach is a helluva deal, and a new favourite spot of mine.
author: Gary E.

description: Compared to all-you-can-eat sushi restaurants in SJ and LA, this one is subpar. A relative put it as "the sushi you get at a buffet (that provides a vast variety of entrees) but without the buffet". The quality really isn't as great as it should be for the price they charged us. Plus, our 3-year olds and 5-year olds were charged as individuals for the all-you-can-eat, but all they have is a few bites of the excess rice (the rolls were 90% rice anyways)! Other sushi restaurants we've attended in the bay never charged our infants for all-you-can-eat. The servers would randomly leave our table and not take our full orders, so we would have to flag them down. The waitress was quite impatient with our arrivals and was even trying to remove our reserved seats and tables claiming that they were expecting a "full house" despite empty tables throughout our entire dinner. It takes them 20 minutes to just bring out wasabi, yet they expect us to finish quickly in the case of a "full house". Why offer all you can eat if the restaurant can't handle the demands?
author: Sharon T.

description: Best Sushi spot in North Beach. Nice fun atmosphere with all you can eat options, good for groups. Try the Hunter Salad.
author: Rocky B.

description:
They offer a $25 all-you-can-eat menu, so if you're looking to carb up, do that! 

I've only tried individual rolls, which are usually average. The reason I gave 4 stars is for my favorite thing: I CRAVE their tuna poke salad.  OMG ITS SO GOOD and SO SPICY! their tuna is always fresh. 

I can't really say how good everything else is but my friends love doing the all you can eat thing (its made-to-order) so we seem to keep going back. Yay, i'm a fan.
author: Danielle R.

description:
We were on a classified mission for a sushi joint...so what was I doing in North Beach you might ask?

Not my fault...I didn't drive, I took a nap after an exciting task of bookkeeping all day and my driver missed Geary St so we ended up at North Beach by the time I woke up...whaaat! 

However, we actually spotted a sushi joint...thought I'd try this place out

I glanced at my to eat list and gorged on the following:

Philadelphia Roll - Fresh Salmon, Avocado & Cream Cheese
Red Dragon Roll - Tempura Prawn Inside, Topped with Tuna & Avocado
Tokyo Pizza Roll - Red Snapper & Mozzarella Cheese Inside, Slightly Fried, Topped with Scallion & Tomato Sauce
 
Sweet. I lucked out again because I actually found a winner in picking one of the best sushi I've ever tasted. Well...fusion sushi. The selection I've tasted were of definite quality but the Tokyo Pizza Roll was to die for and something that I know I'd have a craving for in the near future. Interesting that it happens at an area which I would visit for a bite off a calzone or a chomp off a pasta plate.

Mission accomplished...all is forgiven. But, driver, don't forget your GPS next time...
author: Charmian D.

description: BEWARE: "All you can eat" is not available when they are busy. We made a reservation to get our fill of sushi but was told it's not available to us even though EVERY other table had it available to them. Apparently it's up to their discretion even though it's clearly advertised outside. And they don't inform you until you place your order.
author: Alexander L.

description:
Hurray for sushi buffet in the city!  Now I can be a fatty without driving out to the boonies!

I should have looked more closely at their website before going, but they validate parking for 90 minutes!  Sweetens the pot that much more, since it borders the nightmare of all parking hell, NoBe.

$26 for all you can eat menu (http://www.sushi-hunter.com/ayce.htm).  Like all other sushi buffets, they tend to mess up your order and forget things.  A lot.  But we spent a lot of time in there, so we just kept ordering.  It was great.

Try the chicken karaage, gyoza, and especially the devil roll.
author: Jenny L.

description: Food was good but overshadowed by the excessive wait time. Took forty five minutes to get drinks and at one point the waitress came back thirty minutes after taking our order to ask what we ordered again. They need more staff!
author: Sarah O.

description:
All you can eat and drink for around $40. Pretty good sushi, very patient staff considering our intoxication level. No time limit and a cool blue decor. We stayed for about four hours. Sushi Hunter won.

Makes for a great time before hitting the bars.
author: Jason C.

description: Not the best and not quite the worst either. If average was a spectrum they would be somewhere in the lower middle. However, two of the items we ordered were unavailable and they informed us of one after other items have already come out and theother unavailable item was informed at the end of our meal. Bottom, theres a ton of other choices in north beach, dont bother with this place!
author: Jennifer C.

description: This place is the best AYCE I've ever been to. They don't use too much rice on the nigiri, the fish melts in your mouth, and the service is super friendly! I recommend the HAMACHI, maguro, and sake nigiris. This place sparked a love for nigiri that may burn in my body for a long, long time. I have been here three times in the past couple months and I will be back very soon!
author: Adam T.

description:
All you can eat sushi that doesn't make you sick (granted, they're pretty boring/basic rolls, but when you have a serious sushi craving and are strapped for cash, it's a freaking deal).

All you can drink sake on top of all you can eat sushi for a mere $12 more? Trouble.

FYI, during our last trip, we found out that they now have a 2 credit card max for splitting. Anything over 2 and you get charged $1 extra a card. WTF?
author: Karena Q.

description:
Disgusting sushi, $28 for all you can eat, the sushi and everything is very low quality and tiny, the tiny part doesn't matter because the quality is so low that it's better that it's tiny.

The total bill including tip was $45.00 I only had one plate and it wasn't good, i was sitting at the counter and the chef asked me what's wrong and did I want anything else and so did the waitress, but I got the check and just left, I was too worried that I'll have an stomach ache.
author: N A.

description: The food is okay as its all you can eat. The presentation isn't great (i.e., brown avocado), the taste is okay and the sushi has a distinct smell  (i.e., maybe a day or 2 old). Right on with expectations though.
author: Ana J.

description: Great prices, friendly staff, delicious food!!! The best sushi restaurant I've been to in a very long time. $6 for salmon avo roll and tuna avo roll. Both tasted very fresh! Edamame was delicious too. We didn't do all you can eat, but they said that was $25 and had a ton of options.
author: Lindsay B.

description:
Being down the corner from the boy pad, Sushi Hunter is usually our spot for getting chicken udon or tonkatsu with curry to go. Last night was the first time actually eating in the restaurant and getting the chance to be served by the staff that knows our orders by heart. 

Switching things up a bit with their vast menu, Zach got sushi and I got tempura fried mozzarella sticks and garlic butter fried udon with steak added. Surprisingly, I enjoyed the mozzarella sticks, despite being surprised to find them wrapped in my not-so-favorite seaweed. Garlic and butter udon was so-so, but would recommend sticking with tonkatsu if you don't eat seafood and come here. I really enjoy their curry, but they're skimpy on the portion they give you to top your tonkatsu. Salad there I typically avoid, only because the sesame seeds in the dressing are burnt toasted and give it an overpowering flavor.

The staff is really awesome and friendly and the place has a very modern, hip vibe to it. Great for udon and their unique rolls and menu options, but you can find much better sushi for the same stella price elsewhere in my personal opinion, like at Sushi on North Beach.
author: Alita M.

description:
The highlight here is the all you can eat dinner for $25 Monday thru Thursday, and maybe for $27 Friday thru Sunday.  It's all you can eat but such that they bring the items you order to your table, including the sushi from the sushi bar.  There are cooked items and appetizers also to choose from.  Also, for $4 each, you have the option of one order each of a sashimi plate (8 pieces of 2 kinds of fish) and/or a specialty roll (chosen from a list).

For me, one order was very fulfulling.  It's definitely not hard to order at least $25 worth of food from the selection they have.  The two young ladies going around the tables two evenings ago when I went were very friendly also (one in particular, who's also quite cute =) ).
author: H K.

description:
Saba shioyaki, vegetable croquette, and spicy hotate please.  Especially the spicy hotate, and keep them coming.

For twice the amount of money for a sushi buffet in Davis, I could have all-you-can-eat sushi at Sushi Hunter in San Francisco.  In the couple of times I've been at night, it was not busy, and the waitress is so nice, you "either want to be with her or be her."

I can see how sushi hoarding San Franciscans can eat the establishment to the ground, and even though I know Seafood Watch would frown upon this, I wish they had sashimi on the buffet menu.  Then my $26-30 would totally be justified.
author: Jenn C.

description: I love this place I've been coming here for years and the food is amazing. Great sushi, great environment, and great people. The only difficulty is parking but what do you expect this is San Francisco.
author: Yousef E.

description:
All you can drink sake + a big group is a dangerous thing. When the sake shots start going and everyone starts egging each other on, it's easy to lose track of how many shots you've done. Trust me, it's happened to me on one special occasion here at Sushi Hunter and my bf has never let me forget it. 

With that said, the AYCD sake makes SH a fun place for groups.  I've been to SH three times now, all with large groups of 10+, and I've had a good time at each occasion.  Reservations are easy to make and they're great at accomodating large parties in the small space.  The AYCD sake is an additional $10 on top of the $25 AYCE sushi.  If you're not a fan of hot sake, you might be better off buying bottles. Personally, I prefer chilled, unfiltered sake, but I can't pass up the value of the AYCD sake so I let the hot sake chill to room temperature and chase it with some cold Sapporo. 

The quality of the AYCE sushi has gone down over the years... Or maybe I was alot more sober on subsequent visits.  I used to think that the AYCE sushi was really delicious, but something about the temperature/flavor of the AYCE sushi was a bit off.  The temperature seemed a tad warmer than room temperature, which didn't do wonders for the flavor/texture of the sushi.  I took a few bites of sushi and stopped eating. Luckily, the AYCE list involves many cooked items. My gf and I shared tonkatsu, assorted tempura, gyoza, beef teriyaki, and chicken karaage. Those cooked items went a long way towards prepping my tummy for AYCD sake.  

The interior recently underwent a major renovation. Gone are the yellow walls and garrish lights. They now have white padded panels lining the walls and dark, blue mood lighting.  It's amazing what lighting can do to make a restaurant seem 10x classier. 

Overall: Sushi Hunter is a fun place for groups, but don't go expecting the best sushi.  I only come here for group occasions and for AYCD sake.
author: Monelle A.

description:
I was pretty excited to try this place since I'd heard it was lively, fun and had decent sushi.  Have to say we fell short on all counts although the wait-staff wasn't impolite.

I ordered the AYCE on a whim, which apparently is code for the chefs to include as little actual meat on a roll as humanly possible.  

By the second order, I was finding pieces with so little substance that I had to send the 1/4 of the plate back.

If a restaurant is so reluctant to serve something that they refuse to do it well, for everyone's benefit just leave it off the menu.
author: Colin P.

description:
My friends and I came here on a Sunday night for all-you-can-eat sushi, a rarity in this economy.  This was one of the few places we could find that still has all-you-can-eat and is still open.

We ordered the Sho Chiku Bai Creme sake, and it was great!  Well worth the $13 a bottle.

The waitresses were on top of our orders in the beginning, and the food came within about 10 minutes of each order.  The waitresses were super friendly and attentive.

We ordered almost everything on the all-you-can-eat menu.  However, beware of the Kentucky Fried Chicken roll and the Hot Angel roll.  We didn't particularly care for either of these rolls.  The KFC roll is fried chicken karaage, lettuce, and ranch in a roll.  The Hot Angel roll has fried salmon and cream cheese with spicy, sweet thai chili sauce.  We ate them because we had to.

The fish was fresh and well prepared.  This place is definitely worth the $26 for all you can eat sushi.  I would absolutely recommend this place to anyone.
author: Jess k.

description:
My boyfriend and I ordered dinner from Sushi Hunter two weeks ago.  It's our go-to sushi place because it's close to our apartment, decently priced, and makes deliveries.  They also have an in-house all you can eat menu for $25 per person, which I have taken advantage of more than once.

We ordered two miso soups, the Large Sashimi Plate, two pieces of Ikura, the Spicy Scallop Roll (spicy tuna and cucumber), and the Spicy Tataki (spicy tuna and cucumber topped with seared white tuna and garlic).  The Large Sashimi Plate contains 25 pieces and costs $33, which is the best deal we've ever found and the reason we get it every time.  The only drawback is that you can't request specific types of fish, so if you're really picky, you're probably better off ordering individual sashimis.

Per usual, everything tasted good.  The salmon sashimi could always be fresher, and there could always be more mackerel in the sashimi plate (this time we got none), but at the end of day, sushi of any kind makes me happy.

Per not usual, they were late in delivering our meal.  They told us it would take 45 minutes, but we waited for an hour, and when I called them, they told me that we had wait an additional 10 minutes because they were understaffed.  As apology, they gave us a 10-ounce bottle of nigori (cloudy) sake, which I mixed with orange juice and which more than compensated for the extra wait.
author: Niya Y.

description:
I take back everything I said. I came back a second time with my boyfriend, and the food/service quality dropped a bit. That's okay, I still really liked the place. But when my sister and her husband came for a visit (their first time to the West coast), I thought I'd bring them here for a nice dinner. 

We got AYCE sushi. It wasn't very busy, but service was extremely slow. When I told the waitress we were getting AYCE, I immediately got the stink eye, a big sigh and "fine." Uh okay, grumpy waitresses happen. As long as I get good food it'll all be good.

But then our first order of rolls came in. Most were alright, nothing special but decent. But some rolls...Thick thick slices, some as big as a slider. Yeah, three big bites to eat a regular sushi roll, and these weren't one of those western sushi rolls with a bunch of stuff in them. Ridiculous. 
Then the deep-fried rolls. They were delicious the first time I came here, just okay the second, but this time... a big mouthful of batter. A batter so thick it wasn't cooked all the way through, I could peel off the skin to reveal 
creamy white watery dough. Nasty. But maybe it was just a bad day for the chefs too.

After our first two orders, nothing. Empty water glasses for about 20 minutes, trying to get a waitress as they made a huge obvious circle around our table. When I said we'd like to order again, our waitress, who had just finished chatting about clubbing with another table, rolled her eyes. Up until this point I just thought the rolls were hit or miss, and maybe everyone was just tired. I was tolerating everything pretty fine 'cause hey, shit happens, but this annoyed me. A lot. 

I finished up ordering for my sister and her husband. Thankfully they didn't have any good experiences here to compare to, so it was just so-so to them. Plus they left the ordering and stuff to me so they never had to interact with the waitress. All in all just another slow mediocre out of state restaurant to them, a never-come-back again place for me.
author: Cindy L.

description:
HARD TO FIND, SLOW and AWKWARD!
