Well we get there for a 730 reservation, and we didn't get served until 9pm. The guy sat us down at about 8pm, but didn't take our drink orders until 830. The waitress was not attentive and I was offended when I told her that we're NOT all doing AYCE. She said, "its either you all do or dont because there's no sharing". The AYCE is $28 a person, for just the basic stuff then they charge you $4 extra each specialty item on the menu. That's misleading I think, considering they advertise AYCE for $28 and then you get there and all these exclusions and what not are all over the menu.. The food took forever to get to the table and the waitress I think made sure she didnt ask if we wanted any more.. 

If i ever go back to SF, I wont be going back to this place.. its just not worth spending 3hours and still be hungry because they dont want to feed you..
author: Cathy L.

description:
I concur - this place is pretty good for the price - all you can eat $27 a person *MADE TO ORDER sushi, not some nasty California rolls that have been circling the dirty sushi boat water for hours.  How easy is it to drop $30 on sushi.  This is a no brainer if you're craving pretty good sushi.
Service was nice too.

Note: Make a res if you're going on a weekend night or be prepared to wait and be forced to listen to 'sake bomb' shouting from loud attention deprived adults. Yes, it gets loud so don't think it's a great place for a 1st date unless, of course, you don't mind yelling over the music and crowd.
author: Athena S.

description: for 25 bucks all you can eat sushi, pretty good quality. Great service too.
author: Joe K.

description: The interior promises a lot but ever since I'm in SF I've never experienced something like this. Charging for not eating the rice when you order the all you can eat? Honestly, that's just insane and bad business! You actually have to pay for "rice balls" if you left rice on your plate just because you didn't want to eat that much. Let's put it this way: I won't have sushi here again. Never again!
author: Rudi B.

description:
The fish seems to be of good quality, and service is nice.

But PLEASE, what is it with the amount of rice on the rolls??? It tasted like a drop of fish in a bowl of rice!! Not necessary... Just charge more, and give a decent sushi roll. 
If you're into rice bowls, order 2 rolls, put it in a bowl, and you'll be happy.

Definitely not worth it...
author: Michel A.

description: One of my favorite sushi places to get take out from. The wait time is always reasonable and they're open late! Rolls are good and they have BUTTERFISH:)
author: Shanna M.

description: If you like sushi then Sushi Hunter is a must.  I love sushi and I'm so tired of restaurants that serve overpriced, mediocre sushi.  When I moved to North Beach and discovered Sushi Hunter around the corner I was amazed by their unbelievable fresh sushi, reasonable prices and wonderful service.
author: Meghan N.

description:
I don't care how cheap it is, or how much you can drink for 10 bucks....I cannot stomach the sushi. And, well, it's a sushi restaurant so that should be the main concern. Right? Kinda like King of Thai (don't you dare call them a sports bar.. ha) 

I just walk by and my stomach turns. 

I'm rarely a hater on yelp... but the sushi is dare I say old and of poor quality. 

My roommate and I have coined a phrase "NO Sushi Hunter" for when things are just bad. Nuff Said.
author: Hailey P.

description:
We were in fact "hunting for sushi" at sushi hunter.

This place used to have an Epic all-you-can eat deal. Now, apparently all-you-can eat means pay up, then go get some pizza down the street.

Was at the restaurant with a party of 9, waited 3 hours for a few plates of sushi, left hungry.  Management needs to improve!
author: Jeremy S.

description:
I had Katsu Curry chicken on Aug. 29, 2014. I have been a curry freak since living in Japan in the 70's. I can and do make better tasting curry.
It was bland, no curry taste, no carrots, onions, or potatoes as stated in the Menu... not enough curry sauce served with dish. since it was so bad I didn't eat it all... and she was mad I didn't leave a tip. My tip to her was make better tasting curry. I don't tip for a horrible meal.
author: Bruce D.

description:
Heard this place had AYCE sushi and thought...yay!

They have a lot of stuff on the AYCE menu, not just sushi, such as fried chicken, egg rolls, fried tofu, salad...list can go on.  Personally though, I think the non-sushi items on the menu were better than the sushi.  The sushi didn't taste very fresh and the other stuff they combined with it just did not go together.  I couldn't stop binge-ing on their salad and fried chicken though and we had a good amount of sushi left.  

Also, our sushi orders came out veryyyyyyy slow.  And a few rolls never came out at all. They weren't especially busy when we came in so I'm not sure why service was so slow.  The fact that the check could only be split into 2 cards max and didn't tell us until the end was annoying also.  

In the end I spent $40, which included one beer.  I would've much rather have went to a normal sushi place and spent the $40 on better quality fish.  AYCE was NOT worth it here.
author: Jane N.

description:
A third location to defy the "dirty overhang + sketchy neon signs = avoid" rule (the other two being Bamboo Hut and Chili Cha Cha)

All you can eat sushi: $26 on weekend nights and $24 on weekdays.  They have an extensive AYCE menu, where you order the food and the waitresses bring out what you order.  And not only sushi, either, the menu included appetizers (edamame, wakame salad, agedashi tofu) and entrees (tempura, donburi, katsu) as well.  

But, of course, we must stuff ourselves full of the sushi to get our money's worth!  The rolls weren't top-of-the-line (for example, the spider roll did not include tobiko) and the nigiri didn't cause me to make my O face, but everything was very tasty and fresh.  And, I feel it's important to add, I didn't feel like they were trying to overstuff me with rice on rolls or nigiri.

So, put aside your worries about the sketchy storefront, and enjoy unlimited tasty sushi!
author: Cathy Y.

description:
I'm no sushi connoisseur, but I thought this place was pretty good.  Came here for sushi buffet, probably had 3 or 4 big plates of sushi.  None of it is super fancy (just the plain stuff), but mostly fresh.  

My favorites: Albacore roll, Salmon nigiri, SalmonQ rolls.  Spider roll.  

Everything unagi was NOT fresh.  

Perhaps unknown is that the buffet includes MANY other japanese dishes that were all quite amazing - udon in soup, miso soups, tempuras, katsus, etc.

Get the chicken karage - basically fried chicken bites, boneless.  It was SO tender and moist and tasty!  Wish we ordered this earlier in the meal, then we'd have gotten two or more.  I also thought the gyoza was quite good.
author: Jeffrey Y.

description: This place is too noisy.  I can't really hear my friends talking and they already have carpet.  Service is okay, it's all you can eat so after two orders don't expect services.  Do not order their tempera.  Not good at all...
author: CNS M.

description:
Sushi Hunter = a lot of fun... almost too much fun!

On Friday night, 3 couples headed to Sushi Hunter after a couple glasses of wine. The girls donned going-out dresses (a little fancy for this venue) and the boys wore black-though-not-matching shirts. We arrived at Sushi Hunter and were very pleased to only wait about 5 minutes for a 6-person table.

Immediately, we inquired about the all-you-can-drink-sake. In order to order all-you-can-drink for $12, you also need to order all-you-can-eat for $24.95. This seemed a bit pricey for the food but the menu looked good and we decided to go for it.

It felt pretty good ordering anything and everything off the menu that we wanted. I think I consumed about 6 seaweed salads and was really excited about them... the all-you-can-eat includes a ton of appetizers, dishes like chicken teriyaki, nigiri, and sushi rolls. Some of my favorites were the pot stickers, edaname, and unagi rolls. The quality was nothing extraordinary but what would you expect for all-you-can-eat? The girls may not have gotten our money's worth on the food but we definitely did on the sake! This was a great start to a pretty ridiculous night.

I'm not sure how much of a scene we made since we were not too concerned with that. A lot of others seemed to be having fun too though. The restaurant is very bright and not very fancy but, who cares, it offers all-you-can-drink sake!
author: Meghan P.

description: Very good food. Price is pretty decide for SF. Everyone there is very nice and friendly. Can't really beat all you can eat sushi, and it's fresh!!
author: Hole N.

description: All-you-can-eat menu for $25, son!  Chicken karage, gyoza, tempura, and a gazillion bowls of edamame to share...  2 crunchy rolls and 2 bowls of udon for me...maybe a 3rd bowl if I'm feelin good... pack on the spicy powder for an extra blast of flavor...AND if I've been REALLY good, I'll get the green tea ice cream mochi dessert.  Can make reservations through opentable, which is awesome and explains why I am eligible for the $20 gift certificate...I eat here so damn much :)  I Love Sushi Hunter!
author: Kat C.

description:
It's all you can eat for 24 dollars.  Lets just leave it at that. 

 It kinda reminds me of all the all you can eat sushi restaurants in the City.  Quality is never as good.  You just kinda want to stop eating after a while but you can't because you don't want to get ripped off by not ordering.  After you finish eating you say to yourself I will never do the all you can eat ever again.  

The highlights were the chicken karaage, curry katsu, white tuna, and the croquette.

The lowlights........the rolls......something about the rice.  It was very mushy.

The service, on the other hand, was excellent.  Very fast, efficient and friendly.   There is absolutely no complaint in  that department.  The food is probably 2 stars but an extra star is for their service.
author: jason g.

description:
This review is based on the bento box on a to-go order.  
 
This is the closet sushi restaurant near the area I am staying, so I decided to try it after getting off work since it is near the bus stop at the Washington Square park. I ordered the bento box to go. I ordered the pork cutlet, vegetable tempura, and tuna rolls. It came with miso soup and salad. My pork cutlet was pretty small. Probably 4 inches long, and 2 inches wide, 0.5 inch high. The salad and soup is mediocre for japanese restaurants. The worst part about the meal was actually the vegetable tempura which was basically tasteless. The sauce did not help whatsoever. The tuna roll is decent, nothing special.  

I have yet to have a dine-in experience and to try their actual rolls.
author: Becky Q.

description:
I went here ready to get my grub on because I heard a lot of people talk about this restaurant.  Wow... was this place a big letdown.

It was some of the worst sushi I have ever had.  It was EXACTLY like that cheap Chinese buffet sushi.  You know what I mean... the kind that sits under that lamp next to the soft serve ice cream machine and soda. It is technically still slabs of raw fish that constitute sushi but of such low quality that it is a bastardization of everything that real sushi stands for.

Service is sporadic and the language barrier is damn near impossible to get through.  Sushi orders are straight forward and simple but the staff either: 1.  just does not get it or 2. scribbles down something and you are left sitting there worried that they just nodded with a blank stare and won't deliver your order.

Parking is impossible by this place.  My advice: take a magic carpet.
author: Joey S.

description: I've eaten here several times.  The sushi is good, the staff is friendly, the prices are reasonable, and I love the atmosphere.  My boyfriend and I usually go for the sushi platter for two.  It's a good amount of food and good variety of sushi for two people.
author: Abby S.

description:
I never write reviews, but I must write this one to warn others.

I came here on a Friday night, ordered mackerel, red snapper, butter fish, salmon and white tuna sashimi.  Immediately after, my arms break out in hives, five hours later, my entire body and face was covered in hives, I had to go to the emergency room.

This is not an isolated incident.  In another review (4/10/2010), a fellow yelper and his friends also experienced bad sashimi from this place, which resulted in hives, puking, and other stomach problems.

Good service but really bad food, will never go again.
author: Patrick W.

description:
BEST ALL YOU CAN EAT (AYCE) SUSHI IN THE CITY!!! This isn't crappy buffet all you can eat sushi, this is MADE TO ORDER!

BEST when enjoyed with a large group, as you can't try too many things with just one or two people, and you would get charged for individual plates if you don't finish 95% of what you ordered them to bring out. You can get away with having 1 or 2 people NOT get AYCE, but otherwise, as people mentioned, $24/$26 M-Th/F-Su. Check out their website for their AYCE menu.

This place is pretty creative with your orders too. If you order 3 "Devil Rolls" (our favorite!!) they will arrange it accordingly to make it decorative if it's not too busy (which it often is). They do occasionally (almost once every visit) bring you something you didn't order, so try to remember what you asked for. If you forgot, eat it anyway, you know it's going to be good!

The only down side, and i think i get their strategy, they are slow to come take your next order of refill sushi. I think they do this so you don't eat too much, because the longer you sit, the more the rice will expand in your tummy, hence, the full feeling will come out easier! Nice try Sushi Hunter, i'm on to you! :-) No, they do not over stuff their sushi with rice however, so good job on that Hunter!

Please be polite to the servers, they are working hard and so are the chef's! Good job Sushi Hunter, you've got me hooked and through me, at least 10 others!

GET SOME!!! (sushi!)
author: Larry B.

description: This is the worst sushi place I have ever been to. It takes forever to get food. The servers are rude and the food comes out warm and terrible. I don't know why I came here it is terrible
author: George S.

description:
Yikes. No wonder this place has 60% off restaurant.com certificates...I'm surprised they're still open! 

I made reservations, and when we arrived, the place was half empty, yet our hostess told us we "needed" a reservation. Hmmm, really?

There were so many (too many) things wrong with Sushi Hunter, I apologized to my friend for bringing him here, although the company actually made up for a pretty horrible dinner.
First off, they charge the same amount (around $4.75) for nigiri, and only give you about 2/3 of fish. I'm the kinda sushi fan that believes fish should "drape" over the sides of the rice for a decent nigiri. Apparently SH doesn't share that same belief. Their motto? More rice!

I think over 1/2 of what I ate was rice, which is very disappointing. The Hotate nigiri was also disappointing...I'm guessing they use bay scallops instead of the bigger sea scallops, which is why the scallop pieces were chopped up rather than placed over the rice without seaweed.

Our waitress didn't know simple questions when we asked her (such as what fish they serve that are sustainable, or whether the salmon is fresh or farmed, etc.).

What I can say is that the decor is alright, very "aquatic" themed. And overall, I have to admit that my favorite nigiri here was the red snapper, pretty damn good. Unfortunately, that's about it.

Why spend $80 here when you can literally go right across the street and have amazing paella and wine at Iluna Basque?
author: Alyssa G.

description:
Came here for my boyfriend's birthday. We chose the all you can eat option that's $26 per person. It had items from appetizers, entrees, sushi rolls, and nigiri. We definitely ate more than $26 worth of food each! Good portion control and variety of items. My favorites are the sushi nigiri and beef teriyaki. Usually restaurants serve beef teriyaki well done but they serve it medium rare which is definitely juicier! What I love the most is that everything is fresh made to order, and you can keep ordering as you eat as long as you eventually finish everything. My boyfriend is a fan of sushi rolls which I thought was just ok but totally worth the price. We ordered a 6 sushi rolls, a total of 17 items from their AYCE menu.

The restaurant atmosphere is very hip and cool, age range mostly around mid 20s to 30s. Pretty good service, they even gave my boyfriend a free nicely arranged mochi dessert for his birthday! And sake bombs are apparently a popular drink there, we kept hearing people around us yelling sake bombs throughout dinner.

We are definitely planning to come back to try their regular menu which has an even more variety of entrees, combos and specialty rolls.
author: Linda L.

description:
The Sushi Hunter is a great place! Nothing like a hectic, dirty, fast-food-style restaurant, but rather a comfortable, beautiful restaurant with a nice atmosphere.
The all u can eat menu offers an incredibly huge selection of not only sushi, but also hot dishes, soups, salads and much more. I was amazed that the portions were also beautifully arranged and the quality was really good: fresh, tasty and high quality!

The sushi itself offers a large variety of traditional and also more modern, temporary creations, which were all sooooo delicious (and believe me, we tried A LOT!). 

Seriously, if you love sushi, and you love to eat a lot of it, then try the Sushi Hunter!
author: Kat G.

description: The worst sushi I've ever had. The sushi was warm, not served chilled like it should be. The fish was obviously not fresh and tasted completely fake. To top it off the service was absolutely horrible. After being obviously done for 20 minute and asking for the check  it takes an additional significant amount of time to get the check and get our card back. I will never come back here again. Like all that wasn't enough...I felt sick immediately and through the next day. I don't normally write reviews but needed to notify the public!!
author: Krissy R.

description:
If you're brave enough to try an All-You-Can-Eat sushi joint, then Sushi-Hunter is a pretty good value and the food is adequate. 

Their delivery service, however, is atrocious.
author: West R.

description:
I never thought I'd eat here because dingy looking sushi places scare me.  Well, I obviously should've looked inside because the inside is nothing like the outside.  And thanks to a recommendation from a friend, I finally ventured in for their all-you-can-eat option.  I give it two thumbs up!  

The only AYCE sushi restaurants I've been too involve buffet style platters where you can pick and choose a roll here and there.  Well at Sushi Hunter you place your order with the waitresses and they bring you the food.  So if you just want to try a bite of a particular roll, you're locked into 6 pieces.  They all taste good, so it's not a huge problem, but towards the end of the experience, when you're getting so full that you can't possibly eat anymore, you maybe just want one or two pieces of sushi, rather than six.  

My problem is I'm all about getting my money's worth (and believe me, we did), so I of course ate to the point of pain...because I could.  Be careful.  It's tempting, but it's already such a deal for the price that even after 2 or 3 rolls you're breaking even.  I managed something like 42 pieces of sushi and some seaweed salad.  Next time I'm going for 50, but boy I didn't realize how full I could get.  

My biggest problem at sushi restaurants is being able to consume more sushi than everyone else, and thus going home hungry so as to not break the bank.  Well, here I don't have to worry about that.  I will be back, and I will have trained for a week to be able to make it to 50.
author: Anne Marie B.

description:
I order from here about once a week, we usually have it delivered. The food comes fast and made to order. If you are going to order for delivery I wouldn't order anything cooked. It usually comes a little cold when you want it to be warm. The best thing about the delivery is they have you on file so you don't have to give them your address and credit card number every time you call.

I have also dined in and the wait staff is very nice and attentive. And Guys, they are easy on the eyes. They have a happy hour menu with drink specials and sushi specials. The sushi come is a smaller portion so I'm not sure how much of a deal it is. The fish is always fresh and they have a variety of rolls to choose from.

With the limited options in North Beach, this is definitely my first choice.
author: stacy b.

description:
The Food: The Nigiri consist of a PAPER THIN slice of fish over a huge lump of rice. The rolls were rolled up pretty sloppy and the inners were about the size of a peanut. This place is really stingy on the ingredients other than rice. Shashimi is NOT part of the all you can eat deal. Well why not just pick the fish off the Nigiri? NOPE they require you to eat ALL the rice that is in the rolls and Nigiri.  Okay, there's no way they can go wrong with the Gyoza and vegetable tempura right? Wrong.... even though the outside was fried up the Gyoza was still cold inside! The tempura potato was still RAW!

The Service: There were about 6 tables on a "busy" Friday night. But the order took nearly forever to come. And whats worse is the order that comes isn't even what I ordered. But by that time I was too hungry to 
complain and just took the food anyway.

The Price: I've had much better Japanese food for the amount I paid and I wouldn't go back to this place again.
author: Felix L.

description: Worst place ever! Rice was warm and service was ok. The scallop roll we had to spit out because the scallops were not cooked. I will never go or recommend to anyone. Oh I forgot the water was horrible, so we ordered drinks and those tasted bad too.
author: Sarah B.

description: For all you can eat sushi, sushi hunter is the place to go! Made to order sushi as well as other dishes like beef Teriyaki, chicken teriyaki, gyoza just to name a few off the 60 item all you can eat menu! For $25 it's a great deal! And everything taste fresh and oh so yummy! The service is great! I love the girls there. They work hard and are very polite and always treat me great when I'm there. Whenever I take people out for sushi, there's only one spot I take them, sushi hunter
author: Roger P.

description: Affordable delicious sushi, huge selection of sushi, good service, clean bathroom, pretty atmosphere. What's not to like? Me & my roommate got a total of 3 rolls (about 22 pieces), plus a fried banana dessert & green tea ice cream & it came out to be only 13$ for each of us (26$ total). Definitely want to go again :)
author: Marissa R.

description:
So their all you can eat fat fest is just dismal.

They have many options which is nice but its like choosing from a list of poop. 

The servers are cute and attentive which is cool, but so are the ones ar other restauranrs.

So heres the run down

Saba shio - small but OK
Miso - WAY too much salt
Tai - tasted fishy
Tuna- red slimy blood
Salmon - standard
Tamago - eh
Hamachi- OK
EBI - OK
Surf clam - good
rolls - all not momorable

unagi - eh
Beef teriyaki - super fatty - they used either an end piece or really bad ribeye.  
Chicken Karaage - no thank you
Udon - no!
Tenpura - soggy

The nigiri was setup such that it was all rice a very little fish.

Been here twice now but won't be back for a third.
author: Spanky M.

description: Great vibe.  Great place. Yummy affordable food and happy to serve service. Coming back!
author: Sincerely G.

description:
Not bad for all you can eat sushi.
Devil roll, hot angel roll, Alaska roll, wild fire roll
Salmon nigiri
author: L B.

description:
I came here with a group of 5 for ayce sushi dinner on a Saturday night. Among the 5 of us, we ordered probably 4 or 5 rounds of countless nigiri and rolls, plus several appetizers. My favorites were the hamachi nigiri (very fresh!), wakame, and agedashi tofu. One of the pros of doing ayce sushi here is that there is no limit to how much you are allowed to order at once, as long as you are able to finish it. One complaint I do have is that the texture of the rice is ehh (a little too much on the mushy side), and I've heard that the fish to rice ratio of the nigiri can be kind of one-sided (meaning way too much rice and not enough fish). For the price, I think I'd rather have ayce sushi at Sushi 85 in Mountain View.

-L.
author: Leeann C.

description: This food was amazing! The service was good and it was a pleasant atmosphere. I definitely recommend!
author: K B.

description:
Great value when you do the All-You-Can-Eat, just bring an appetite. I've never had any complaints when it comes to the food, and the staff has always been friendly and welcoming. The sushi chefs are hilarious if you find the time to chat them up.

They're very accommodating to large groups, just be aware that it can get relatively rowdy on Thur-Fri-Sat nights when the bottomless Sake deal is in full effect. When it's crowded, expect to wait ~15-20 mins between orders, so make it count when ordering (volume-wise). 

An additional +, Sushi Hunter is very active in the philanthropy world, allowing several different groups to host fundraisers there.
author: Joe A.

description:
Take a second to look at my profile pic and you'll see I'm not messing around here. 

Our party of 4 did the buffet.  The waitress underestimated us.  We did serious damage.  On that note, service was just a tad slow by my standards, but that was all made up for, with huge orders of sushi, high quality fish, and a reasonable price for SF.

The sushi buffet can be improved upon with slightly faster service, turning the music volume down a notch, and including sashimi.
author: Matthew W.

description:
sushi here is comparable to any other ayce sushi joint.  the only reason why I would consider coming here again is if i had the urge to drink ridiculous amounts of sake.  Granted it is crappy sake,  but for an additional $10 to your meal, it can't be beat.

come here thirsty, not hungry.
author: Ngoc N.

description:
Regular customer - Always satisfied with the AYCE menu. Rolls are carefully made with good ingredients. Great non-sushi selection in the AYCE menu to complement the meal. Knocked 1 star off because service can be a little slow sometimes - but not to the point where it is a major inconvenience the experience. 

One of the times was here for a friend's birthday and they surprised us with a complimentary glass of green tea ice cream and a candle! 

Great for couples and small groups.
author: Yehia B.

description:
So I'd been here before as we live nearby and love all you can eat sushi and after that experience (which wasnt particularly bad), I swore off all you can eat sushi ever again...

Unfortunately today we decided to give it another go (maybe 4 months later).  Given this time it was a Saturday, the all you can eat is more $ than weekdays (makes sense and we knew that beforehand), and the place was pretty packed.  They put us at a little 2 person stand alone in between a bunch of other tables en route to the bathroom table, where my boyfriend bitched about staring at/facing the wall.

Definitely cramped and whenever anyone walked to the bathroom my boyfriend had to scoot his seat in so they could get by...

Aside from that issue, our waters were nearly empty at all points in time, the initial waters they gave us were warm (ice had long melted), and only about half full.  When we'd ask for more water, they literally would ignore us and walk around and refill everyone else in the entire place's water and still not refill ours (nor were other patrons waters actually empty as ours were).  

Additionally, after our initial sushi order, our waitress essentially never came over to us again.
During our first round of rolls my boyfriend discovered a sticker stuck inside a roll, from the skin of an avocado.  Worrisome that 1) they put avocado skins in the sushi rolls, and 2) that the stickers would also be inside the roll.  We pointed this out to one of the waitresses (as ours had never returned), but she sort of laughed like it was no biggie...hm ok.
So as many people said, the time between orders is pretty ridic, and when you have no water and are being crammed in between huge parties/tables nearby who constantly need to go to the bathroom and trample you, the experience is that much less enjoyable.

Most of the rolls (as our water in the rare occasions we had water), were somewhat warm, and yes, mostly rice and little fish.  I do like the crunch roll and the devil roll at first, but then after a couple orders i'd rather jump out a window than finish anymore of either of those rolls.

We had to wait for eternity to be able to tackle someone for a 2nd refill of water (which also hindered our ability to down as much sushi as we could otherwise), and to get our bill.

This time we will NOT be back. I mean it this time. And if we do return, I am 100% certain I will again regret it.

Awful service, worrisome food. That said, the one male waiter (maybe a manager) was very nice and definitely overworked. They need a larger staff, at least for the busy weekend shifts....and given the stickers inside the sushi rolls, perhaps a new kitchen/quality control staff as well.
author: Danielle J.

description:
MY WORST EXPERIENCE EVER!! It is not about the food quality nor the service but the general policy of the place. 

So, I was in a group of 8 people, all 7 of them ordered All you can eat menu, however I decided to take only mozzarella sticks. The waitress, when she heard that I will only do mozzarella sticks ask me to sit on the end of the table so I can not try/share food with the others as they do not allow 'sharing' the all you can eat menu, even if I am a girl and 6 other people were men! ok, logical but come on, 7 to 1, even if I had eaten it would have been the same. But fine. Then, in the middle of the dinner, as I was already done with my mozzarella sticks, and obviously finished especially as I placed my tissue and chopstick paper on the plate, she came and asked me if I am done so she can take away my plate, which was really rude after she pointed out how I am not "allowed'' to try sushi from the others. 

Then, and this is really too much - never in my whole life I had experienced such a bad service and such a bad business!!!  

My friend, the second girl at the table, didn't like that sushi had a lot of rice in it, she left some 'rice balls' in her plate after we finished the dinner. The waitress came, cleaned the table and after including 20% gratuity, charged my friend an extra 3$ for not eating all the rice but ordering more sushi and actually eating more fish but not enough rice which would it make her more full in shorter time!!!!!  

I will repeat again, never ever I had experienced such a bad service, frustrated waitress or management or I don't know what, but it was humiliating. They were treating us as we came there to eat as pigs for some cheap money! 

And we ended up paying 280$ for a dinner for 8 people which we could spend in a normal restaurant but not in this place with not that bad sushi but with worst customers service ever! Never will come back!!
author: Miljana V.

description:
The All-U-Can-Eat menu is a scam! They have very limited choices, and sometimes make you pay extra for very normal items. They also stuff everything with rice. And it was crazy expensive!

 Usually I wouldn't mind but in Boston or LA you can get all you can eat sushi for lunch for 20 dollars after tax and tip. This place charged like 30. 

Look people if you want to make an all you can eat menu, do it right, if you're going to charge that much for so little and dump on the rice, than just don't offer all you can eat at all.

There were two wicked hot waitresses, but they weren't hot enough to make the meal worth it. 

I will likely never eat here again.
author: Arthur S.

description: Came here for all you can eat sushi after the wait for another restaurant was too long. It's not terrible, but it's not great. The rolls were kind of flavorless, but it didn't taste bad. After a while, we didn't really feel like eating all that we could eat. This place is good if you have no where else to go, but there are better options for sushi.
author: Jamie C.

description:
DIdn't know I wrote one, but a follow-up doesn't hurt. Price hasn't changed ever since, and selection is still great. HIGHLY ADVISE getting the teriyaki beef; it is the best cut of meat you'll ever have (yes, on par with some steakhouses I've eaten at). Unagi is still buttery and smooth (some places are chewy).

still reviewing for the all-you-can-eat portion. I'll most likely try some other menu items when my craving isn't as large. yes, it is pricey, but quality comes with that price. for those that don't eat raw food, it has an excellent selection; this is the best all-you-can-eat sushi place I've been to so far in SF.

how can I say that? i'm more for the value side, and with the rolls and items i order, they get toward that $24 mark so easily. thats about 2 appetizers, two rolls, and two nigiri. FYI, i eat ALL the rice; there are starving people out there (and i happen to be one of them)! i've never gone beyond what i can eat and i never try to overwhelm the waitresses; although it may seem forever in between them brining out your orders, thats when you do the other 50% of going to a restaurant - TALK TO YOUR GUESTS.
author: Jeremy W.

description:
So the all you can eat for 24 bucks is absolutely worth its money. you can order from a whole menu of nigiri, sushi, tempura, appetizers & soups.

Cliffs: Very Good for the AYCE offer since you can choose what you like most. 1$ green tea w/ refills ;) 

ive been to some all you can eat sushi places (not only in SF) and i can assure you,  this one is one of the best. oc there the fish/rice ratio is smaller than if you order in a high end restaurant, but its not outrageous or cheeky or anything and then again: you can order as much as you like ;)

there are plenty of different kinds of sushi from the most classic ones like nigiri maguro to more western variations like spider roll or fried California roll. the sushi and the appetizers were lovingly prepared and arranged.
we've tried almost everything on the menu and the only thing i didn't like a 100%  was the beef teriyaki. hence the 4* out of the 5*.

the plain look on the outside is kind of camouflaging the inside, so dont be fooled!
author: rick b.

description: Let me start by saying this is one of the best food places i have ever been to. Not just sushi but food in general . It looks like a hole in the wall but those are usually the best finds. I came here on a friday night at 7pm. The party who we had gone to dinner with has been going here for over a year now and highly recommend . I will most certainly heading back in the very near future!
author: Thomas B.

description: All you can eat sushi and Japanese dishes for a very fair price. The quality is better than you would think for a joint like this. They have nigiris and rolls similar to those at a traditional restaurant. Very trendy feel on the inside and a good atmosphere for some drinking and dining. I was hunting for sushi and ended up eating my heart out and was very happy with the food and service.
author: Ed L.

description: We've been seated for 10 muntes and nobody came to get our order until I called the waiter to get our order. From here on another 30 minutes before our drinks even was served. I have to remind the waiter to bring something from any of our order. We were just getting ready to walk out when they brought something, a chef compliments which was a very tiny slice of fish for a family of five that are starving from a whole day of sightseeing tour of San Francisco. So if you are very hungry, dont go to this place. And then we were hit with $188.00 bill for a below average all you can eat sushi with a terrible service.
author: Lorenzo C.

description: I'm reviewing this as an All you can eat sushi place and not a regular per item place.  I love sushi and always rack up a huge bill.  Have been to the other Sushi buffets in the city but as you know they are not the best quality.  Sushi hunter's all you can eat is a reasonably priced  and you order as you eat  but get quality sushi.
author: Manny R.

description:
It is really all you can eat place. Its not a buffet but you order the food that you want off the menu and the chef makes the sushi fresh for you. The menu is not just limited to sushi but also appetisers and some 'meat' if you so desire. 

The staff is friendly and allows you to order more food upon delivery of the first plate of food to your table. 

I always leave this place fat and happy!
author: Elly G.

description: I'm rating this based off the All-You-Can-Eat option. There are definetly better sushi restaurants in SF but I don't know anywhere else in the city or near SF for made per order all you can eat sushi. I think fish quality is fresh and good. Have been 4-5 separate times and never had issues with quality of ingredients. Like ordering the seaweed salad, miso, gyoza, and then the nigiri and rolls. Hamachi nigiri great as well as tunas. Wait staff very friendly. Good value, good food, nice location, and best about eating all you can eat at sushi is you're not going home feeling sick or going into a food coma but you still for sure get your dollar's worth. Highly recommended! Also, they do bottomless house hot sake for a good deal if you feel like getting a cheap buzz!
author: Moshe B.

description: Lots and lots of rolls. The prices are standard and so is the food. There are definitely better places to go for sushi. It's a decent pick when u r in the neighborhood and u r hungry for sushi and don't want to wander that much.
author: Eve C.

description:
Back in college, our days seemed to be filled with sushi buffets. Maybe because we were poor college students with an endless appetite but also because my bf went to Davis, the land of all you can eat sushi joints. They might not have been the best sushi around but we still have fond memories of dining at those places. When we found an all you can eat option at Sushi Hunter with a free 1.5 hours of parking, we were so there!
 
I guess the first sign I should have taken to heart was the limited amount of specialty rolls offered. Their list seems to be pretty long with appetizers, hot dishes, nigiris and rolls but everything offered was average or below.

We had the edamame and miso soup for appetizers. How edamame can taste so bland I don't know but they did here. We were stuck with a huge bowl of it too that we had to finish or would be charged for wasted food. We had the tempura and saba for our hot dishes and those were just okay. I didn't really like the tempura green peppers. I'm not really used to those in my tempura mix. The saba was very oily but not bad. 

They try to make their list look diverse but all of the rolls were basic.  The most "special" were the rock n' roll and spicy hotate (scallop) roll. They also had a Kentucky roll which was chicken and lettuce. I think it's obvious that one didn't taste good. Actually most of them didn't taste good.

One of my biggest peeves was how slow the service was. It almost seemed like they wanted us to go over our validated 1.5 hours of parking so we'd have to pay the garage for going over. If that was their intention, they successed. We had to pay an extra $6 because of how slow they were. And trust me, we can polish off any sized plate of sushi in under ten minutes. 

I'd much rather go somewhere else to order rolls I like than eat a whole lot of average to below average tasting rolls I wouldn't normally order. I highly recommend you look at the menu first before going and really think if you would enjoy what's being offered. Maybe the regular menu is better but I think Davis sushi buffets have this place beat and for cheaper prices too.
author: Julia T.

description: We were here on a Friday night and chose the all you can eat sushi, I was so surprised at the offerings for the price. $28/wknd. The sashimi was EXCELLENT! Absolutely fantastic quality, melt in your mouth fresh. Didn't expect this for the price. The sushi rolls were only average, but many to choose from. I am half Japanese and very picky when it comes to sushi so overall thrilled. The place is very small but very upbeat, However the large group sitting next to us was the loudest I have ever heard in public, so word of warning, if you want quiet dining then this is not the subdued option.
author: Kumi V.

description:
My first review on yelp, regrettably, is not a positive one. My family has been frequenting this local sushi restaurant for the past 2 years on a fairly regular basis hoping in vain that  the quality of service and food will improve. We succumbed to the convenience of their location. Last night, however, they reached their all time low and we have decided not to return again.

Not only is my 7 year old home today with a stomach ache from poor quality sushi (on her birthday no less!), two of our orders were botched, I had to ask twice for a refill of hot versus tepid tea and I had to return two orders of sashimi that looked questionable. On top of all that, the waitress had the nerve to tell me that the fish always looks like that. Really? Shriveled and dry looking? I eat plenty of sushi to know the difference. By the time the food came out, my daughter was falling asleep at the table.

While I am willing to overlook mediocre service for high quality sushi (my favorite food), I cannot compromise on the latter. The biggest shame was that we were regular customers, i.e. a source of regular business to the point where we know nearly all of the wait staff and sushi chefs. To them, it didn't matter and they had the nerve to make me wait for food, drink refills and worse, had the nerve to serve me the s***iest quality fish last night. Consider yourselves warned - there are plenty of MUCH better sushi joints around the city.
author: Mia J.

description:
Ordered the sushi buffet with a friend for 50 bucks total. What I got was plate after plate of cafeteria grade sushi stuffed with rice. Some of the rolls were virtually entirely filled with rice and spotted with that zesty japanese mayonnaise. 

The fish wasn't that wonderful either, seemed frozen or packaged in a way that leached color and flavor from the meat. 

I'd be happy to eat there if I were literally starving but culinary experience this ain't.

I give it one big 'meh'.
author: Jonathan W.

description: surprised to find myself giving 3 stars for all you can eat sushi, which concept I dislike, but for $25, it wasn't bad granted I ate mostly non sushi items such as the spinach, broiled mackerel, tempura, gyoza, etc.
author: Wakako U.

description:
Yes! Finally found decent sushi near my house--and only on the second try!

Came in one night for sushi, was very pleasantly surprised. From outside it doesnt look like much but this place is really cute and has a cool atmosphere. 

The food was good, the service was quick and attentive and the price is right!
author: Britney K.

description:
Ok. Bleah. This place is close by and since the Yelp reviews were pretty good, I decided to try it out. Bleah. This place is about as tasty as it looks from the outside (fake sushi in the window says enough). 

The sushi was ok if not below-average. The typical non-sushi dishes (Bento Box with Chicken Teriyaki & Tempura) was...ok. There are better sushi places out there people!!!
author: Karen S.

description: Sushi Hunter is underrated! I didn't try the sushi/sashimi, but their bento boxes ($16) are bomb! SO MUCH FOOD! I got the mackerel, teriyaki salmon, and curry tonkatsu and everything was A-OK! I love that it's a great value (they give you miso soup, salad, and tea too!), and in a good location. To top if off, our server was extremely charming and attentive. Give this place a try, at least for their bento! You'll leave feeling full and content.
author: Adrienne C.

description:
I bought a restaurant.com gift certificate for Sushi Hunter a while back and finally put it to use today.  Since it is not valid for the all you can eat deal, my boyfriend and I just ordered from the regular menu.

We shared the following:
~ Wakame Salad: pretty small portion for $3.95 but I liked that they drained it pretty well...a lot of places don't bother to and the salad ends up being too wet
~ Volcano Roll: my favorite of the rolls we ordered...super hot like the menu says...yum!
~ Deep Sea Swimmer Roll: spicy tuna and cucumber inside topped with butterfish and tempura crunches...I couldn't really taste the butterfish but it was a very good roll nonetheless
~ Titanic Roll: even though it has tempura prawn inside and is topped with salmon, tuna and spicy crab salad, this was a surprisingly light roll...the salmon and tuna were very fresh as well

The sushi at Sushi Hunter is definitely better than a lot of other places that I've been to and I like that their rolls are different than the standard ones at a lot of places.  Plus, they didn't put a lot of mayo in their rolls, which is awesome.

Even though we ordered less than $40 of food (the gift certificate is good for $25 off for $35 or more), our total came out to be a little under $25 after tax and 18% gratuity (automatically added for using the gift certificate), so I am definitely glad we had that.  If parking wasn't such a pain, I'd love to come back more often.
author: Katelynn L.

description:
This is a nice looking place and the food is OK, but the prices are way too high. The standard bento box you get at other places for $7 or $8 is about $15 here. The portions on everything seem small and overpriced. Ive ate here twice and there wasn't anyone else there both times.

Yokohama down the street on Columbus is way better and more affordable but they have weird hours.
author: Mike S.

description:
Whats better than sushi you say? why a sushi buffet of course! Excuse me, its an all you can eat option, not a buffet. Why? thats because they make it when you order it. And all of this for about $25.

The nigiri delicious: mmmm Tuna, Salmon, Hamachi, Unagi
The rolls: not really a big fan of regular rolls but the Rock n Roll was good.
The plus: the all you can eat menu is not just limited to sushi, theres also items like teriyaki beef, fried tofu, chicken cutlet etc etc. 

I walked in there lovin myself and walked out of there disgusted at myself. But I will definitely be coming back here again. Why you ask? Because I love stuffing myself silly with delicious food. Like Sherry Bobbins from the SImpsons said, "Thats the American way!!!!!"

Parkings a bitch! minus one star!
author: Dorian T.

description: I really like this place. In a sea of Italian restaurants it is nice to have an option for good sushi. The all you can eat menu is the way to go. I went on a Saturday and it was $28. I got 3 orders of salmon nigiri, udon soup, a house salad, and a spicy scallop roll. My friend got even more than I did. The house dressing on the salad was really good and and spicy. It was none of that thousand island bullshit, it was homemade. The fish is fresh as well. The waitresses were super friendly and nice and kept coming to our table to ask if we wanted to order anything more. I definitely like this place and will be back for the all you can eat menu.
author: Jennifer J.

description:
Tried the all you can eat Japanese food and not limited to only sushi but to the full menu. You can get sushi, and also order tempura, while adding soup, gyoza, salad, etc...

Great food, music, and nice waitresses

There is also an all you can drink Sake that is the bomb.

you guys gotta try this place
author: Dave C.

description:
Complete surprise!  DAMN this was good.  After sampling beers over at Rogue Ales I was going to come here, get a quick bite to eat, and head home.  Didn't expect much.  "Sushi Hunter?"  Odd name.  Maybe I'll just get a roll or two.  I walk inside, well not bad... sit at the bar.  Look at the menu... "all you can eat"  Oh really!  Been searching for an all you can eat place - that doesn't suck.   Nonetheless, let's order a few pieces and see how it is.  

Kid you not... Every.  Single.  Piece.  Of.  Fish.  Extremely fresh, tasty, flavorful, MELT in your mouth.  I tried the mackerel, salmon, tuna, albacore, yellowtail, eel, a spicy scallop hand roll, and God know what else . ALL good.  Yeah, I stayed a while.   Total tab ended up being like $34 (with some green tea and a Kirin).  And I ate A LOT.  Practically had to roll myself out of here.  Oh, service kicked ass here.  Friendly staff.  Even got some complimentary stuff from the chef.  YUM.

I want to give this place 5 stars bit I will hold back for now, need to come back 2-3 more times to make sure they are consistent.  Been screwed before.  But this place looks promising and appears to be a welcome change from all the hoity-toity places.
author: Chris B.

description: Maybe the warm fish and dry seaweed is saved for all you can eat...yuck. Skip it, you don't need to try it, honestly! Happy hour isn't good either.
author: Daydreamer S.

description:
Its okay. The beef teriyake was fantastic before the remodel. Now its tough and not very tasty. Did the ayce thing --Came out to 33 a person after tax and tip. Found parking a block away--got lucky! 

Staff was attentive enough but the sushi was just meh. some rolls were packed with rice. 

Good eats: devil roll, tempura, udon, gyoza

Bad eats: beef teriyake, veggie croquette (only potatoe now) and kentucky roll 

The remodel makes it dimmer and more loungesque. There were two loud bday parties to the right and left of us but we didnt mind. Then we turned around and saw a family with 2 babies. Ha-its def. a mixed crowd place!
author: Amy S.

description:
I would really give this place a 3.5, but since I can't I am going to round it up to 4.

I went to this place last night with a few buddies of mine. We came in and decided to do the all you can eat where we paid $26 each for unlimited sushi. The ideas is great and we made sure to take advantage.

The environment was friendly, waitresses were courteous and cute, everything was good. I however didn't really like the price of my sushi because to be honest $26 is very pricey. I expected the sushi to be more than great with that kind of price, but instead it was just satisfactory.

I would recommend this place to people who are determined to eat a lot and take advantage of the all you can eat. If not just order a regular sushi plate and admire the cute waitresses.
author: Sonlay V.

description:
I recently tried Sushi Hunter's All you can eat sushi. I was really impressed. I went with a date and it was a great place to go together. I really like the new remodel and it has a very cool lounge feel to it. Our waitress, Danny, was very attentive and made sure we got everything we wanted for the all you can eat menu. 

We had the green salad (all right), the gyozo (good), Alaska Roll, Crunchy California Roll, Japanese Bagel Roll, Rock n' Roll and a few others. We ordered 6 rolls between us and some appetizers. I think it was a good value but it ended up being $37 with tax and tip per person.

All and all, I'll totally come back again. I will fast for days and days upon end and then come in and get my money's worth.

Side story: Danny, our waitress, told us about this guy who ate 60 rolls on the all you can eat menu. We kinda felt like weak sauce, you know, because our number was 3. My goal is 10....60 pieces of sushi, a worthy aim.
author: Lauren J.

description: Just moved into the hood and this will def be my new go-to for sushi. Happy hour can't be beat. Go nigiri: butterfish is the favorite, hamachi and salmon are second favorite. Oyishi roll is the jawn and cold sake warms my heart. Go here.
author: Tommy H.

description:
You know that favorite niece/nephew that's super cute and you just can't get enough of?  Well imagine that same kid suddenly hitting puberty and becoming an royal pain in the ass. That's Sushi Hunter.

I USED to love this place... so much so I was eating the All You Can Eat about twice a week.  They closed for renovation and recently reopened.  More than just the paint colors must have changed because they now received my vote for "WORST SERVICE IN SAN FRANCISCO"

DO NOT waste your time here. I already wasted 2 hours there today, and I refuse to waste another minute going on and on about how BAD of an experience my friends and I had here. 

Face it, Your favorite nephew/niece is dead.  If you're in the area just head to North Beach Sushi.
author: PJ M.

description:
Very disappointing. The nigiri tasted like bleach. Maybe we're to spoiled by all the other excellent sushi places around here ? We got the all you can eat deal, so I kept ordering a new set of nigiri hoping something eventually would taste good. But since everything tasted the same we eventually switched to rolls. Even they were disappointing.

After the nigiri experience I decided to say something to our waitress. She just rolled her eyes and said "well, noone else seems to be having a problem !"

I *love* sushi, but this experience has turned me off fish for a while.
author: Bjornar S.

description:
I came in without any expectations except for my room mate saying it's good. I came out with (woah their fish was by far one of the most freshest fish I had besides zushi puzzle)

I have to go back, I just gotta! The only thing that's holding me back is the amount of money i spend being there. I'll definitely try the buffet next time :)

Oh, the missing star is for the slow service (I think there was only a couple of waiters working a full house) but they made up for it by giving us some stuff on the house.
author: Quinallison D.

description:
I used to enjoy Sushi Hunter whenever we were in the North Beach region, which wasn't too often, but enough...

But sometime between last summer and now, they cheapified... a lot...

Their nigiri went from an okay slice of fish to a laser cut micron of fish... and both nigiri and rolls seemed to be overflowing with just too much rice.  I know they pack AYCE sushi with rice, but this is bordering on ridonkulous.

They used to validate parking at a local garage for 1.5h...  Again, sometime between last summer and now, they've started this racket where they charge you an extra dollar to validate.  Sure, you still save $5 on parking, but c'mon...  isn't it illegal to charge for validation?  if not, it should well be...
author: Roni L.

description: First time here..Very good...nice selection of sushi! Nice with sake(of course) no matter the time of day :) Worth the visit for a local place near little Italy! Its a good spot local spot if you plan on going out with freinds for the night or a good spot to go first before going to other spots!
author: David C.

description:
So . . . was a regular (once a week) for the all-you-can-eat sushi before the recent (and very sad) remodel. It used to be my favorite eats!

However, after two hours of poor service, I left hungry without getting my full order. (they seemed very understaffed) I got too hungry waiting for each entree I ordered off the all-you-can-eat menu I left to get gelato down the street at Gelato Naia (which was awesome!) 

I really hope they get their act together.
author: Eli M.

description: My roommate and I both got the all-you-can-eat sushi from here. It was probably the biggest mistake of my life. First, we both got sick. Additionally, their all-you-can-eat sushi menu is horrible. They claim there are 31 options but it is really just made up of 4 or five options that are slightly modified. STEER CLEAR OF THIS PLACE. it also did not taste good at all.
author: Omar S.

description:
If I can give this place zero stars I would! This is the most disgusting sushi place I have ever been to in my life! Not only were all the waiters rude, but the fish was sour!!! Their water tasted like toilet bowl water and it was very dirty. The only people that actually eat there are young college kids who get so drunk that they don't realize what the heck they are eating because the sake and beer are so freaking cheap!

This place is a rip off!!! Stay away!!!!!!!!! If you want food poisoning then this is the place for you!
author: love l.

description:
All.  You.  Can.  Eat.

no joke. No lies, no bad tries.  They are absolutely serious.  

I've never seen such an extensive all you can eat menu at a sushi resteraunt.  I'm sure some of you are scoffing at my lack of experience... but whatever.

Soup, Salads, tempura, nigiri, entrees and an impressive assortment of sushi.  ALL INCLUDED.. 24.95 on a weeknight (not sure if it was more expensive on weekends) but godddamn it was worh it.

You'd be surprised at how much sushi you can eat... or nigiri for that matter.  That's right boys and girls, cause most all you can eat places either dont' include nigiri, or have some sort of time limit.   I mean you get SOOOO much of that delicious fish and you get full like 1/2 as fast.... translation for all you bad at math folks?  FIIIISHHH!!! woohoo!

Highlights:
soup/salad - maybe I'm old fashioned, maybe I'm just trying to fit in wiht the white people... but its good.  Don't skip it.

Mackeral - I'm not huge on cooked fish but hey.. why not?  Tasty and the butter sauce is good.

Teryaki beef - a bit on the dry side, but get an order for the table anyway.  Gotta have that tangy sauce.

Spicy tuna roll  - YUMMMM really good spicy sauce here nicely done!!

All in all, warm up that appetite (anyway you know how) stretch and get your ass over here.  Prepare for a feasty challenge.
author: Joseph F.

description:
All you can eat sushi - appetizers, tapas style entree portions, rolls, dessert etc...  Speaks for itself!!  Go early to take advantage of this offering. 

Quality meat cuts (beef teriyaki is nice thick slices of steak) and nice to watch the game, music, and modern asian interior.  Recommend the deep fried roll that has sriracha sauce drizzled on it.  Yum!
author: Caroline L.

description: We came here 10 minutes before closing time and the service was prompt, courteous and efficient. The food was very good.  There is an all-you-can-eat menu, but not buffet, it is fresh, made to order and reasonably priced.
author: t d.

description:
Oy. Don't follow the siren call of all you can eat sushi -- you will just be dashed on the rocks. 

The sushi here is just bad. Even the dumplings were nasty. Walk down the street, go to sushi on north beach, spend maybe a few more bucks, and  actually enjoy, rather than endure your dinner. Trust me.
author: Jason B.

description:
Wish this place would chill their glasses before serving the beer in them.
This has been a persistent problem here.  However, they do now chill the bottles of beer more, so if you drink them out of the bottles, they are chilled perfectly.  
Another peeve...why do they provide you with such think napkins and only one at that.
Service can be good or slow. On our last visit, it was slow, even though the place only had about 6 people dining there.  They kept forgetting to bring our beer, were slow in coming back to ask what else we wanted. Was difficult to get their attention because the owner and waitress were always talking together and never looking at the tables. Was rather annoying. We usually get the all you can eat for $$25. pp on weeknights and $28. on weekends.  They also have a decent early bird menu from 5:30 to 7pm with a reasonable limited menu.  However, hen it was time to bring the check.....they were very prompt!  Ha!
author: Girly Foodie F.

description:
So I guess this place was just remodeled.  I find it very entertaining that that means it now looks like it came straight from the 80's.  Not that its a bad thing, I enjoy horrible looking asian places, it usually means its good.  

This was perfectly fine sushi, but nothing out of the ordinary.  Lots of fried stuff, lots of rolls.  The end.  I think I'm spoiled by sushi zone.
author: jessica b.

description:
I finally got a chance to eat here after a friend recommended it.  Five of us went for the buffet and we became fans after our first visit!  The buffet menu selection is pretty extensive (your order is brought to your table).  It would probably be best if you went with a group of 3-4 at minimum in order to try as much on the menu as possible.  The quality of food is excellent and they don't skimp on portions just because it's all-you-can- eat.

I really wanted to give this place five stars since it's now one of my favorite restaurants in the city (I can't believe I never came sooner especially since I've lived in SF my whole life!).  It's very clean (the sushi chefs scrub and spray down the sushi bar at the end of the night), decor is nice, chairs are comfy, and everyone seems to have a good time over a hearty Japanese meal.

However, getting another table's order more than once as well as another table's check warrants 4 stars =/

I'd give Sushi Hunter 4.5 stars if I could!
author: Carter Y.

description:
This review is for service only.  We didn't get a chance to try the food.

We were seated relatively quickly on a busy night but then we sat for about 30 minutes without any acknowledgement from the waiters/waitresses.  Not even a drinks order.  Not any kind of acknowledgement.

We just left.  Really, I understand a busy evening and we weren't in any hurry, but to not even be acknowledged that we would be helped eventually is just too much to take.
author: L. W.

description:
Probably more of a 2.5 after our last visit there, but I bumped it to a 3...

In the past, I've really enjoyed this place. Great selection of AYCE sushi and a decent price. The service is a little slow if you want a water refill etc, but overall a solid place to go.

I was here a few weeks ago though, and was pretty disappointed. 

Soya Sauce was watered down BIG time - like 30% sauce, 70 water.
I ordered several rolls in Tempura and they we soggy
The spicy tuna tempura was actually kinda icky.

Everything else I had was good and fresh - just not what I had expected after the last few times there.

Oh - and they validate parking (in certain spots). I love that! However, they started CHARGING you to validate! Ummm...okay...is that even legal?
author: Victoria L.

description:
So this place is tucked at the very end of a really awesome area.
The only item we ordered that was great was the gyoza. the salmon moonlight roll and the salmon don were eh. the salmon wasnt the texture we perfer. Id rather go to Mona Lisa or cafe grecco or something like that. 

so not worth the 2 hour bart ride and 20 minute walk. I would have much rather have gone to El Rio for a picnic style dinner and a strip tease. at least the girls who frequent there are cute.
author: Katie F.

description: I love this place. I so will be back. All you can eat sushi for a very reasonable price. Plus the food is really really good. It is a little cramped and service is good. I like the location too, right by little italy. I can't wait to go back.
author: Sarah C.

description:
Forget March Madness, true competition is the 2 on 2 sushi eating challenge that went down this past weekend at Sushi Hunter! As the self-appointed referee, I witnessed enough sushi eating in three hours to suppress any sushi cravings in the short-term. 

The sushi is not the highest quality you will find, but there is sure is a lot of it! All-you-can-eat for $26 to be exact. Half of the group ordered a la carte and opted for the all-you-can-drink option which in retrospect was a good game time decision. 

The rolls on the all-you-can-eat menu are very standard and unoriginal but make sure to order your sushi in bulk! The wait per order was an average 10 minutes but it seemed like eternity, especially when you're trying to referee an eating challenge.  After three hours and 50 sushi pieces per contestant, the wait staff officially cut us off. 

My favorite items on the menu were non-sushi. The edamame, gyoza, kiraage (chicken nuggets), and soups didn't make up $26 worth but having sampled most of the menu options, I'm not sure if I'm in a rush to head back soon.
author: Lan H.

description:
Another place that I have been looking at for years and had been wanting to try for the longest time.

Treated my dad and my GF here for dinner tonight and have to say this is one of the harder reviews I've had to write since I have such mixed feelings about our experience.  We each had the $23.99 all you can eat menu (weekday) special where you can order anything and as much as you like off their special menu (nice variety) with the one condition that you don't waste or you may get charged.

I never should have told my dad that because instead of setting forth on a culinary adventure of discovery and excitedly looking forward to what we were going to order next, he instead sat there worrying and asking who was going to finish the fried zucchini so that we don't get charged.  From there, things only went downhill when our sushi arrived.  The pieces were small which I had no problem with since they were easy to eat in one bite (I figured you can order as much as you want anyway so size wasn't that big a factor).  The fish itself, although not mind blowing, seemed pretty fresh although far from buttery or magical.  Where the sushi really fell flat on it's face, however, was in the rice.  As we ate, he endlessly and relentlessly would not stop b#tching about how bad the sushi was.  He told us that the rice was cooked too hard, the nori tough, and that there was no rice vinegar or mirin in it like proper sushi rice should.  

He went so far as to say that the supermarket sushi at Nijiya or Tokyo Fish was much better.  Not quite what you want to hear when you consider that the only reason you took him there was in an attempt to make him happy and do something nice for him, especially when you know that this cheap sushi dinner is still coming out to over $100.  It got on my nerves so much after a while that I actually told our waitperson this (who actually turned out to also be the manager) when she asked.  Yes, I was so fed up with hearing him complain that I told her his comments on the sushi.  I immediately felt bad, but what can you do?  She was very professional about it and said that sushi is so subjective (I agreed) and told me that it's good to hear input from customers.  It was a good answer and exactly what I would have said if I had been in her shoes.  

This now being far from a magical dining experience, my GF and I proceeded to polish off three large hot sakes (they weren't that large) at $7 each.  I agreed with him on the sushi, but still didn't want to hear it over and over during the meal which only made things worse.  I then proceeded to order three more non-sushi items to go with the earlier appetizers of vegetable and prawn tempura, gyoza, and korokke (potato croquette) that we ordered earlier.  

The chicken kara-age fried chicken was good and the grilled mackerel small, but tasty.  The curry pork tonkatsu cutlet was nicely cooked and actually really good, but the super watery curry dip (WTH?) left me wanting.  There seemed to be no consistency in portion size either...it varied widely depending on the item ordered and...I'm guessing, what it probably cost them.  The chicken kara-age portion was generous, as was the curry pork cutlet, but the above grilled mackerel and the potato croquette were tiny.  When I say croquette, I really mean one croquette as in one small, thin potato croquette (like a McD hash brown, but way smaller) cut in half longitudally with two squiggles of mayo (I hate mayo!)  

As we ate this, my dad saw someone in the next table order ikura (salmon roe) sushi and actually wanted to try it so I went ahead and place one order for him (two pieces).  When the sushi came out, he was really happy and said that they had made it differently this time and that the rice was much better.  He really liked it and so I went ahead and asked for three more orders (six pieces) of ikura sushi for him which he actually enjoyed.  I was impressed that they actually listened and accomodated him.

Afterwards, we all enjoyed green tea ice cream (3 x $1.50) which tasted okay.  He said it was nothing like the fro-yo we had the night before at Moyo's and joked that the portion was so tiny compared with what the birthday girl at another table received.  Their menu was clear  that this was not included and although $1.50 is nothing, I really thought it should have been included with the meal.  

With a good tip, the three all you can eat menus, three large hot sakes, one Diet Coke (for him), and three green tea ice creams came out to over $137.  Granted, $21 of that was sake, but even then, it didn't seem so cheap in the end.  Then again, we did have as much sushi as we wanted and also a wide variety of Japanese appetizer dishes.  The other girls working there were really sweet, too. 

Not sure what to make of this place...on one hand, it seems like a deal, yet on the other hand, it really wasn't.  Like I said earlier, mixed feelings about the experience.  Don't think I'll be back anytime soon.
author: Roy N.

description:
Food was okay for the all you can eat.  They give you a ton of rice with your sushi.  Whatever you get on top of your sushi is very thin or very little.  Was it worthed it?  Nope.  I can get just as full at any Japanese restaurant for the same price if not less.  Nothing special about this place. 

Service was slow getting our order to us.  Each time we order something, its like a 15-20min wait.  Its horrible.  It took us, a group of 4, three hrs to finish eatting.  If you're pressed on time, don't go to this place.  It'll take quite a long time until you are full.  The longer you sit, the rice within your tummy gonna expand making you eat less.
author: Henry T.

description:
Sushi Hunter, round 3!! Notes on Take Out: I came in on my way home after work to order about 4 dishes. The restaurant was half full and the service was pretty slow. That being said everyone working were very nice. I think they hired some new people who are still learning the menu, but helpful and friendly.

The fish was fresh and tasty. I got 2 types of Nigiri and even made the trek home with hot pot stickers, which were still delicious. The Alaska Roll didn't hold up as well, but the Specialty Roll (the Crazy Horse Roll) was still piping hot. 

I will get take out here again, just be more prepared to wait. Sushi is hard to come by in North Beach!
author: Natalie N.

description: Waitress was super rude, food was bland, we tried to chat her up and get her out of her mood but she stuck to her jerk ways.
author: David C.

description:
Cheap. Relaxing. Throw-back.  

What could be better than sharing a steaming bowl of udon brimming with veggies and pretty sushi rolls while listening to great one-hit wonders from the 90's like S Club 7's Never Had a Dream Come True and O Town's Liquid Dream!?  Not much.

The sushi isn't fantastic, but the price is right and the bright colorful lighting is hip!  The service is relatively slow, the parking isn't great (it's north beach) - but the staff is friendly and the sushi is cheap and filling!

Solid go-to if you're craving Sushi, don't have a lot in your wallet, and are in North Beach!

Know Before You Go:
1. They say they have validated parking?
2. Udon here isn't over salted or lackluster - full of veggies, goodies, and very flavorful!
author: Jane L.

description:
Did the trick for a quick dinner, but with so many other options in SF, don't waste your time.

To Sushi Hunter's credit, the staff was very friendly and always ready to refill tea and check in, but, food-wise, it just didn't cut it.

-Hokkigai nigiri was flavorless and had too much rice
-Spicy tuna maki (my personal litmus test) was a pureed mess of tuna that was not especially spicy 
-Negi-hama maki was decent in flavor, but with incredibly differently sized pieces of hamachi in each piece
-Spicy scallop, while spicy, was nothing special - and def not worth $7.50
-Salmon toro sashimi was delightfully buttery, but looked as though it had simply been hacked, not sliced - into weird little squares (wtf?)
We also shared one Kirin and both had tea.

The total was $45. I guess the lesson to this story is that if you just want to get filled up, go there, get the AYCE for $24/person and have at it, but don't go the route Jon and I did and select things individually hoping for quality.
author: Joanna R.

description: ok... this place's service was bad. They were very friendly but they took ages to bring the food out, and once they did they had us waiting 15 minutes for utensils so we could eat the salad standing right in front of our faces, they forgot our plates, they did not bring wasabi or soy sauce for a bit either, and never brought out the green tea we ordered. It took another 15 min to run our check. First time in my life I walk out without tipping. And as a former bartender/waiter that says a lot because I am very very flexible with mistakes in this industry.
author: Sandra C.

description:
$12 all you can drink!?

Couldn't have had a better night with the fellas last night. We downed sushi as if mercury poisoning was 'in', and tossed back sake like belugas.

Meghan P, thanks for letting me know about this incredible deal!

This is the making of a solid wed night tradition.
author: Mike K.

description: I'm glad I found this place yesterday... friendly staff and all you can eat sushi for 25 bucks... the sushi's actually really good too... it's a shame it only apply to the nigiris but then again, I'm being greedy... definitely worth it... I wonder if you can get kicked out for being a cow? I shall find out tomorrow!
author: Nathan D.

description: If I seriously can rate this place with no stars I would do it. Nothing has a taste.. Worst sushi place ever! Don't go there u'll end up regretting it.
author: Mariam B.

description:
seemingly authentic...quaint sushi bar...table seating few...corner tucked...northbeach little italy....menu sportin' typical japanese-american fare....california rolls, nigiri sushi, tempura, teriyaki, udon and such....finding rolls extremely over dense and packed ultra tight with rice...pricing norm at $ten plus/minus per flavored decorated fat rice rolls....neither cheap nor expensive....also, experiencing undercooked, almost raw hard, tempura vegetable....side of bland tempura saucing, "dark water"....finding bento box common...medley of small portioned teriyaki, tonkatsu, etc. with rice, miso 'n' salad....udon looking tastier than most items ordered...

$twenty-five all-you-can-eat from seperate limited menu....observing limited to rolls, nigiri sushi, fried, tempura, etc...rice packed filler items...non-buffet type all-you-can-eat...menu order and wait all-you-can-eat....no sashimi for all-you-can-eat....passing on all-you-can-eat...
author: Hen A.

description:
We came here because bf was craving all you can eat sushi.  Sushi Hunter is good.. not Vegas good, but very good.  Glad the place wasn't crowded.  Its a small intimate restaurant, and the staff is friendly.  They only had one sushi chef, so we had breaks between are all you can eat binges.

They had a good sized menu, with tasty rolls and appetizers and such.  I left stuffed and satisfied.  Very reasonable pricing.  I do wish the dessert was part of the package!
author: Marcia D.

description:
All you can eat! Oink oink oink! 

My roommate had his birthday here a few weeks ago. It was a Tuesday night, so the all you can eat sushi was $22.95. They have a pretty good selection on the menu. There's a variety of appetizers, entrees, nigiri and rolls. The sushi is decent, but nothing to rant and rave about. But I do give them a thumbs up for not overloading their nigiri and rolls with rice. 

I must say the service was pretty damn good....especially since there were 20 of us, and we kept ordering food every 5 minutes. I applaud the two waitresses for putting up with us! 

Here are a couple of picks that I liked: 
-Agedashi tofu 
-Chicken karaage 
-Gyoza 
-Albacore 
-Hamachi 
-Philadelphia roll...we requested this to be deep fried..mmm 
-Spicy scallop roll 
-Udon 
-Wakame 

This place is definitely accommodating for large parties. But parking is a bit of a pain since its in the North Beach area. This made me not want to eat all you can eat for a while. I almost had to be rolled out of the restaurant!
author: Patra I.

description:
I would like to change the name of this restaurant to "Sushi HUNGER".

'Cause if you are really hungry for an unholy amount of raw fish, this is your place.  $24 gets you all of the appetizers, grilled dishes and sushi that you can eat (off of a set menu).  I can hardly believe a deal like this exists in SF, let alone in North Beach.

Now, I would rate the food alone at about 3 stars.  It's not terribly innovative, the presentation isn't particularly artful, but it is good.  However, the price/value relationship earns 1 star all by itself.  And the service was friendly.

Think about what other activities you can do in this city for $24, and having a gargantuan sushi meal is probably not among them.  You could:

- Take a cab almost all the way to the airport
- Buy movie tickets for two, but no snacks
- Go to the Titanic exhibit
- Buy a tiny Betty Crocker EZ Bake Oven-size cake at Whole Foods

On my virgin visit to Sushi Hunter, I put away more sushi than I care to admit.  But I have to give credit where credit is due - it's Daniel W.'s fault that my pants felt uncomfortably tight.  Damn you, Daniel, for luring me into your world of decadence and excess.  Damn you!

Oh, are you gonna eat that last piece of white tuna?
:)
author: Liz S.

description:
BEST sushi I've had in San Francisco HANDS DOWN!!

Seriously.. I didn't expect a whole lot.. and boy was I wrong!!


Toyko Pizza Roll (Mozzarella cheese YUM) +
Japanese Bagel Roll (cream cheese YUM) +
Dragon Roll+
Tiger Eye Roll (salmon, cream cheese, and jalpeno in soy paper)+
Unfilitered Sake =

HEAVEN :)

I didn't try the all you can eat.. but we basically spent just as much on our meal and it was fabulous. By the looks of the menu its all very basic/mediocre rolls, and I always want to try something new. So, my advice.. don't go with the all you can eat.

Our waitress was very nice, but didn't seem to speak English very well so be prepared so ask for WATER several times (4 times in my case) before receiving any.
author: Sarah W.

description: Great service. The staff isn't Japanese but it's pretty good sushi. The fish is fresh and cut well but the rice isn't seasoned properly, too bland. Cooked foods were great. They have a very nice happy hour that is worth doing even if you don't eat sushi.
author: Donald A.

description:
Daniela-san was not very happy with her food tonight.  I came here with the same friend who introduced me to San Jose Taqueria #3 and I am absolutely convinced now, more than ever, that he's making me pay for all the shit I gave him in college.   WTF?
