I thought I was safe since his girlfriend and his friend were also with us, but apparently the guy will stop at nothing to make me pay for all the times I called him an a-hole and treated him like dirt.

I ordered the chicken teriyaki dish because I wasn't really in the mood for sushi.  Best decision of my life apparently (and I've made some good ones).  Ugh!  The chicken was cold and rubbery.  The seaweed salad was ok...not terrible, but nothing to write home to okasan about.   The udon noodle soup was bland, according to the friend's gf.  The tea was lukewarm.  I didn't drink the glass of water put in front of me, but I'm pretty sure it probably tasted like dorm water (i.e. like chlorine).

Osoroshii!!!

Will not return.
author: Daniela L.

description:
One of the best deals in town. Sure, the sushi is not the best you've ever had. But for a good variety of very fresh, made-to-order, all-you-can eat rolls, nigiri, and popular Japanese staples (tempura, udon, teriyaki, donkatsu, chicken karaage, etc.), Sushi Hunter can't be beat.  Unsurprisingly, sashimi is not offered on the all-you-can-eat menu. But there are many other choices for the sushi lover.

For the all-you-can-eat menu, it costs $23 a person from Monday through Thursday and $25 a person Friday through Sunday. The food comes out quickly, service is good. 

This has become a new stand-by restaurant for me and my hungry friends.
author: Jenny K.

description: Outstanding food and service--great all you can eat menu!  We had planned to go to another sushi restaurant that we had found on Trip Advisor on Columbus but it was closed.  We were so happy that Yelp directed us to Sushi Hunter.  We were thus, as a  family, able to share the celebration of my son and his wife's 17th anniversary, enjoying every bite!
author: Kenneth S.

description:
We walked in around 9 pm and there were 2 empty tables and several available seats at the bar. For several minutes, we were observing the personnel passing through and completely ignoring us. Finally, when we waived to the presumed seating hostess (SH) she acknowledged our presence and, when asked if we could take the empty table, mumbled smth. like "let me check with my manager". She then disappeared. We tried to seat ourselves at the bar, but were stopped by a waitress (W) who informed us that "...it would take several minutes to clean it up and that we should wait...". Another few minutes went by, and both the SH and the W reappeared completely ignoring us and doing everything but making any attempt to seat us. Needless to say, we left and had great tapas across the street.

Dear manager, it gives me a geuine pleasure to join the army of yelpers commenting on the atrocious service at your restaurant. I should invite you to my house and teach you how to treat a hungry customer. Until then, I will recommend to all of my sushi-craving friends avoiding Sushi Hunter at all costs.
author: Cook S.

description:
$24.95 for all-you-can-eat sushi and other Japanese entrees!  It's not like one of the gazillion Chinese Buffets in the Tri-City area either-- everything is made to order!  You take a look at the menu (http://www.sushi-hunter.com/menu1.htm), place your orders, and the food comes out within 10 minutes.  If you're still hungry or want to try out more, just keep placing more orders.  We had 11 people and I have no idea how the servers kept up with all of our orders/demands.  

Tips:

1) Make reservations. This place is a magnet for large-parties, so you want to make sure they can accommodate you and your guests. 

2) If you're driving, get there very early!  Parking in North Beach is a bi-atch!  If you get there late, just drive 5 or 6 blocks out from the restaurant and walk!

3) Get the Devil Roll.  It is to DIE for!  I can't find it online, but it should be on the dining room menu.  =)
author: Marilou A.

description: DO NOT GO HERE. Horrible. The music is bumping and drunks are all around. The sushi isn't fresh either..
author: Lucca W.

description:
Traveling to Tokyo two years ago, I ate the best sushi of my life at the Tsukiji fish market so I consider the "all- you- can eat sushi buffet" an oxymoron in the Japanese culinary culture. However, I was pleasantly surprised after my visit to a recent buffet created by owners Hanson and Christy Lau, who presented some unique offerings that made my meal worthwhile. As the stand-alone Japanese restaurant in the rustic Italian district of North Beach, Sushi Hunter quietly sits in the corner of the Powell street hill, surprising patrons daily with a rowdy ambiance.
Ocean blue walls and giant marlins serve as the centerpiece, creating a sea harbor décor. The sushi bar is illuminated with neon sapphire lights to create a sensual mood. Big screen TVs broadcast sporting events while jovial patrons participate in sake festivities. The waiting staff is attentive to refill drinks and to take the customers' next round of order.

The all-you-can-eat sushi bar offers fifty made-to-order items. The menu includes appetizers, cooked entrees, nigiri sushi, and sushi rolls. Sprinkled with sesame, the spinach appetizer is a great starter. Not overwhelmed by any sauces, the natural taste of spinach shines through the dish. With a gelatinous texture, the seaweed salad offers a cool crunch. The miso soup is slightly diluted so an added teaspoon of miso paste would have rounded out the kelp and bonito flakes. Without price as an issue, I ordered a selection of nigiri sushi (served in pairs). Arriving on a black lacquer plate, the sushi displays a myriad of colors, creating an appetizing canvas. Smothered with a slather of teriyaki sauce, the buttery eel could have used a dash of sugar in the sauce. The salt cured mackerel combines a strong savory taste with a rich finish. For a sweet sea crunch, the squid nigiri will do the trick. With a creative spin, the seared tuna flaunts a slightly smoky crust with a sweetly mild interior. Melt-in-your-mouth, buttery yellowtail sets an example of sweet, fresh fish. The Japanese often finish a nigiri meal with tamago (the sweet omelette). Created by layering thin, fried eggs, the combination of pungent eggs, mirin, and sugar ends a great nigiri set. Unlike other all -you-can-eat sushi places, Sushi Hunter serves a reasonable portion of fish to rice ratio.

For the next round, I sampled a few sushi rolls that did not disappoint. Putting a new twist on a classic, the fried California roll contrasts a crunchy tempura crust with a buttery sweetness from the rice and the imitation crab meat. With a shimmering seaweed cast, the shrimp tempura roll delights the palate as it combines chewy seaweed and crispy shrimp. Pan-fried with a chewy skin and crispy brown bottom, the gyoza (Japanese potsticker), was the best appetizer of the night. Cooked al dente, the udon satisfied my comfort food appetite; however, the soup base needed a dash of salt. Fried till golden brown, the chicken karaage is a great Japanese version of the chicken nugget; a quick dunk in soy sauce adds even more flavor. Contrasting the texture from the mackerel sushi, the grilled mackerel features a nutty, savory skin that balances out the flaky, mild meat. Coated with a light batter, the shrimp and vegetable tempura is meant to be dunked ever-so-slightly to sustain crunchiness and prevent a soggy coating. A floral green tea ($1.50 each) refreshes the palate and ends a great feast. For the entire meal, with tax and tip, I spent sixty dollars for two people.

Behind the tandem team of Hanson and Kristy Lau, Sushi Hunter has gone through challenging times. Their previous partner was caught in a money laundering scandal. Despite debts, litigation battles, and the troubled economy from 9-11, the restaurant survived on pure determination. Immigrating from Hong Kong to pursue the American dream, the owners were determined to carry Sushi Hunter through the hurdles. Desiring to differentiate themselves from most Japanese restaurants, the owners chose the Italian eatery row (North Beach) and an all-you-can-eat menu. Sushi Hunter is a great neighborhood restaurant if you're in the mood for an elaborate tasting menu.
author: Rayfil W.

description:
If you're coming to Sushi Hunter to get drunk and eat mediocre sushi on the cheap in a large group, then this place does you just fine. It's Saturday atmosphere is pretty good (its clientele falls under the "just got out of college and drink like I'm still there" category - I'm not judging, I partook) and it's a good place to go with a group interested in some sake bombs.

But the sushi is not good, and the only way you'll be happy with eating it is if you're so drunk that you absolutely need the sodium. Service is fine, and it's in a good location if you're looking to start out your night, but if you're after a fine meal of raw fish, take your business elsewhere.
author: Amanda F.

description:
Definitely my favorite sushi place in the city.  It is not the best sushi, but the all you can eat is fresh and made to order.  I love the seared tuna and the fact that there are tons of non-sushi items like agedashi and wakame.  Service is good. You can basically guarantee that when you order all you can eat they'll forget something, but as long as you ask again you'll get it.  All you can drink sake is awesome/terrible idea.  Not sure I've ever been here without accidentally breaking something. 

Weird side note, one of the waiters recognized me at a Warriors/Mavs playoff games a couple years back.  That won me over.
author: Jesse L.

description: Our organization reserved the restaurant for a banquet and had a blast. The staff was fantastic and really made the experience enjoyable for all of us. The food was tasty and drinks were plentiful. Can't speak to price, but Sushi Hunter definitely made for a fun night.
author: Michael C.

description:
While it's not the best Sushi place I've ever been to, it's a hop, skip, jump from my apartment which gives it an extra star. Plus they're willing to deliver the two and a half blocks when it's raining and I'm too lazy to pick it up.

Rolls are decently priced. Service is abnormally slow sometimes - you have to flag down the waitress to get your water refilled, but still one of the easiest places to grab a quick meal in North Beach.
author: Anna E.

description: Bland mediocre sushi, boots with the fur music bumping, staff eating behind the sushi bar, go somewhere else.
author: Cory M.

description:
If you're like me (a chubby kid who loves sushi), you habitually spend about $50-60 on yourself when you go out for raw fish.  Sushi Hunter's all-you-can-eat deal is spectacular.  Ok, it's not the end all and be all of sushi in the city, but I'll tell you what, it is pretty damn good. It's always fresh, totally melts in your mouth, and comes with some great apps. and sides as part of the deal. 

This place has become my Sunday night hangover ritual. Nothing sops up a deepening, alcohol-withdrawl-fueled depression better than 17 pieces of nigiri, 4 crunchy rolls, 2 orders of Gyoza, a bowl of miso and some edamame. (By the way, that's what I personally ate  last time I went).
author: Benny B.

description:
All you can eat sushi, all you can drink sake for about $45 bucks!

I'm excited about this discovery, but not sure if it's good for me I now know about this. We were beginning a big night, so we decided to forgo the sake special. I love that you can order other Japanese entrees as part of this deal - my favorites were the chicken katsu and the edamane. Our table went crazy for the Udon too. Be prepared for tons of rice with all the sushi pieces (hey, they've got to recover costs somehow) but they're still pretty tasty. The eel rolls were my fave. 

Being a server here must put you on the shortlist for sainthood, but it was still lacking. A couple of our orders were forgotten, and getting our check was a 15 minute process. We'll be back for a night when we can swing the all you can drink sake for sure!
author: Kelly C.

description: I went here last night with my buddy and I must say, it was well worth the journey! We got the all you can eat and we most certainly ate all we could eat! The options for it were extensive and it was all super tasty. We mostly got nigiri which is my favorite. For $25 all you can eat Monday-Thursday, i know i will be going back. The service wasnt amazing, but it wasnt bad at all. They are really friendly, and if you make basic eye contact, they know your still hungry and want some more. Definitely worth a try if your looking for an all you can eat
author: Tyler L.

description:
Date:  November 29, 2008 @ 6:08 PM 

Occasion: Saturday Date Night with Boyfriend.

Rationale:    
I wanted a semi-guilt free food (which means, sushi, in my book) after boyfriend and I stuffed ourselves during Thanksgiving. Thought this was the chance to try Sushi Hunter which I found through Open Table and Yelp.

Venue:  Small Mom and Pop in the heart of North Beach.
               Better described as "All You Can Order and Eat Sushi" for $25.95

Ambiance/Decor:  Minimal and Casual.

Social Scene:  
-  2 young teenagers on a date
-  An Asian family who got hooked up with good stuff, I mean we watched tray after tray of beautiful sushi arrived at their table(Seems like they knew the owner)
-  We missed the two large parties (about 20 each) the staff were setting tables for.

Service:  5 stars for the service. Very attentive and efficient. Our drinks were always filled. The server came to the table a lot to ask if we wanted to order some more from the buffet menu.

Drinks:  Green tea and Diet Coke
                                          
Taste:  Seaweed Salad/Gyoza  
             Chicken Teriyaki/Shrimp Tempura
             Udon (Very tasty actually. I'm not a big fan but it was good.)
             Almost all the nigiris (salmon, mackerel, yellowtail, tako etc.)
             A bunch of rolls

RECOMMEND:  
1. This place is great for big parties, or at least 4 people.
2.  Then, you can order everything on the menu.
3.  It is more fun to share and watch your friends eat tons of sushi.

SKIP:
1.  If you don't eat at lot like me.
2.  If you are expecting superb sushi because you eat their sushi for fun but not for the best quality.
3.  If you expect great sushi rolls, the rolls were skinny and not like what I get from Nijiya market in J-Town.
4. If you hate looking or paying $25.00 for parking,

Tab:  $70.00 for 2 All You Can Eat buffet and drinks, tax and tip

Parking:  $22.50

Overall:  
We were a little disappointed at the place. If we were in North Beach and wanted sushi, we will go to this place but we will not purposely go back given the lack of parking in the area and abundance of very good sushi in the City.  

More About Our Date Night:
The night was beautiful, not too cold. We went to the Italian glass store, admired the pastries at one of the bakeshops but still too full, took in the scene and beauty of North Beach at night.
author: Leah E.

description:
I've always dreamed of all you-can-eat-sushi. Endless sushi presented on fancy platters one after the other..

So I was thrilled when I stumbled upon "Sushi Hunter".

When I entered the first thought that crossed my mind was that this was hands down the most unusual Japanese sushi joint I had ever been in. Pastel and art deco design, flowered curtains and Mod colorful chairs.

BonJovi was playing. 

BonJovi continued singing through out the entire 3 hours we were there on a repeated loop. Odd choice. It seemed like a "Best of" mix because it had all the hits I remember from my childhood. I would have chosen a different kind of background music but it was amusing..

The selection of choices for $22.95 was impressive. Appetizers, hot entrees, Maki sushi, Nigiri and Veggie Sushi Rolls. 

We ordered a bottle of Saki and glanced through the menu. We started off with California Rolls, Crunchy California rolls, Philadelphia rolls and fried Ebi (Cooked shrimp with Avocado)

I was in complete heaven. The wait staff was really attentive. The minute we cleared one platter, she would arrive and take the next order. The service was fast for fresh sushi. One after the other endlesslly until I felt like my sides would burst. 

The rice was perfect. I read about All-you-can-eat Sushi Joints adding an extra layer of thick rice to fill up the customers early and forcing them to eat all the rice before allowing them to continue. That wasn't the case here. The rice was the ideal amount for sushi. Although I don't know what would have happened to us if we *didn't* eat the rice...

At around 9:45 P.M., 15 minutes before closing we requested the check. the waitress accidentally gave us the bill for the table of five across from us. For a moment my heart stopped and I gasped at the price. Until I realized the error and the table next to us made the bill exchange while laughing. 

My friend and I devoured about 15 rolls between the two of us. I can't remember the last time I ate THAT much sushi in one sitting. 

If you're a sushi-lover, I really recommend checking this restaurant out. when it comes to all-you can-eat sushi, this restaurant is on the affordable end of the spectrum. I can't afford to go every night though. I really wish i could..
author: Daisy F.

description:
I'm seeing poor reviews.
I think there are people who don't understand how to handle this place.
In order to completely imbibe the true essence of Sushi Hunter, a small group of people MUST do the following:
 
First, become heroes by neutralizing several rounds of sake bombs.
Pound the table and shout across a peaceful dining hall full of guests.
Arm-wrestle the chef (make sure he removes his fishy glove)
Take excessive pictures of whichever hero passes out face down on the cement in front of the establishment (it happened to be Kevin last time).
Sincerely apologize and overtip everyone in the building.
 
From then on, it's up to you to decide how and where in San Francisco you would like to urinate.
It's your choice, you can pass out on any park bench or street corner in the city.
You can have potato sack races in Washington Square Park just down the street.
Or you can ask innocent civilians to take a group photo with you and then start falling all over the ground laughing hysterically.
 
The ball is in your court.
 
Bottom line.
Good sushi.
Fun staff.
Harry the chef.
Decent service.
Sake Bombs.
 
The San Francisco chapter of The Sake Heroes definitely recommends Sushi Hunter.
author: Daniel J.

description: Hot and cold roll....yum. Service was quick and the reataurant is nice and quiet.  Cool atmosphere.
author: Kristin D.

description:
Oh $11 all you can drink sake... You always seem like such a great idea at night and bring me so much pain in the morning. That being said, I will continue to enjoy you and ignore the past hangovers.

This is a great place for groups because it is never crowded. And I really like taking visitors here. The sushi is just fine and the All You Can Eat Option is a fun change of pace for a dinner out. If I was looking for the city's best sushi, I wouldn't come here. But I'm okay with sticking to the specialty rolls and getting my money's worth on the booze. It's a great deal and makes heading to the North Beach bars afterwards a lot cheaper!
author: Jennie H.

description:
Not quite as a good as Sushi on North Beach right down the street (basically the only other sushi option in the neighborhood) but pretty good overall. I didn't find the rolls to be inventive at all (I don't think this is really what they're going for anyway), but what they do do is good and pretty close to average. 

We didn't do the all you can eat, drink thing but it might be fun. 

Wasn't too crazy when I was there and can't imagine it gets packed so it could be a good place for a larger group.
author: Derek B.

description: We love this place! The sushi is delicious and the service is great. The decor is pretty cool too!
author: Virgil and Jessica J.

description:
Cantonese-owned, but they survive as the only sushi bar in North Beach.  Sit at the bar, hiphop bumpin' in the background, and you'll see the sushi chef toss the fish in and out of the glass case like hunks of meat.  They skimp on the fish, with the nigiri sliced thin enough that it's practically draped over irregular of balls of rice.  Even the rolls have too much rice & not enough flavor...

-- Crazy Horse
Sad average-sized roll with mismatched ingredients & barely any fried tempura goodness on the outside.  Totally not worth $11.

Acceptable:
Norway Roll - Strong flavor of mackerel paired against equally sharp punch of ginger w/sweetness from a bit of green onion.

Butterfish - Similar to yellowtail in its rich buttery flavor

I am unimpressed:
Dinner for 2 = $37
author: Christina J.

description: No idea what ppl are talking about if they  don't like this place. This place is legit. All u can eat includes nigiri. The selection is great and fresh and not expensive.  Plus the waitresses are hot
author: Will B.

description:
3.5

One of the only things that brings this place down is parking.  Maybe on any non social night it's not hard to come by, but otherwise it's rather difficult in my opinion.  If parking doesn't bother you then maybe add another .5 star?  Service was decent-slow considering when I went here it was for a bday party that took up 1/2 the restaurant (so not sooo much their fault).  Anyways, maybe I'd come back when it's not so busy since the food was ok enough to come back for, especially all you can eat = win.
author: Brian Y.

description:
Although I went there to check out the $22.95 "all-you-can-eat deal," I ended up just getting a sashimi dinner set for about $18 bucks instead.

"All-you-can-eat" is great for people with a larger appetite so they can chow down a couple of rolls plus terriyaki-type dishes. I decided against it since I'll can only stomach one roll and maybe one more thing. So it's not worth it for me. 

I was hoping that the $22.95 deal would include sashimi, but it that menu is mostly sushi rolls (6 pieces) and cooked food.

Menu and prices aside, the sashimi is quite fresh at Sushi Hunter. The staff was courteous and attentive. I also liked their stronger than average wasabi!
author: Tommy T.

description:
Call off the hunt - an excellent Japanese restaurant in North Beach is found.  Within walking distance of Club Fugazi (Beach Blanket Babylon), this fairly small Japanese restaurant did not disappoint.

I made reservations via opentable.com and we were seated immediately upon arrival.  There was a large raucous group which really overwhelmed the fairly small space, but the staff kindly offered to move us as far away from them as possible.  It was still quite loud, but I can't imagine groups like this are the norm here.  Since we couldn't hear each other, the focus was on eating.  The food was excellent!  We did not opt for the all-you-can-Hoover menu, but instead went for Bento boxes so we could sample various things.  Quite yummy!  The green tea ice-cream was the only thing I could've done without (aside from the party goers).  It was actually the worst green tea ice-cream I've ever had - and I am somewhat of an aficionado in this area.  It really tasted like frozen brown sugar.

The staff was kind and attentive, food excellent, and I'll have to get back to you on the sound level.  I have an appointment with my audiologist later this week.  Or, at least, I thought that's what they said.
author: Margo G.

description:
I like this place well enough but Sushi 85 in Mountain View is nearer and has a much bigger selection and is just as fresh, and in the case of fish roe fresher taste/quality of fish. That being comparing the AYCE food coma menu's to each other. One thing Sushi Hunter does better though is including some of the started stuff like Saba Shioyaki, Agedashi Tofu, Wakame, and Gyoza as well in the AYCE menu. If I was just in a sushi mood I'd easily pick 85 over Hunter, but if I was 'hunting' for more variety (and didn't care about the extra drive the The City) Sushi Hunter would be a better choice. 

Park in the City Parking near the cop shop and walk one block down and two over
author: Valerie F.

description:
Finding a teeny tiny parking spot in North Beach after circling for what felt like an eternity: $0 

Great company: $0 

Copious amounts of mind blurring sake: $14 

Decent all-you-can-eat sushi: $25 

Meeting the friends of the guy you're dating for the first time: Priceless
author: Julia N.

description:
ATMOSPHERE: Sushi Hunter looks like a beat down dump from the OUTSIDE, but once you enter the restaurant, you'll notice the well-kept bar along with the 42" plasma TV that is always kept on mute because of the AWESOME music they play in the background.  Sushi Hunter plays Pop and R&B songs from the mid-90's! Who else does that?! I tell you who...NOBODY!!!

SERVICE:  ONE OF THE BEST!!! The waitresses remember you if you go there enough, which is a very rare characteristic to find nowadays, which makes me sad to admit!  They're CONSTANTLY refilling your tea and water without asking and always making sure EVERYTHING is going well!

PRICE: Like every other sushi restaurant, but when you taste the quality of their sushi, you'll come to appreciate their normal pricing, because the flavor in each roll is UNMATCHABLE, which warrants higher pricing!

MENU: 28 basic rolls along with 26 specialty rolls!

ROLLS:

Sake Maki (salmon): Although this may seem like any other basic roll, do not be fooled by it's simplicity, because this is THE BEST basic roll I have ever tasted.  I, like most people, believe sushi is BEST-SERVED cold, but Sushi Hunter breaks away from this tradition by doing something to this roll.  I cannot describe it and figure out what Sushi Hunter did, but whatever they did, IT WORKS! It's almost as if Sushi Hunter lightly warms the roll before serving it, because once you put it into your mouth, it pretty much MELTS in your mouth.  The roll is BUTTERY SMOOTH that literally MELTS in your mouth.  TRY IT! (5 stars)

Tekka Maki (tuna): Another basic roll that is best eaten and finished right when it is served.  Like I said for the Sake Maki, it just MELTS in your mouth.  Another MUST TRY! (5 stars)

Lion King Roll (Imitation crab meat inside topped with salmon and special sauce, oven toasted)  It's OVEN-TOASTED! Enough said! Anything oven-toasted comes out mouth-watering!  (4 stars)

Rocky Roll (tempura flour crunch and imitation crab meat inside topped with BBQ eel and avocado):  2 UNIQUE things here.  1. No tempura needed in this one; they simply use the crunchy parts of tempura.  2. No use of teriyaki eel, instead they barbeque it! So with those differences, Sushi Hunter serves THE BEST DRAGON ROLL! (2nd: Sunny Sushi  3rd: American Sushi House)  Along with the two aforementioned characteristics that makes this the BEST DRAGON ROLL, Sushi Hunter does not drown the roll in sauce causing the crunchy bits to become soggy.  (5 stars)

CONCLUSION: I have tasted sushi rolls from dozens of different Japanese restaurants.  I have spent a large sum of money trying to find the ONE PLACE I can call my FAVORITE Japanese restaurant.  So after my search in the cities of San Mateo, Millbrae, San Bruno, Daly City, South San Francisco, and San Francisco, after I have used gallons of gas driving, and after I have spent hundreds of dollars trying out different rolls, I can say with CONFIDENCE that SUSHI HUNTER is THE BEST and therefore MY FAVORITE Japanese Restaurant!  Hopefully with this said, it will warrant your curiosity to try out Sushi Hunter!
author: Matthew L.

description: How does this place have only 3 stars? All you can eat sushi that's actually good for 30 bucks?! What more can you want. And I'm not just talking sushi, I'm talking edame, sashimi, other apps, a variety of rolls, all made to order! I've had some bad experiences with all you can eat sushi places that make your tummy very very sad. This is not one of them. The only thing is that they want you to finish everything you order so make sure you can finish everything you get. The wait is a bit long, especially on the weekends, but this place is the bomb. My hubby can eat a lot of sushi so it can get a bit pricey at other restaurants, so this little gem is fab for us. LOVE LOVE LOVE Sushi Hunter.
author: Hanan H.

description:
My son can put away the sushi, as can I.  When you've got a 14 year old with an appetite for sushi, Sushi Hunter, with its all-you-can eat special, is the place to go.  The food is fresh, it's a super deal, and the service is fine.

Beware the late weekend all-you-can-drink bridge and tunnel idiots, though. They can turn the entire restaurant into a drunken frat party in under ten minutes. Ugh.  The weekends seriously draw a weird clientele. I watched a girl come in, sit down, take her shoes off, and wipe her bare feet with her f**king napkin.  WHAT??  Stick to the week nights.
author: Jamie C.

description: Pretty good for AYCE, I suppose.  I like Nara Sushi's AYCE better.  It's w/e.
author: Erika C.

description: Had not been here in about 10 years, but in the last 6 weeks have been back 3 times!  They have an awesome all you can eat menu with over 60 items with choices from Tempura to Sushi, for $25 it is an awesome deal.  Their Gyoza is really good. They bring it to the table which is nice but service can be slow on the down side.  All in all if you are in North Beach and want Sushi this is the place to go!
author: Amber w.

description: Went here about 2-3 weeks ago.  I LOVE Sushi but the food here leaves MUCH to be desired...  As in better sushi...  LMAO.   It was like Chinese buffet sushi...  Mostly small mediocre rolls lacking in flavor.  I think the unlimited sake was like $12...  that was kinda cool.  The music was loud and made the atmosphere more enjoyable but did not make up for the so-so food.  I will NOT be returning.  BLECH.
author: Hello.kitty.kat S.

description: Though I still love the place, I have to downgrade a bit based on my latest visit.  First, they kept bugging me about what I wanted to drink as I was waiting for some friends to arrive.  Second, the tuna sashimi on this Monday was an unnatural red that looked like some plutonium got loose in the restaurant.  It tasted ok, but was a bit disturbing to the party.  As the local, I felt obligated to eat most of the order.  In all, my most recent meal was still very enjoyable, but can't give top rating anymore.  Gyoza still great and this new item they have on the buffet menu, the "devil roll",  that is a slightly fried spicy tuna roll was very nice.
author: Marc S.

description:
Normally I would not think of going to North Beach for sushi, and to be honest, I was just walking home wanting sushi.  

I actually went here instead of sushi on north beach (which I know to be good) JUST so I could yelp about it. 

The prices are reasonable.  But it was the WORST edamame I have ever, and the wakame was a bit greasy.  The sushi was adequate.  

As other reviews mention, if you are looking for great prices, this place is great, but not great if you are looking for great sushi.
author: Amme P.

description:
HEY! Sushi Hunter! Turn down the temperature on your beer cooler!

I had a pretty good experience here, but it seems like it is probs kinda hit or miss. We had a surprisingly good spicy tuna roll- totally fresh, no complaints at all! And some type of yummy gringo roll, perhaps the "crazy horse?" It had some darn good sauce.

Service was good, the clientele was cool, there were cute children frolicking about- my beer was slightly warm though.

And the whole thing was like 23 bucks. Can't really complain about that, and since it's right around the corner from my girl Annie's house, I'm sure I'll be there again.
author: Katie H.

description: Sushi Hunter is a good Sushi spot by North Beach! Food was good, Sushi was good and the people and atmosphere were good! Our server (Alyson) was awesome! I already have my favorite Sushi spots and Sushi Hunter just got added on my list!
author: Russelle A.

description:
I was THIS close to giving it 4 stars for the sake of how drunk we got off of the all you can drink sake.  But I gave the food 2 stars, sake 4 stars, and I guess 3 was just right.

Came here on Saturday night to grab dinner and drinks before heading to Cobb's.   We got there around 6:30pm, which isn't dinner rush, and there were plenty of seats, but still there were some large groups already there. 

The BF and I, never had all you can eat sushi, but what really sold us  was the all you can drink Sake. 

Ordered some appetizers, some teriyaki and rolls.  Came in like 15 minutes. Not shabby on timing. The appetizers which was really the miso soup, and seaweed salad was good (but you REALLY CANT mess up basic miso, and cold seaweed salad).

The rolls were meh, skimpy on the ingredients, heavy on the rice, BUT its all you can eat... so I understand. The rolls tasted all kinda the same, since rice dominated it.  Tempura was good, not soggy or to heavy on the batter. Chicken teriyaki... umm my bf ate it up, but it was meh to me.

The sake KEPT on flowing! They were not shady in refilling our sake! I mean we must have went through (and im not kidding), 10 of them!  And we started to drink a little with our wonderful server, and he ended up getting shots of the GOOD sake from the back for us.

Second time, we ordered more food to soak up some of the sake we had consumed. And this was the breaker =(  It took 30 minutes to 45 minutes!  I mean, we order some very basic stuff, like edamame!

Given the restaurant got a LITTLE bit more fuller, still 30- 45 minutes?? At that time we had to leave to head to Cobb's, got the check... THEN our food finally arrived!  By that time, with the delay of food intake, we felt full.

I guess thats how they make money.  Overall, what did it was that we consumed soo much sake that it was ended up being worth it. 

I would say great for drinkers, and for ppl that dont have big of a taste for GOOD sushi.  But to be honest.. yes I will probably be back again.... for the sake...
author: Deanna T.

description: Came here for all-you-can-eat sushi and thoroughly enjoyed it!  The sushi is definitely not the best I've ever had, but it's decent, and they also include a lot more non-sushi items than most all-you-can-eat sushi places.  They had teriyaki beef and chicken, chicken katsu, curries, etc. so for that I thought it was worth the price.  The staff was also great, and we never waited long for any of our items.
author: Kelly G.

description:
I'm reviewing only the Bento Boxes, FYI..can't say how good the sushi is..

--bottom line..skip the bento box either way...boxes come with miso soup, salad, white rice and choice of 3 sides (chicken, steak, tempura, eggroll, gyoza etc)

--the biggest problem I have is the portion size of the chicken teriyaki..I've had a lot of bento boxes and seriously, it's a slap to my face when they give you literally 5 small pieces of chicken!! I'm dead serious..most place give you at least twice that amount if not more! for 14.95 dinner, it's a total rip

--that's my main complaint..the gyoza was okay but I prefer mine to be more crispy...tempura pretty good..rice is rice but not piping hot

--staff was sorta slow but did pick up towards the end

--service was friendly and clean bathrooms helps..it's kind of mean with the 2 stars so i'm going with 2 3/4 stars if that's worth anything to people out there
author: James K.

description:
Go here for value and for Japanese favorites. The sushi buffet is good but not great, but the side dishes included in the buffet are great. Great gyoza, tasty tempura, wonderful wakame, eggcelent eggrolls. 
If you want fancy rolls, order off the menu or go elsewhere.
author: jacob s.

description:
Another Chinese sushi place with a touch of cheap night club. But were in the city so the $25 deal is not all too bad. You get what you pay for.
Three small stars from me.
author: Jesper W.

description:
Food:    -5stars (minus 5 stars)
Service: 4 stars

I avoided this place for a long time because you can feel, as a Japanese, Sushi here wouldn't be good by just looking at the restaurant name.  Why I came in here then? 
2 of my non-Japanese friends suggested that this place is very good.... and I knew they like sushi so I trusted their suggestion and I thought I was missing out of something because of my prejudice. 

Unfortunately, my instinct was right. Sushi here was so bad. It was edible but it was really just that. 

One thing I like about this restaurant... the waitresses were very attentive and nice.
author: Wakaknee J.

description:
My overall experience here wasn't too bad. My friend and I ordered several sushi rolls with the recommendation of the waitress, who was very kind and attentive to us. 

I liked the Dark Rainbow roll a lot. As far as quality and taste of sushi, it was decent, but not spectacular. Portions I don't believe live up to their price. 

Not a bad place to go, if you are around the North Beach area and want some sushi nearby. Otherwise I think I've had better.
author: Catherine O.

description:
I wish I could give Sushi Hunter two different ratings, one for eat-in and another for delivery. Eating in is great; solid food, good service, excellent prices. Delivery, on the other hand, is a nightmare. 

The first time I ordered, it took TWO HOURS for my food to arrive. After an hour, I began calling the restaurant. The woman who picked up said the delivery person got lost (my place is a few blocks away from the restaurant) and that they'd be there soon. Thirty minutes passed and I called back. She said she'd check where the delivery person and get back to me, though I never heard from her again and the restaurant stopped answering its phone after that. This week, I decided to give delivery another chance, figuring the first time was just a fluke. When I place my order I was told delivery would take 45-55 minutes. An hour and fifteen minutes later I called the restaurant. The woman who answered said the delivery person was on her way. Another fifteen minutes passed - nothing. I called back yet again and the woman said she'd call and find out where the delivery person was and get back to me. Again, I never heard back from her. I tried calling back to cancel my order in favor of ordering a pizza, but the line was busy for the next 15 minutes straight. Yet again, a full two hours after I placed a simple order, my food arrived. 

While I'll likely go back to Sushi Hunter for eat-in, I will never again order delivery from them.
author: Rachel N.

description: Food besides sushi is actually better. The $28 AYCE is a bit pricey for what they offer.
author: Jj M.

description:
I took my honey here the other day, because I'm always on the lookout for new Japanese restaurants, and I heard they do all you can eat sushi. I wasn't sure what I was expecting, but it wasn't what I got at Sushi Hunter - and I mean that with the best possible intent.

I've been to a few All-You-Can-Eat sushi places, and they have always been done one of two ways: Either you select from the boats going around the bar, which are usually filled with mainly things you don't want. OR it's buffet style, and you have no idea how long anything has been out, and the rice being a little firm isn't helping your thoughts on it.

Sushi Hunter does AYCE in an entirely new and much more awesome way. You get a menu with a selection of items that include nigiri, maki, appetizers, teriyaki - pretty much all the mainstays of any sushi restaurant, and get this... You order as you go. Want a miso soup, some gyoza, oshitashi, tempura and a hamachi nigiri the first round - great! Second round, maybe some more gyoza, some salad, a couple rolls - no problem! Third round (if you can make it that far)... and on and on. They bring it out to you just as though you were ordering from a normal menu and paying for it ala carte, so it's always as fresh as whenever you first order it, so why not order a little at a time?

Their service is fantastic - our server was very attentive, and smiled the entire time we were there. The food was decent - again with the "typical mid-range of a casual Japanese place." I'd definitely go back if I felt like stuffing myself on sushi at a fixed cost.

For the record, for two of us on the AYCE menu with a bottle of sake, and a 20% tip, we spent $85. Not bad considering how bloated we were when we left.
author: Stefani P.

description:
Threw an event here and the staff was AMAZING!!

Loved them. They were so excited and into it. Not sure how the place/food is on a regular bases. But, April 24th it was fantastic!!

The chef was thrilled with the amount of people that showed up and hooked us up with lots of SAKE! yum.

They know how to run a good business!! :-)
author: Art A.

description:
I always wanted to come eat here for their ALL YOU CAN EAT!  So.. I did last week.

Went with a big group and we all got all you can eat.  We stayed for about 2 hours and never been that full in my life. The fish is fresh and all the rolls were really good especially the Devil Roll.  

I didn't eat all day just so i can save room for this meal and it was worth it!

ONLY thing I didn't like..was the fact that they put hella (yeah i just said hella) rice in the nigiri!! We had to find other ways of disposing the rice so we don't get charged a fee.... shhhhh
author: Tiffany L.

description:
I will give this place 1 star for the super nice waitress I have had here quite a few times (even when I used to take out she wanted to chat it up and was so sweet). I will give one more star simply because there aren't really any sushi places in North Beach, so they really have nothing to compare to, ya know?

However, I did used to come here all the time, as I live in North Beach and needed a neighborhood sushi spot. My roommate and I got it to go for dinner and to be honest it was not good at all, very fishy in fact. I was very disappointed, since then I haven't been coming here anymore. Just a heads up...
author: Sara L.

description:
All I can eat? Ohhh yeah! I order tons of salmon sushi along with some gyoza, edamame, seaweed salad, spinach (dig on the spinach- try it!) and some rolls too. I think I definitely eat more than my money's worth here. The fact that you can get apps AND sushi is really nice. I like being able to order so many different things!

Note: as probably expected, you're not techinically allowed to order all-you-can-eat as well as from the regular menu at the same table.

Oh, it's also walkable, right on Wash. Sq....sometimes I roll home...so full...mmm...
author: Diane S.

description:
If you're like me (a seriously lazy, North Beach area resident who is cool with average tasting, decently priced sushi), you'll like it. 

Why? 

They'll deliver to your lazy ass if you live in North Beach! Yay for delivery!
author: Baby Bear G.

description:
i almost always regret going to this palce, but, alas, its the only sushi joint in north beach that stays open late.

i also always feel kind of rushed when eating here.

their rolls are okay, but just okay and i find the interior boring and pretentious.

there is plenty to not like about this place and i suggest, if they would like to stay in the hood, that they pay some much needed attention to major details of their business...
author: Daniel H.

description:
My cousins suggested this restaurant after they tried it (they found it on Yelp!). When I heard it was an all-you-can-eat, I expected mediocre (at best) sushi and I was surprised at the quality! 

First of all, there were 18 of us and we waited about 10 minutes for our table - not bad considering it was a Friday night. Then the menus came out for the all-you-can-eat... I thought it was going to be buffet style so this was great cuz they make the sushi fresh for you. The menu included appetizers like gyoza, wakame, salad, udon, miso soup; entrees like tonkatsu, curry katsu, fried makarel; rolls (about 10 or so); and nigiri sushi of all sorts. And even better: there was enough variety that even I (8 months pregnant) had a good choice of sushi (the sashimi looked sooooo fresh and, according to everyone, tasted good too! Sigh, after the baby comes we'll go again!)

The service was good in the beginning, but, because our party was so big, they started mixing up our orders and gave us seconds of previous items. Also, they took a while for certain orders - had to keep reminding them about the order. But they did let us stay as long as we wanted and we never felt rushed. In fact, we did loiter until closing time.... =P Yet they never kicked us out, even after we paid!

The only item that was a bit disappointing was the Kentucky roll: fried chicken with lettuce. A bit dry. 

Overall, pretty good all-you-can-eat and I'd definitely go back!
author: Felicia S.

description:
After a rowdy day at the North Beach festival, my friends and I pulled ourselves together for the infamous all you can eat sushi special at Sushi Hunter ($25). There is a limited list of rolls and they insist on family style. The sushi was mediocre and after our first round, the service definitely dropped off and slowed--my theory to make us disinclined to stay. 

The menu they provide for the all you can eat special is deceiving. Not everything is included so your bill will be more than you expect. 

There is also an all you can drink saki special (sapporo not included) for $12 that would be fun before you head out for the night.
author: Jennifer W.

description:
So judging by the strain of bad reviews prior to mine, I can see why this place was pretty much empty at ~7:30PM on a Saturday. My friend had heard good things about this all-you-can-eat dinner and we were worried about having to wait so we called to make reservations. Needless to say, it was completely unnecessary.

Service was pretty slow considering how empty the place was. Be sure to order more when you're halfway done with your current plate or you'll have to wait hungry for awhile longer. Both the nigiri and rolls are too much rice and not enough fish. I know their objective is to stuff you at minimal cost, but it really took away from the flavor/quality of the sushi and made it not worth the money IMO.

I give this place an extra star for the seared tuna which i was devouring pretty quick while my friends made multiples rows of salmon nigiri disappear ridiculously fast. Though that was probably more because we were super hungry.

We pretty much starved ourselves all day looking forward to this, passing up clam chowder @ Fisherman's Wharf :( F me for being too lazy to lookup this place myself before coming!
author: Tom Y.

description: This place is cool. Not as cool as the decor would propose, but what can u do. We went for a buddies birthday and everyone in the whole place sang and drank with us. It is definitely a place for the younger crowd as the food wasn't above PAR and the service wasn't either. It's your typical college town sushi/booze place, but we aren't in a college town...the thing is because it's that kind of vibe, it is cheep so younger kids can go get their jollies there for the dime on the dollar.I got the Dragon roll, which is a safe bet at any sushi joint, which didn't dissappoint.
author: Danny S.

description:
$26 all you can eat sushi-- made to order. 

The usual all-you-can-eat sushi places are more like smash and grab places.  Everything is behind a sneeze-guard and you grab what you want.  So I thought this was an great combination, you get custom rolls that you order on the spot.  not some sketchy food that's been sitting out for, god knows how long....

However, one point escaped me.  made to order requires time.  I went with a really large group because it was my friends birthday and the food came out really slow because they were not really prepared to serve the restaurant *and* our party.  The food was decent, nothing really spectacular to call out-- just ok decent.  Altho, there's a lot of rice in each roll, so you really dont get your $26 worth of sushi-- imho, i didnt think i got my $26 worth of sushi.....

however, I will definitely go back during weekday when the price is slightly lower and with a smaller group (4 or less)-- just to see how it's different with a smaller group
author: kate y.

description:
I literally just got home frm Sushi hunter after one of the most interesting experiences of my life.

I think, I cant be positive, but I dont think my waitress spoke English or Japanese. She was confused the whole time, messed our order about 7 times (for all you can eat) and forgot the other half of our order. She was very sweet but holy crap when you order Nigiri and you get an order of teriyaki chicken... seriously. I mean seriously, come on now.

THE food was fabulous. Fish was fresh, cant go wrong with the miso, the house salad was a tad nasty, and the egg rolls were the shit. I will go back any day of the week to stuff myself of delicious sushi and miso soup.

(excuse my spelling... I had a little bit too much sake at dinner...hehehe)
author: Nancy B.

description:
I know NOTHING about sushi. But I do know that if it's not good, my brain wakes from its beery slumber and sends messages to my stomach, messages that sound something like,

"You are eating big hunks of raw fish, stupid white boy. Stop it or I'll make everything go backwards!"

To this date, no thinly-veiled threats from brain to belly at Sushi Hunter. Just fishy goodness mixed with sticky rice and eaten with clever little wooden sticks. Those crazy  Asians! What will they think of next? Maybe some day all our cars will be stylish and fuel-efficient... ah, to dream...
author: Brock D.

description:
We go here for the all you can eat japanese food: sushi, tempura, gyoza, noodles and more!  Not only that, the sushi is made to order so it's not sitting on a revolving belt going around forever!

Value 5 stars
Food 4 stars
Decor 2 stars

I'll put up with the decor and noise since the value and food more than make up for it.  Make a reservation so you don't have to wait for a table.
author: Jade S.

description: Where is the fish?!?! We ordered the all you can eat menu and the rolls had no fish!!! The restaurant smells like fish, and not the good smell.
author: Mandy G.

description: $23 for a sushi buffet doesn't sound too bad, but the buffet menu was very limited. The fish was fresh; however, I wish they had offered sashimi. All that rice just filled me up too quickly. The gyoza was my favorite, tempura was crispy (and oily), agedashi tofu was average, wakame salad got a bit salty towards the bottom of the bowl, chicken anything was terrible. The chicken katsu, the chicken karaage - what mean were they using?
author: Jonas T.

description:
I went here for an eating contest. My friends and I brought a scale and measured our weights before and after eating. 

Starting weight 190lbs. So we began eating. Mounds and mounds of sushi, an hour rolls by. Around an hour and a half in I'm starting to feel sick. Not because of fullness, but because I am starting to detest the taste of fish and eel. My fellow contestants began to feel the same. I hopped on the scale. 200lbs. 

I ate fucken 10 lbs of sushi. Literally. The prize? I didn't have to pay. Not like it would have mattered. My cut of the bill was only 30 bucks.
author: F B.

description:
Sushi Hunter gets points for the name alone, but also for their modest prices in a North Beach restaurant culture of lunacy-based meal pricing. Then, more points awarded for being a cozy all-purpose destination that's just as good for a date as it is a drinking spot as it is a perfect table for one when you just feel like some Futo Maki.

I'm no learned sushi scholar, but SH's sushi is very tasty, quick, and always really fresh (even on nights when no one is in there [seriously, one time it was just me and a friend sitting alone in there, munching away and gulping hot sake all night] or when they're very busy).

Then, disagree with me here if you want, but i also give Sushi Hunter another +50 points for employing a hostess calibrated to the same seemingly-unattainable cuteness wavelength of baby rabbits.

So it is written, and so it is at Sushi Hunter.
author: Dustin K.

description:
I gotta give this place 5 stars cuz it's all you can eat and drink for $35 bucks.  I spent two and a half hours here with some friends ordering plates upon plates of sushi and about 10 bottles of sake.  I was surprised to be able to choose from anything on their menu.  It was truly barbaric.

The fish strips are a bit thinner and smaller than in classic Japanese cuisines, but it's all you can eat, c'mon, anyone can understand that. 

The beef teriyaki was awesome.  The chicken karaage was super awesome.  Spicy tuna rolls were awesome.  All the usual hamachi, salmon, and seared maguro were all awesome.  

I'm definitely bringing everyone I know to this place!

J
author: John M.

description: This place is great. The service was excellent and friendly and the fish quality was very good. All you can eat sushi with a large selection for 25$ is worth it.
author: Will J.

description:
On the weekends people come to get wastoid on all-you-can-drink sake. When I was there a couple on a date was unintentionally but literally shouted out of the restaurant by two large parties (one of whom I may or may not have been a part of) getting hyphy on a Friday.

They have an all-you-can-eat sushi deal too, which isn't bad but about what you'd expect from all-you-can-eat sushi. Save room for the Mediocre Roll, it's a house specialty. The staff is cool about ordering though, even from large parties, so they're not at all annoyed when you're cramming it in like Jeremy Piven.

It's fun if you're out to indulge your carnal appetite like a Roman statesmen, but if you want a quietish place for quality soosh I'd probably head elsewhere. Noise levels approach the bombing of Dresden.

Also the name is stupid.
author: Trav W.

description:
Went here for all you can eat with some rowdy friends.  I like a good challenge, but having to scream at a waitress for attention to maximize on an AYCE is not one of them.  

The food itself was fine for an AYCE.  Of course, the menu is limited so I can't speak to the dishes not on the AYCE menu, but basically I would never pay for anything I did eat were it not part of a gorge-yourself menu.  We had all the staples: tuna, spicy tuna, salmon, scallop, shrimp, some hot dishes, etc... For better quality, hit up Ace in the Marina (I know, I know, sorry...) or Miyabe... Blowfish too.  So quality-wise, I got what I paid for.  

But the service... THEY owe ME for that.  Everyone knows how AYCE works - I come in quietly.  I browse the menu as if contemplating ordering something legit, but you and I both know what I'm here for.  I probably reek of booze, but I'm maintaining.  "I think we'll have the all-you-can-eat menu, please."  You nod, collect the menus, maybe judge silently, but the contract has been signed.  You walk away, and come back with our first - of what you know to be many - rounds of fish.  You might snicker here and there about the over-fried roll we're leaving barely-touched in the middle of the table, but you keep bringing us more of the other things we order.  When we're about to re-gift everything you've just fed us, you ask politely the question the answer to which we should have given several rounds ago - "yes, we are done."  We pay, you don't call in the morning, and we walk by from then on like it never happened.

BUT NO SUSHI HUNTER, THAT'S TOO MUCH FOR YOU ISN'T IT!?!?!?!  

I don't know if this is the kind of restaurant that likes to be smacked around a little, and smacks a little back, but I don't like fighting to get food.  I CAME HERE to get fat.  I CAME HERE because I want a stream of food so endless that when my stomach runs out of space it starts diverting spicy tuna to my heart.  The default should be "Bring these guys more food."  Don't they know how hard it is to get up and flag waitresses down when you're engaged in this kind of feat?  Vicious.  Anyway, given the un-attentive service I'll look elsewhere next time I need gluttony in my life, but it was worth a shot.  Somethings were never meant to be, Sushi Hunter.
author: Jake D.

description: The sushi here is good and I like their teriyaki plate. The environment is nice too, a little too dark and cold sometime, but not bad other than that.
author: Young N.

description: Save some room if you plan to eat the "all you can eat sushi" over here. It's worth it. The sushi is good and all that stuff, but I loved that mackarel the most. I probably could've eaten 5 of that alone. I thought the Chicken Karaage was pretty good too. Edamame is usually served a little bit cold at other Japanese restaurants, but it was warm and a bit salty here. Different, but not in a bad way. The wait service and general ambiance of the place is good. I'm surprised there isn't more people eating here.
author: Gerard Y.

description:
This place is known for the all you can eat sushi., which normally seems like a bad idea from the start.  But the fact that you got to choose off a special menu and the sushi was made to order seemed like this may work out after all....

Wrong.  All you can eat = all you can stand to eat, or all they will bring you when they finally: a.  make it back to your table or b. remeber what you ordered.

The prices were pretty cheap, but this was definitely a case of you get what you pay for... wouldn't go back if it were the only sushi in the city.  No thank you, I'll hunt my own.
author: Sara Ann S.

description:
For an all you can eat place, I find sushi hunter to be pretty good.  The fish on the sushi wasn't the freshest, but if you like rice, they sure know how to pack it on there.  The rolls are also just average... nothing exciting, but if you've got an insatiable sushi fix, you'll probably be able to satisfy yourself here.  

The other stuff on the menu may be better than the sushi itself.  The chicken karaage may be one of the best I've had... meaty, tasty and not overloaded with skin (yuck).  Spinach salad is cold, very green, and refreshing.  The tempera was light and crispy.

Service is friendly.  Food can take a while to come to you when they are busy, and it can get loud and obnoxious in there with their all you can drink-watered-down sake.
author: shaun l.

description:
Go for the all you can eat. Stay for the sake cubes. 

What do you expect for service when you're chowing down plate after plate of sushi? I've been there 5 times and the service is definitely nothing to write home about, but it's nothing to ding them for. Just relax a little, enjoy your sake, and your sushi will come. 

Every time I've gone, I've had so much food I can barely walk and just make the stumble across the street to the great Rogue brewery. 

Warning to those in big groups: anyone who doesn't get the all-you-can-eat will be very jealous of those who did as you sit and wait while more and more seared maguro come to your table.
author: Josh B.

description:
3 stars for an AYCE sushi place.

I guess if you're paying $22 for all-you-can-eat, you get what you pay for. The quality of the fish was ok, especially considering the price...nothing toxic, but nothing that made my mouth water. 

The service was extremely slow (it took at least 20 minutes to get each order), and the staff, although friendly, was forgetful in placing our orders (we ended up having to order some things 3 or 4 times before we got it). 

The pro was that the riceballs of the sushi order were small, so they didn't fill you up, so you could eat more.
author: Reina M.

description:
My friends and I were looking for a place to eat before we went over to a show at Cobb's; didn't really feel like Italian so we were trying to list off different cuisines. Then someone mentioned sushi..which at that time just sounded like the best idea ever. But sushi in North Beach? Yes, sushi in North Beach.. better yet, all-you-can-eat sushi in North Beach :) 

We were kinda in a rush since we only had about an hour before our show. So we sat down, glanced at the menu, waved down the waitress (before a group of 6 could), and started ranting off what we wanted. 

The food came out pretty quick; there were two sushi chefs working and two waitresses. Within 5 minutes our appetizers (edamame,  2 wakames, fried tofu, cold tofu, and 4 miso soups) started slowly appearing.. and disappearing at the same time. While we were still working on those, our sushi rolls ( 2 orders of spicy tuna, 2 orders of rock n roll, crunch roll, albacore maki, and a San Francisco roll)  along with our salmon, tuna, and hamachi sushi nigiri AND our chicken katsu were making its way to the table. 

Between four people, we had a decent amount of food. We even had enough time.. and stomach space to get a couple more nigiri. Too bad the group of 6 decided to take all the hamachi for the rest of the night. Selfish. 

Even though we were about 20 minutes late to the show, it was worth it. The salmon and hamachi slices  were SO unbelievably fresh; it just melted in my mouth. I think I would've been able to just sit there and eat chunks of it. The other rolls on the menu looked really interesting and good; must try those the next time I'm there. 

Minus points for charging $1 for tea- thought only dim sum places do that
author: Krystal T.

description:
I'm going to provide the Sashimi Snob perspective that is apparently lacking here.

If, like me, you are more at home at the sushi bar than at a table, and you won't eat any variety of fish that the chef didn't recommend when you asked him what was fresh today, you will have no problems whatsoever.  The cuts are thick, the usual evening chef is cool, and you can get any kind of roll or temaki you want to order.  Prices are pretty reasonable; I'm usually well satisfied having spent $20 on sashimi and a couple of temaki.

You may even be pleasantly surprised.  I have, on one of my sushi bar visits to Sushi Hunter, been recommended the salmon as a sashimi selection.  Against all my better instincts and experiences eating salmon in San Francisco (it is generally universally bad -- I claim Salmon Snob rights also, because I used to live in Seattle), I got some really nice cuts of it here.  (If you're *looking* to eat raw salmon, though, go to Ryoko's where they often have wild alaskan salmon sashimi in the specials).

I've never done the all-you-can-eat option, but I've dined a la table once.  It was good, nothing spectacular.

This place gets four stars from me just for the sushi bar.
author: Naomi M.

description:
I tried the All you can eat menu and thought that it was okay, but not great.  The food is not authentic, Chinese people trying to cook Japanese food. The fish seemed fresh, sushi and nigiri were pretty good but the non-sushi items (tempura, teriyaki, salad) were gross.  I had to force myself to eat it because they charge for unfinished food.   My suggestion is only order sushi,  also gyoza and miso soup are good too.  I would stay away from non-sushi items because they are fillers and has no flavor.  As far as service goes, the servers are friendly, fast and efficient.  To sum it up my experience.  Service : great, food: not so good.  

Tip: If you are looking for a all you can eat sushi place, check out Sushi Hana on Van Ness Avenue...It is cost about the same but the food is better.
author: Eva E.

description: Sub-par sushi and service with a tad of attitude?  No thanks!  But I guess there really is no such thing as a good sushi buffet as you pay for quantity not quality.  Maybe it was an off-night because I was here with a group of 25, celebrating 3 birthdays, but this place is definitely not worth it.  If you want to try a decent sushi buffet, I think Sushi Hana wins in that department.
author: Kira K.

description: I finally got a chance to eat here.  I wanna try the all you can eat with full service.  That is what waitress said to me.  Not a buffet, but an all you can eat because the waitress corrected me.  The staff was nice to me and my girlfriend they speak Chinese as well.  We order two times. and I also found out what sushi my girlfriend likes, the uniga.  The bill was about 50 with tips is about 60 bucks.  We almost didn't finish the food.  It probably get busy on the weekend.  The kitchen might be small if the place gets full might have to wait longer for food.
author: John F.

description:
Yeah...about this place. They should hunt for better sushi, or better chefs. But either way, they should hunt for improvement.

Sushi was just ok. Portions small, prices normal. Lion King Roll so so. Nothing special about this place. Decor is intersting though.
author: Eddy N.

description:
It's probably from sushi deprivation in North Beach and the fact that my fave place, Warakabune, is closed on Mondays and Tuesdays, but I am strangely impressed with this place. 

First of all, they deliver only to NB which is really convenient if you live in the area. But if you're out and about and want all you can eat sushi for $23 (weekday), this is not a bad option. 

Had delivery the first time -- it was quick (even late at night) and the fish was good. I wasn't expecting much, and was pleasantly surprised. Nigiri ... Albacore was great, hamachi was really good, salmon was OK, and the few rolls we had were really good also. Crispy California is not worth it, but there are some other fried alternatives that do the trick. 

Went into the restaurant last night to eat and the place was really busy -- only 2 servers, so the service was super slow ... but the menu for all you can eat is pretty extensive and affordable.
author: Jen W.

description:
One of the few all you can eat sushi restaurants in the city. For about $25, you can get all you can sushi which is limited to just the regular rolls. I think the list boasts about 50 different types.
The sushi isn't that great, but's it's still worth it.
author: Dao C.

description:
All you can eat sushi and more on a Friday night for 24.95.. when there are only two servers and a full house..

Well let's see what happens, you get your food in like 20 min long paces, you don't get your water refilled, your order gets neglected. I don't know if it's like this every Friday night, and I'm not sure why the restaurant was "short staffed" because honestly it's not even a really big place and two people should be enough to cover the place.

Taste wise on the food, it's not bad. Sushi was a little warm (?) but the rolls were on par with some other sushi places you'd visit. I didn't like their teriyaki chicken but the miso soup was ok. Their udon is good too.

BTW you can't have all you can eat and a la carte mixed at a table.
author: Yosie G.

description:
Me and a couple of friends came here once because we were craving enormous amounts of sushi.

Because it is located in the downtown area, street parking will take you at least 15 minutes which is a drag unless you get lucky or fork up more money for parking garages nearby.

The atmosphere of this place is nice. Small and quiet. When we sat down, we knew exactly what we wanted which was the all-you-can-eat special for which was slightly less than $30 per person. Yes, it was expensive but we desired tekka rolls and we desired an unlimited amount lot of them. Other items offered on the special were gyoza's, nigri and terriyaki beef and chicken. The beef was AMAZING. It tasted as good as prime rib so we kept on order that.

For that price we were able to stuff ourselves with countless rolls. However, it was still a pain in the ass to find parking and $30 per person is still pretty damn expensive.
author: Stanley C.

description:
Very friendly service, but so much rice in the rolls. I could barely taste the fish, and when I did, it was average at best.  Meh.
I think I'm spoiled from living in L.A. where there's a sushi place on every corner.
author: Debbie M.

description: This place is Great!   My husband and I  gorge ourselves on the all you can eat and we embarrass ourselves.  They never bat an eyelid. They are very gracious and the food is exceptional.Very fresh . Great service..
author: cia v.

description:
We ate the "all you can eat" sushi special.  As one would expect with an all you can eat theme, the food was just not all that great.  You can eat until you bust a gut, but why eat something that is not all that special and get fatter in the process?

The one other problem that I had, but I do understand their reasoning, is that if anyone at your table wants the "all you can eat" deal, the whole table has to order the same.  It does make sense but annoyed me anyway.

Overall, the idea is somewhat fun but not a place I will seek out in the future.
author: Scott A.

description:
All-you-can-eat sushi for $22.95.  This stuff hasn't been sitting around, either -- you order your sushi from a menu so it is made fresh!  The selection is ok and the sushi is acceptable.  

We went there on a Friday night when it was packed and service was very slow.  It took 25 minutes from the time we ordered until we received the sushi.  Next time, we will order a HUGE ORDER up front instead of breaking into 2 orders when the place is packed.

Friendly service and pretty fast when they are not packed!
author: Spicy T.

description:
Reading the reviews below I'm thinking I should go back and try the all you can eat/drink menu. 

Anyhoo, I've been to this spot a couple times and have always left leaving telling myself I won't go back. 

There is definitely something odd about this spot. Every time I've been there's only a handful of folks eating. The food is bland and with my last experience I questioned the freshness/quality of fish. 

We ordered Miso soup and a seaweed salad to start off with. The Miso was tasteless and lukewarm and the seaweed salad reminded me of ramen noodles dyed green with food coloring.  Our yellow tail had a rubbery consistency and our two rolls (Big easy and California) tasted like something you could buy pre made from Safeway. When I go to get sushi i expect the freshest of the fresh.

In a city full of great options and sushi spots Sushi Hunter doesn't make the cut.
author: Summer C.

description:
Not sure what to say that hasn't already been said.  The inside is nice but a little to fancy for a AYCE sushi place.  It's not Moonstar that's for sure!  You put in your order with the staff and they bring things out.  We were pigs.  We tried just about everything on the menu.

The hot food items are super small and sort of bland.  The portion was like airplane meal sized.  The nigiri choices were ok.  Better than sushi factory that's for sure but they were too generous with the rice.  They don't limit you to a few items at a time like sushi factory (3 items at a time per person).

I'd go back again but not anytime soon.
author: Angie C.

description:
This place has good food but I think the price is a bit much.  I came here with a bunch of coworkers and we ordered pretty much everything on the menu and then some but I don't think it was worth the $30 i spent.  

The rolls, seaweed salad, beef teriyaki were all very good but anything with chicken gets a thumbs down for me.  Chicken tasted like fake chicken - ala chicken nuggets.

The service was awesome and they were all very friendly.  Eventhough we were being loud and stayed for about 2 hrs, I never felt like they were trying to throw us out.  The waitresses just kept coming to take our orders.

Overall, I would go there again but definitely only when I am really hungry so I can get my money's worth!!
author: glen o.

description:
I've had much much better ones!
We went there with a group of 8 and we had the "all you can it sushi"
(I usually start with pros but I make and exception for this one, you'll se why)
-CONS:
1) the "all you can eat" menu is SO SO limited, you don't have many choices and most of them are fried!
2) they missed a lot of our orders and at some point brought what eve they wanted, we had more fried sushis than we ordered and we had to eat them because of the surcharge! and we had to order the ones wanted again!!!
3) WAY too much rice in each piece of roll and tiny pieces of fish on the sashimi, I felt sick after it and it wasn't even that fresh.
4) 5 tracks were played the whole time I was there which was about 2 hours, so imagine how many times I heard each of them :s
5) too crowded, the tables are so close you can barely walk in between them
6) my friend had a vale parking, when she got her car back she was told it costed 37$!!!!! then said "what???!!!! it was 20!!!" and the guys said "OH, OK, if you were told it was 20, so 20"!!!!!!!
-PROS:
1) I can't think of any right now, I'll update if I do
TIPS:
1) the limited choices of all you can eat sushi, too much rice, with sake and of course the 18% service (because we were a group), all costed us 45$/person, which was not worth it in my point of view
2) don't pay anything you are told for vale parking
3) there is a parking on Vallejo that has a discounted rate for this restaurant, so use it!
author: Gnaz A.

description: Decent choice for all you can eat with lots of choices.  I've only been for lunch so none of this rambunctious-ness that everyone has been talking about.  Overall its a decent option, especially if you want all you can eat.
author: J. B.

description: It's a great place to eat a ton of sushi.  i went with some friends and we ate till we could eat no more.  the all you can eat menu has a decent amount of variety and the service is great and friendly.  they even validate parking!!
author: Patrick L.

description:
HELL YEAH!  ALL you can eat Sushi.  That's really all you need to know.  Go there with an empty stomach, and order it up like there is NO TOMORROW :)

I go there for my Sushi fix.  YUM!

Oh, and the wait staff is SUPER FRIENDLY!
author: Noneya B.

description:
This got 3.5 stars?  Come on...really?

So I've seen some of the other reviews that talked about the poor service here.  I thought it was fine though it wasn't exactly crowded for a sat. night so maybe they had time to tend to our table.

Since it was close to Beach Blanket Babylon, this place came highly recommended from a guy who lived nearby.  I was told when I arrived that this place was great because "it's all you can eat so you can order whatever you want".  Often times criticized as a food snob, I was trying really hard at this point to maintain an open mind esp. since I was not with my usual food crew.  

First started with the chicken karagee...
other guy: "hmm isn't this so good?"
me: "umm yea, it tastes and looks like a chicken nugget"
other guy: "exactly!"

ugh, the rest of the meal was pretty much the same so i'm not even goign to dive into the details.  In fairness, I don't usually hate any food so everything was still okay to eat and quality wise was probably about the same as some of the places back in ole MI (yes I translate that into sub-par for SF).  At the end of the day, I still spent $40 at this place for this all-you-can-eat sushi plus a beer.  I'd much rather take my money elsewhere and eat a little less but have much better quality ingredients.  Or.. if you really want to eat all-you-can-eat sushi... go to Todai.. same concept, same quality.
author: Ken S.

description:
All You Can EAT!

Showed up at around 7:45PM on a Thursday with my gf.  There were about 7 other people in the restaurant.  I have walked by this place a couple of times.  Seems to be the only Sushi Restaurant in the North Beach area.

There are some rules and regulations, which one of them are "If one person is eating all you can eat then everyone else must, if not they must sit at another table."  So I ate at one table and my girlfriend at another.  What a great date!  JK, we both had the all you can eat.

Atmosphere - One room with wood accents seating about 25-30 people, clean.
Food - The sushi was average, but decent for the price.  The menu for all you can eat ranged from the Chicken Cutlet, sushi, tempura and soups.  My girlfriend didn't like the bland udon noodle soup.
Service - Japanese servers make it more authentic.  Good at the beginning, but less attentive as the night went on.  It took forever for my last sushi dish to come out (egg on a rice roll), but it was made fresh and it was good.
Recommend - Good for a quick fix and price, but probably won't be back there unless I want all you can eat.  I would prefer to pay a little more for better quality.  If you are a sushi snob then you probably won't like it here.

3 stars - The "All you can eat" counteracts the poor service plus it's the only sushi place in North Beach so it adds variety to the area.  One of the better Sushi buffets around.
author: Po L.

description:
Went here for a spontanious birthday dindin and didn't know the city had an all-you-can-eat sushi place that's not moonstar. Not bad at all and I would come back.

Small place, but very colorful and art-deco. Might have problem getting a seat as it is a small place and parking is horrible (it's in North Beach), but after eating, you can always walk off all the crap you just added in and head to the bars which is a big plus.
author: M T.

description:
five stars for the experience.  sushi was good, but more impressive was their handling of our large party.  we made a reservation for 26 for the all-you-can-eat sushi and all-you-can-drink sake duo before a tainted love show at bimbo's, and sushi hunter handled.  plenty of sushi, a variety of rolls and nigiri, some tempura and teriyaki appetizers...

highlight of the night: setting up a round of sake bombs, and one falls in before everyone is ready. the waitress, as she walks by, slams the table to get everyone's going.  straight classy.
author: doug a.

description: I've been to Sushi Hunter on many occasions seeing that there are only 2 sushi places in North Beach. Anyways, Sushi Hunter isn't bad, but it isn't great. My sister and I usually just come here when we are too lazy to go all the way to Downtown or Richmond for sushi we really love. The last time I was here I got the Devil Roll, spicy tuna and siracha. It was okay. I felt it could have been a lot more flavorful. I also got another roll with just unagi and cucumber. Again, it was okay. 3 stars for an average sushi joint.
author: Jackie M.

description:
(okay, so this restaurant is really a 3.5...)

in the past, i've always had the all-you-can-eat which is pretty solid. i'd probably opt for Sushi Hana's all-you-can-eat over Sushi Hunter's.... it's worth it if you get a lot of nigiri. 

tonight i ordered from the regular menu...it was an okay experience. i had the bento box with teriyaki chicken, negi hama (yellow tail), and tekka (teppa?) roll (tuna roll). my boyfriend had a bento box with tempura, salmon shioyaki, and nigiri, chef's choice. all of the different items were okay... chef's choice was yellowtail, tuna, and unagi. the miso soup was wonderful (!), probably my favorite miso soup of any restaurant.. but I take issue with the fact that the waitress asked us if we wanted some edamame to start, and then charged us for it. maybe that's standard, but i feel like they just offer that for free at a lot of japanese restaurants? and then there's that tension moment where you assume it's free, but you don't want to ask because it's tacky to ask "is it free?"  so it's not free. anyway, the food was pretty decent.... not too filling. with restaurant.com, it was $34 for two bento boxes, an alaska roll, two tsingtao's, and edamame. i have no issues with this place, but i'd never crave it either.
author: Kimberly S.
