description: Came here for the buffet, and although theres much cheaper Japanese buffets elsewhere (in Davis), this place wasn't bad for $26 a person in SF. You can't have specialty rolls, but you can basically have all the nigiri, appetizers, and hot food items you want. Tea and ice cream/mochis are discounted. Other drinks and items are at full price. There is definitely enough in the buffet menu to keep you satisfied. I don't think I'll be dying to come back for the buffet, because I'm not so much a buffet person. The fish for the nigiri weren't so fresh, besides from the salmon. The unagi was very good. But most of all, the beef teriyaki was a steak rather than just beef. It was of good quality, and cooked perfectly pink! Service wasn't bad either! But parking was -_- Clean overall.
author: Elaine H.

description: im surprised i did not review sushi hunter the first time i went in. $25 for all you can eat! that is incredible.. i have spent $30 at other places and walked out hungry. now if you are a sushi connoisseur you may judge but i have never noticed anything but great quality fish and everything has been delicious.. works for me!!
author: Barbara C.

description: This was absolutely horrible. I have no idea why anyone would ever say that the fish here is fresh or good.  It tasted like it came out of a freezer.  The quality was about as good as Miyake's in Palo Alto (which charges about $2 for a spicy tuna roll).  We had a big party and I appreciate the fact that they let you have big parties, but they often forgot rolls, brought out random nigiri, and then people couldn't even remember what they ordered because nothing came out at the same time nor was it given to the people who ordered it. The all-you-can eat deal isn't worth it and neither is the all-you-can drink sake.
author: Annie T.

description: Sushi Hunter is a great place for a variety of reasons.  The atmosphere is great full of energetic people in North Beach.  The food is absolutely delicious and is fresh, made to order.  The staff is quick and really outgoing towards their patron.  I had a dinner for my friend's birthday here and had about 15 people.  This place is great for groups, they catered to us very well.  Excellent Sushi Hunter I will definitely return!
author: Mike F.

description: Well all I can say is that this place used to be good. I am not sure what happened and it was one of our favorite places to go but no longer. The honeymoon is over!! The service is so bad it took over 20 mins to get a drink and even longer to get our first item out. We ordered several things at once and by the end of the first hour we still did not have all of the food that we ordered. I could not even enjoy the food because the service took so long to bring out dishes. I did not even get all of the food we ordered before I asked for the check and left. But they did bring the check out in less than a minute. I will never go back here. We left disappointed and disgusted....and did I mention still hungry so we left and ate somewhere else. Total waste of my money. There are too many other and much better sushi places in North Beach for me to waste my time here.
author: Scott K.

description:
Food: Decent. I'm used to having more fancy rolls even at an all-you-can-eat place, but their selection was satisfactory. The fish is not very fresh but still edible. Agedashi tofu and korokke are a must! 

Drink: The all-you-can-drink is only sake, and you have to buy beer separately. This can work to your advantage though, because people not having all-you-can-drink sake at the same table can still purchase beers, while most other places have an all-or-nothing alcohol policy.

Decor: Very Americanized-Japanese sushi bar style. The place was bright and clean.

Service: All but one of the waitresses were very sweet. The birthday boy and 2 others in his car were running late. 45 minutes after our reservation time, the not-very-nice waitress came over to berate us for his tardiness and point out what a big favor the restaurant is doing by letting us wait at our table for so long. When the latecomers showed up, the first thing she told them was how long the rest of us had been waiting. I can understand what a pain it would be if there were other customers waiting, but there were other empty tables, no other large groups scheduled to come in after us, and definitely no need to make everyone feel guilty.

Price: My share for all-you-can-eat/all-you-can-drink + a couple shared bottles of beer came out to be almost $50 including tax and tip. Fairly comparable to a similar deal at a shabu shabu place.
author: S L.

description: This place has good food, the best service (really, she was just top notch, belongs at a very high-end place), prices were reasonable and they didn't try to kick us out even though we were ordering up until the very last minute.   I didn't see the all you can eat menu but.  We spent a fortune but it was worth it.
author: JD D.

description:
Best sushi in north beach.  Their extravagant rolls are definitely the best... Black Pearl, Dark Rainbow, Lion King, Crazy Seahorse... yum!  Go here with a large group of people and make everyone get a different roll to share without overlapping.  That will give you a good sampling at about $20 a head. 

They also have a limited all-you-can-eat menu for about $22 until 10pm but its pretty boring.
author: ahh lee n a.

description:
Ward-

You went here hungry and you were disappointed from the start.  You couldn't understand the waitress because she spoke so softly, they charged you for the hot tea and that pissed you off, the portions were way too small and now you're home eating your leftover garlic bread in an attempt to fill your stomach.  You paid too much for so little and still threw a pity tip of $2 because you felt bad for the girl who spoke so low.

You will never go here again and can understand why a place with portions that size would offer an all-you-can-eat package.
author: Ward D.

description: Came here on a Friday night before going out in North Beach. I thought the food and the service was great. My only complaint is that if you are looking for a place to spend some time eating and drinking with friends, this place is a bit BRIGHT and lacks a bit of atmosphere.
author: Meagan C.

description: I came here with 4 of my best eating buddies to eat the "all you can eat" meal.  What I found was a restaurant that pulled out all the stops to minimize their losses.  First, the waitress seldom came to take orders even though the restaurant wasn't crowded.  Second, they made sure to bring out the food really slow to allow our stomach-full receptors to fully engage.  Lastly, the restaurant wasn't even busy.  Thoroughly disappointed.  I'd rather go to crazy buffet...
author: Vincent T.

description:
Don't be fooled.  I went into this place with high hopes.  Extraordinarily high hopes.  After all, this restaurant is named SUSHI HUNTER.   The name alone makes it sound like it boasts the most thrilling dining experience San Francisco has to offer.  The first thing that went through my mind was "Am I really going to get to HUNT for my own SUSHI?!"  Was I expected to roll up to this place, packin' my CO2 pellet gun, continuously guzzle down carafe after caraffe of hot sake, and aim my barrel at little round targets on wooden sushi boats circling the dining room Kaiten-zushi style? 
 
Edamame? ***BAM!*** 
 
Spicy tuna roll?   ***BOOM!*** 
 
Hamachi Nigiri?  ***BULLSEYE!*** 
 
Present me the fruits of my labors, waitress!  Bring me the spoils of the hunt! 
 
Unfortunately this was NOT AT ALL the case.
 
In the back of my mind, I can only hope that shooting range sushi was the owner's original intention when naming his/her restaurant "Sushi Hunter," a dream crushed only by liability reasons and patrons' unwillingness to sign waivers upon entry.  However, I was disappointed by much more than Sushi Hunter's unwillingness to let me fire my rubber pellets at will. 
 
First of all, we were here for a birthday party for the one-and-only Ashley M.  While I give props to the staff for putting up with our incessant sake bombing, boisterous curse-laden toasts and repeated spilling of booze all over the table, the kitchen seemed to be completely overwhelmed by our party of ~20 ordering the famous all-you-can-eat menu.  They couldn't bring out the gyoza, maki, nigiri, or even edamame and sake fast enough to fill our tummies.  And we weren't gorging ourselves or having some sort of eating competition; we were just eating at a normal pace.  There was absolutely, positively no way to get our money's worth of the promised "all-you-can-eat sushi" and "all-you-can-drink sake."  No way.  For $24.95 for sushi, $13 for mediocre hot sake and $6/beer, we would have had to have consumed a shit-ton more than we did to make it worth the lump sum we paid at the end of the night.  

In my mind, the greatest affront Sushi Hunter committed was that after we paid the bill because part of our party was leaving, the waitresses refused to bring us one final bottle of sake to finish off the meal.  Just because a few people left the table and we paid our bill with obligatory 17% tip, service just stops dead?  Good thing my CO2 chamber was emptied by the time that happened...

Admittedly, I did have a great time for Ashley's birthday party but it was because of the company, not the service or food.  If I ever go back to Sushi Hunter, I'm going in with a vengeance.  I'm wearing camo, I'm not eating for two days beforehand, and I'm chowing down on maki Sonya "Black Widow" Thomas-style! Livin' the dream.  Huntin' the sushi.
author: Erin L.

description: I straight up love this place. Open until 1 am, they have all you can eat sushi and appetizers for about $24. The food was amazing, made even better by the loud techno and pop music they blasted. Since we were there pre-partying before the bars, around 11 pm, it was perfect for us. You don't expect good sushi in the heart of North Beach, but Sushi Hunter delivers!
author: Allison M.

description:
Ow. Ow. Ow. 
It wasn't until Sunday morning that I started to feel somewhat normal again. When my friend told us that we were celebrating her 26th birthday at the Sushi Hunter, I thought, "Great, that will be so fun"! Little did I know that , "so fun" was actually going to mean, "drink yourself into oblivion" and try to make it home. 

There were 15 people in our party, so we all did the All-You-Can-Eat sushi. The menu is 50 items long and ranges from appies, to nigiri to rolls. You can order anything you want in mass quantities, but beware. There is a disclaimer at the bottom of the menu, better known as the 3rd asterick. I can't quote it verbatim, but the effect is "you will be charged for frivolously wasting nigiri rice balls". I'm sorry, what? It was my first experience at the Sushi Hunter, but the more seasoned vets in my party explained to me that I was only to eat the fish and to ball my rice balls into a napkin, where we would then take turns ridding ourselves of them in the bathroom. I thought that was the most bizarre part of the evening, until the waiter asked me if I wanted the All-You-Can-Drink sake. Wait, huh? Come again? I surely thought that I was hearing things. Nope, for a mere $11 you can proceed to drink hot sake to your heart's content. Sign me up!

The rest of the evening gets blurry from here, but I will say this: If you are a fellow Gaucho, you have been to the Sushi Hunter before. Only it was called Kyoto's on Upper State or Something's Fishy on lower State Street. I thought that at 26, we had all matured a bit - nothing like all you can drink sake to prove you wrong.
author: Jenny S.

description: The first time I came here with my roomie and we did the all-you-can-eat and all-you can drink deal. We left thinking the food was so-so, but definitely worth it for all the sake we drank! Fast forward to a few months later and I decide to do a re-do of the all you can eat/drink. And much to my surprise, the food was actually really good. The sushi rolls were a bit high on the rice, but that was perfectly fine with us because we ended up sticking with the beef, chicken, fish and pork entree dishes...along with the many, many appetizers. Their service is pretty fast, the food is pretty good...and they're really nice!! I'd definitely come here again
author: Natalie J.

description: Went here for dinner the other night with some friends.  The decor inside is nice, very modern, almost had a club feel to it (especially with the music playing).  We all had the "all you can eat" special.  It was nice that it had other stuff besides nigiri and rolls.  The food was ok, but we got a lot.  I wish I could say something better about the food, but ok is the strongest adjective I'm willing to use.  The fried stuff (karage, tonkatsu, tempura) were pretty good.  The rolls and nigiri, like I said before, ok. I'm a picky sushi guy, and all the stuff on the all you can eat menu was frozen.  But the sauces on the rolls cover up the quality of the fish.  Now if we didn't get enough food I would have given this place 2 stars, but we made it a point to order more food any time a waitress was in the nearby vicinity.  Hopefully the regular menu is better, willing to try that.
author: Shane Y.

description:
So, I believe that tonight is the third time that I have ordered from Sushi Hunter and once again, I am a satisfied customer.
For some reason, I really like how you can order online through delivery.com and sort through the menu at your leisure to decide exactly what you're in the mood for.  Personally, I order the sashimi every time, which is always good. Is it the best I've ever had? Probably not, but it's good and fresh every time and satisfies my craving for sushi.  Other items I have tried are the edamame (which are always good and firm. Surprisingly edamame are very easy to mess up... some places boil them too long and they become too soft and almost soggy), seaweed salad (always tasty) and the hamachi handroll (which was ok, but I probably won't order it again).  
Overall, Sushi Hunter has become my go-to for sushi delivery (it's also really close to my apt which helps) with a very nice lady that delivers it every time still wearing her apron :)
author: Emily S.

description:
first time in san francisco and we tried the sushi hunter...i have to say that it is delicious!!!! i have tried sushi in tokyo and back in my home country (luxembourg) and honestly...the sushi hunter makes the best sushi i have eaten so far!!! it is fresh and home made and mind blowing awesome :))) to all the people out there...go and try it out!!!!!!!

p.s. the service is friendly as well and relly helpful in case you don't really know anything about sushi...
author: Bob U.

description:
I always feel a little naughty when I come here; as though I'm doing something which is a little illicit. Never before finding Sushi Hunter had I the option to gorge myself on as much sushi as I could handle, all made to order, and leave with a bill for two under $60. Does Sushi Hunter serve the absolute highest quality fish? No. Are the plate presentation and atmosphere top notch? Again, no. However, if you've ever fantasized about writhing in a vat of raw fish and a touch of soy sauce, forced to eat your way out, then this is the place to go.
I've seen reviews stating that the service can be a little spotty, but every time that I've been in the waitstaff have been excellent. Also, I've been told that it can be a little loud on weekends, but I don't know from firsthand experience. Then again, anyone who goes to an all-you-can-eat place on a weekend in North Beach should know what they're getting into.
author: Daniel W.

description: Another local spot I enjoy and we come here often. Guys, avoid Friday and Saturday nights if you want a quiet dining experience as my roommates friends and I are likely to be in there on one of those nights Sake Bombing away and living it up. The rolls are pretty good if you know what to get, like the AC360, Titanic and a few others.  The staff is extremely friendly and helpful even if you are making a mess of your bombs all over the table they seem to enjoy the liveliness. The sushi chef made a special chef's special roll for my bday that was EXCELLENT and not on the menu. This was because I was just talking with him and asking him what was some of his favorites.  If you want a stogie over priced pent up sushi experience go to Ozumo, if you want to hang out, eat some good rolls (it's not world famous sashimi or nigiri so stick with rolls) and have a dining experience where the staff feels like one of your own friends then come here.
author: Chris C.

description: All you can eat sushi for $23!!! That includes other stuff (udon, teriyaki, gyoza etc..) not just nigiri and rolls.  I'm pretty sure they have an all you can drink sake deal too.  The staff was polite and quick, taking away plates the second you finished and asking if everything was okay.  The menu was pretty basic..nothing too crazy I hadn't seen before but still very good!
author: Kelsey R.

description: For $25, it was a good selection of food.  The fried dishes were all really yummy (tempera, karaage).  Food came out pretty promptly and the sushi didn't have as much rice as I was expecting, which is good!  Thanks Sal for arranging dinner!
author: Jen C.

description: The staff was friendly, the prices were cheap and the food was decent. Not the best Japanese food in the world, but if you're tired of the all the Italian restaurants in North Beach, consider it a possible alternative...
author: Natalie T.

description: Ever try to gorge yourself with enough sushi to test your physical and mental boundaries? Well if you haven't, you should. Sushi Hunter has really good sushi, and at $23 ($25 on weekends) for all you can eat, it's a great deal. Plus, their all you can eat menu isn't limited to just sushi. They have chicken teriyaki, katsu, etc. So the sushi-haters can have a good meal too! I only give it 4 stars because the service can be kind of spotty. It might have beeen that my friend and I had eaten more than 30 peices of sushi each. But who knows...all you can eat right? Also, a great tip is that you can't just eat the fish part of the sushi, any rice you leave on your plate after you're done, will be charged the full price of an order of sushi. Kind of lame. But i guess there has to be some sort of guideline.
author: Ben R.

description: Went to SH the other night, walked in very hungry, was served right away...our server was a very sweet girl...we had very traditional sushi rolls, nothing out of the ordinary...the best part of the meal though was the dessert...we had the fried ice cream....AMAZING!!! The prices seem cheap, but they add up quick!! I want to come back for all you can eat though...I've never seen that in the city...!!!
author: Elana N.

description: If you're a hungry college student/fratboy at heart (or in real life), the $20 all-you-can-eat sushi/appetizer/entree menu is for you, though you'll have to be ASSERTIVE to keep the food coming.  Sure, the sushi quality doesn't stand out or anything, but if you're going to an all-you-can-eat place, do you really care??  They also have a big TV on the wall that's set on sports games, if you're into that sort of thing.  And then there's the $10 all-you-can-drink sake.  My roommates and I don't remember much after that...
author: Rego S.

description:
I am still buzzing from the Sapporo that I enjoyed with my meal at Sushi Hunter today!  Yes, 600mL bottle of Sapporo about 45 minutes ago...  Great food, great service, great atmosphere, great company and overall great experience!  We even told the waitress to take her clothes off in Japanese... bad, I know, really bad.  She was very uncomfortable with us the whole time.  Hey, that was the only phrase we knew and thought it would be funny.... Ha!  We're sorry.

Let me rewind and let you know how my friend and I ended up eating here today...  
     As the Italy vs. Spain game come to a disappointing ending, the guy I am recently dating, Rob, gave me a call to meet up for early dinner, late lunch.  I suggested Mood Sushi (on Beach and Taylor), but apparently, the sushi chef does not come in  until 5p (it was 3:40pm).  We headed back to Columbus, North Beach Sushi, but they did not open until 4:30p (it was 3:55p).  We were hungry, very hungry, have not eaten anything all day and was ready to settle for whatever we can find, sushi or not, but decided that we've come this far and sushi was what we wanted... Thank goodness for Sushi Hunter (third time's a charm)!  
     Why have I not eaten at SH before since I live in the neighborhood and love sushi? Well, it's simple, one of my roommate said she did not like it so I never even thought about trying it out myself.  Today, I have to say that I disagree with her because I really like this place...
      Rob and I shared a Specialty Roll,  Hot Tuna Roll (tuna & avocado inside, topped with seared tuna) for only $10.50.  Rolls were decent size.  I specially like the seared tuna on top; lightly seared and very tasty!  We also each had a bento box.  For $13.95, our bento boxes included; rice, miso soup, Nigiri Sushi (3 pcs Chef's Choice sushi nigiri), Sashimi (3 pcs Chef's Choice raw fish) and 6 pcs California roll.  

     Our sushi cravings were surely satisfied without spending too much money.  We would definitely come back and maybe even try the ALL YOU CAN EAT SUSHI next time :-)!
author: Celeste M.

description:
This is a hidden gem for one reason and one reason only:  the all-you-can-eat option (which includes sushi)!  I have to admit, I was a little skeptical at first.  I feared that that the food would be pre-made, sitting in a bin, and that the sushi would be egregiously over-stuffed with rice.  Thankfully, these fears were unfounded.  The all-you-can-eat option is a steal.  For $22.95, you get all the FRESH Japanese food you can eat.  Literally, you order the food (from the somewhat limited, but still reasonably vast, all-you-can-eat menu) and THEN they make it.  There are appetizer options (like miso soup, green salad, edamame, gyoza, agedashi tofu, etc.), entree options (like chicken teriyaki, assorted tempura, saba shioyaki, etc.), and sushi options (like maguro, seared maguro, hamachi, sake, etc. and assorted rolls).  The hot items (like tempura) arrive at the table piping hot.  The sushi looks just as it would if you ordered it a la carte.  At first blush, $22.95 may sound like a lot, but considering the quality of the food, it's actually a steal.

The one drawback is that the service can be a little spotty.  But if you're going for the all-you-can-eat option, you're probably not in a hurry anyway.  And considering that $22.95 is a bargain for all-you-can-eat high-quality Japanese food, you can tolerate some mediocrity.
author: Sophrosyne Y.

description: Slow service! food is ok. Nothing special. Paper thin slice sushi + thick rice= you get full fast. But the gyoza is the best ive ever tasted! Servers were very friendly.
author: Earl P.

description: I have to agree with Jennifer B.'s review below, there's something odd about this place, I just don't know what it is. We've gone there for all you can eat a couple of times and it's always ok, but never outstanding. This place has terrible acoustics and you can hear everything going on at every other table. The service is slow and sometimes the cold stuff comes out warm and the hot stuff comes out cool. I've never had a terrible time, or food poisoning or anything, but I've left feeling like I could have done better had I gone somewhere else. I'd rather find a new place in the neighborhood rather than go back there. Plus, they've limited their all-you-can-eat menu down to basics. Took off my fave--seared tuna.
author: Denise L.

description: i would of never thought that there would be a sushi buffet but boy was i wrong, They have two ways for you to dine there, one is all you can eat and the other is per item. The food is mediocre but better then most sushi buffets i know of. And the service was everything you would hope for, friendly, helping, attractive and very attentive with our every need. there missing one star because of the boss lady giving that poor waitress a bad day. the price would say okay enough for like a weekend dinner but not for a daily meal. the place is decent with a like big screen TV for sports and the other best thing is the all you can drink sake.. how great is that.. just for 11 dollars you can get piss drunk and pack with sushi..so over all this place is great, i would come back again for over all. food, service and entertainment..
author: david l.

description:
This place is amazing for big groups - they don't mind the noise, so sake bombing is welcome.  Make sure to go during the all you can eat sushi and sake - amazing.

For those looking to hit the city after dinner, Northstar (a bar) is right around the corner and is always hopping.
author: T U.

description:
not the best sushi ever but they do get extra-bonus-points for: 
a) the all-you-can-eat menu - admirable, just off the mark on quality; 
b) proximity - on sunny days the grass of washington square park is there to catch you, buzzed and stuffed, for a nap
c) putting up with our shenanigans.
d) they deliver! and it's quick! (*btw, if you do get delivery be sure to give the delivery ladies a great, big tip - they're the sweetest and happiest ladies in town...)
author: mike l.

description: Just went here for a b-day party and was pretty impressed with the overall experience.  Their sushi is not spectacular, but it is at least average.  They get the 4 stars for the all you can eat sushi (and all you can drink hot sake for and extra $10!).  I went in with a small party that over the course of an hour turned into a larger one (about 15 people or so), and the staff was very accomodating with bringing more tables and place settings, etc...  The place was pretty busy but the waiters were still pretty attentive.  All in all, I had a great experience.
author: Robert R.

description: All you can eat sushi?! Who could turn that down?! Great deal, good food. I always take friends from out of town here. You get all you can eat sushi and appetizer/entrees from their separate menu. It's a great way to try a variety of items in smaller portions. Think they wanted to kick us out when we went...my brother in law and boyfriend at the time were eating enough for the entire place along with the all you can drink sake. Ah, good times! Parking is difficult...so plan ahead.
author: Kai T.

description: To preface, I'm a nigiri guy - no brokeback-gonzo-w-creme cheese rolls for me thank you.  I also value authenticity over flash.  I really only like to sit at the sushi bar and ask the chef whats fresh, what he likes etc.  There are only 2 sources of wholesale sushi quality fish for all of the SF Japanese restaurants.  Meaning that as long as its fresh, its pretty consistent quality everywhere you go.  So one searches for other criteria-- namely the rice quality, the attitude of staff, price-value, the rapport w/ sushi chef etc.  Sushi Hunter is really only worthy if you want to play the tabehodai/all you can eat game- thats why they got 2 instead of 1 stars from me.  Few sushi places to be found in North Beach, but skip this one.
author: Brian D.

description: went here after work with a girlfriend for a quick bite to eat and a drink and was really surprised. Not only was the food awesome but so was the service. They were very attentive and we even got desert and an appetizer on the house. The ambiance is relaxing but yet chic. I will MOST DEFINITLEY go here again. its a neighborhood gem.
author: Lindsey Marie O.

description: Nice fresh sushi, decently priced.  Rolls decent as well.  Nothing outstanding about this place, but nothing horrendous.  Good place for some quick sushi when you don't want to spend a lot of money.
author: M J.

description:
are you kidding me? Four stars for this joint?
First of all, this place is located near north beach and is one of the ONLY few non-italian food places you can go to. My biggest complaint of this establishment was if you are going to put "all you can eat" deal then provide all the "FOOD PEOPLE WANT TO EAT" I went there with a very large group awhile back and the owner looked irritated about the amount of food he thought "We'd consume" He told us that because it has been so busy that day, a lot of things had "run" out and the waitress kept coming back to say "sorry no more" We sat there and ate few pieces of nigiri and maki when all of the sudden the bill was handed to us without us even asking for it! Really? Then being the large group we were, we decided all to pay cash and while counting the cash to put into the bill, the waitress takes the money out of my hand and starts counting herself! How rude! While the food was ok, i have a better luck going down to my neighbor safeway for some sushi....... it was the service and the attitude of this place that had me saying "Hontoni?" 

Basic point,
dont go here because its "all you can eat sushi"
their sign should be "all you can eat sushi or whatever we have left of" 

Poor service, poor food, and rude waitress who just wants your money!
author: Youna K.

description: WOW.... all new with nice and cozy feel. Come check it out... I haven't come back her for some time.  The food still the same and place fantastic!! I've been here twice and both times this week in town visit my mom.  I went the food was fabulous. The prices are a taaaaad on the pricey side but for the quality of the food, it's totally worth it. And it's also true that the portions are a bit on the smaller side for some of dish. so if you want to fill up, be prepared to dish out the dough. The restaurant had a new look, so wait times could be long because they close out for sometime couple weeks.  if you go during peak hours. Also staff is limited, so my main (and really only) gripe is sometimes there is a long wait time between dishes.  Try to come weekday, so you don't have to wait....
author: Jen L.

description: The best thing about this restaurant is the all-you-can eat: they have a special menu you can order from, but it has a lot of items, and the best part is that they make it fresh to order- not like other all-you-can-eat places where the sushi is pre-made and sitting in bins. The sushi is of high quality and very fresh and the tempura comes out piping hot! Yum!
author: Kristine Y.

description: i was happy they have a happy menu, we've been here before for dinner and the quality was decent. but when their happy hour they not only skimmed on the quality and completely different forms of sushi. it's not worth it at all.  DON'T DO HAPPY HOUR HERE, YOU'LL BE DISAPPOINTED!!!!
author: Frances T.

description: Five stars because I love Sake... and they have lots of it, and it is unlimilted! The funnest night that I will never remember! :)
author: Abra J.

description:
Living in North Beach does have it's down sides (very very few, but I'll admit it's not perfect). Sushi is not our little italian food infested neighborhoods strong suit. You've got this place and sushi on north beach down street. I like Sushi Hunter better. 

The sushi is ok, I haven't had anything bad, but I would never recommend this place based solely on it's wonderful, fresh fish or clever delicious rolls - no way. It's totally basic, some rolls just ok, fish seems good, but not outstanding quality really nothing to rave about on the menu that I've found so far. Sushi Hunter gets my business because of it's service, location, and lack of competition in the area. But, it's grown on me and I have a lot of fun memories here over the years. Back in the immediate post college days the Miguel and I would come here often with friends to sake bomb and dig into their all you can eat menu's, which is a good deal if you really eat a lot of sushi. For the guys it was a bargain, for me I'd rather just order a few orders of exactly what i want. Anyways, they are always friendly, they can accomodate large groups and they're totally accepting of loud obnoxious sake bombing, yelling and making a mess of beer all over the table (I prefer to just pour my sake in for the bomb rather than the whole scene on the chop stick, banging the table etc). Sushi hunter's friendly encouraging behavior of sake bombing single handedly was responsible for many of our worst hangovers back in 2005, I think they used to offer $10 all you can drink house sake (is that right? it seemed to good to be true back then too). Pretty sure Miguel has a scar on his forehead compliments of his lovely girlfriend under the crazy sake special influence. They've also got a flat screen that always has ESPN on so my guy would like coming here for that reason too. They play very random, but always pretty fun music. 

It's really a great place to come for a bite to eat and some sake before starting a fun night. Because of this reason, we recently had a birthday party here and the same night across the room was another large party. They handled the groups well, let us bring in our own cake, and they spruced it up with some chocolate drizzle and put it on a cute platter and came out signing happy birthday. That scored big time points with me since a few other places I'd called wouldnt let us bring in our own cake, they really went the extra mile and I appreciated it. 
I am moving back to northbeach in a few months and will be living almost directly across the st from sushi hunter - so - I am anticipating being back many times in the near future.
author: Audrey V.

description: The sushi quality is good and CONSISTENT.  Though I am a sushi snob, I have been there several times with friends and have not been disappointed.  The menu has a vast selection of rolls and other traditional Japanese items.  If you are in the mood for no-fuss sushi and some appetizers, this is the place to go.  I love that it is tucked away from the hustle and bustle of other North Beach restaurants.
author: Hiromi N.

description: Favorite Sushi restaurant in north beach. All you can eat menu is quite extensive.
author: Rico S.

description: Lowering this place by one star. Went again with the same friends - one of our friends really loves this place. We had the same waitress who is really slow and forgetful. First we did the all you can eat again. Everything came out slow and we ordered beef teryaki - it was one of the 1st things we ordered and we had to ask for it 7 times and it still never came, when we asked about it at the end we just said to forget it since we didnt feel like waiting an hour or more for it since she couldnt remember to order it for us. Then when we got the bill they included 18% gratuity - they didnt do this the first time. The waitress sent her manager who showed us on the menu that it said that 18% gratuity was included for parties of 5 or more. Uh...we had 4 people and a baby - since when do you count a 9 month old as part of our party when she's not even eating? I've never been to a place that did this before - AND THE MANAGER argued with us about it. Bad business, super rude. Not like we don't tip good. But I'm not going back to this place. Bad bad bad service. Not worth the price or the waiting.
author: Kimberly R.

description: Ok - not sure what all the good reviews for this restaurant are doing here. On a slow night we ordered the all you can eat and were miserably disappointed. All I have to say is this place serves flavorless, low quality food. My point is totally supported by the paper-thin nigiri, awful beef teriyaki, poor tempura, tiny sushi rolls, and so on. Believe me, I'm not a mean guy but honestly cannot in good honesty and integrity recommend this place. The reason we came was we were staying in a hotel nearby and saw the great reviews on this site. All I can say is paper thin nigiri is not excusable and no way to enjoy a night out - and that alone is enough to substantiate this claim of "1 star".
author: Nick S.

description: My husband and I were in San Fran in March and we discovered the Sushi Hunter. Actually a Sonoma tour guide recommended the place. We were very happy we went there and enjoyed the extensive sushi menu. Food presentation was very good and the fish was fresh. Atmosphere leaves a bit to be desired. But we went there for the fresh sushi so we didn't mind.
author: Barb D.

description: WOW! Ive been in the city for a while now and I've always walked by Sushi Hunter. When I found out they were ALL YOU CAN EAT for a decent price of $23.95 I was in!!!!!!!!!!The sushi is so good. The atmosphere is super casual and the chefs are real nice! Super homey and comfortable. Hit spot for sure! Make sure you ask for the flying fish roe!
author: SLO C.

description: Dear God no. This place was not good at all. Like most restaurants that I think is bad I go back and give them a second sometimes third chance thinking "maybe they were just having an off day, everyone's entitled to an off day"  I tell myself but nope, everyday is an off day in my opinion for Sushi Hunter. If you want all you can eat sushi I suggest you try Sushi Hana on Van Ness. The staff is a lot nicer and way more attentive. Plus I think the staff at Sushi Hana might actually be Japanese, not Chinese like Sushi Hunter.
author: Christian H.

description: I came here back in july/august for a friends birthday and let me tell you!!!! The service here was horrible!!! I walked in and the server didnt take any notice of me for 20 minutes and the only reason she finally did, is because 5 of my friends yelled her over to the table to take my drink order.  She charged me for the "all you can eat" and didnt even ask me what I wanted all night. The only reason I got an order in is because I got up and walked over to her and told her what I wanted. After that, all of us had horrible diarrea all night! After that I decided about 3 weeks ago(stupidly) to take my sister and give them a second chance.... 2 hours later we were shitting  miserably! I later found out that their fish is not fresh and I want to make sure no one makes the mistake I did!
author: Kelley A.

description: All you can eat sushi, all you can drink sake! I didn't even need to go here to give it 5 stars!  It was a great time, and the sushi was actually good!  I didn't have high expectations and it rocked my world, and that was before I had consumed my 100th sake bomb. -on a side note I thought they were joking when they said I had to eat EVERY veggie and rice pellet off the plate or else we would be charged...they were NOT joking.
author: Liz O.

description: Should sushi be all you can eat? I figured out that with a friend you can get everything you want for the same amount you would both spend on the all you can eat.  Good sushi, average service, no ambiance.
author: C J.

description: Avoid this place like the plague. The nicest thing I can say about Sushi Hunter's is I didn't get sick. Tiny portions, horrible service. There should be negative stars for places like this
author: Dave D.

description: I've only ever been there for the all you can eat sushi. The decor sucks..but the service is friendly and the sushi is good. If you want a casual night out the 22.99 price for all you can eat is well worth it. If you're a sports fan they have two flat screens playing games constantly.
author: Nihad P.

description: the food here was good and it pretty much could feed anyone on a budget. Mind you, I had california roll and chicken teriyaki...their dinner specials are enough to feed two for under $11...
author: Michelle N.

description: Great sushi and happy hour! Very convenient for  those in north beach area who want a small and easy experience! Love it and great service
author: Morgan W.

description: My girlfriend, her friend and I went here for lunch today, and the sushi was awful.  First off, the rice, wasabi, and miso soup were very watered down and bland.  Next, the gyoza was greasy and tiny with a boring dipping sauce.  Lastly, the sushi was some of the poorest quality that I have ever had.  The flavors were boring, the unagi seemed like it was sitting out for a while, and the tuna looked and tasted like it was left out in the warm air for waaaay too long.  With so many decent or good places in town to get sushi, everyone should take a WIDE berth around this one.  The review below by Nick S. is right on the money.  DO NOT EAT HERE for any reason!!
author: Evan H.

description: When you have space in your stomach and want decent, but not great sushi, this is the place to go. Parking's a bitch, so drivers won't be happy, but a bus-er like me is fine.  There's a menu that you order off of and the make things for you as you order. It can take a while, so when you're halfway through your first order, you might want to make your next order so that the food keeps on coming.
author: ML N.

description: I have eaten my 2nd and FINAL meal at Sushi Hunter due to the TERRIBLE service and subpar sushi.  If the easter color scheme wasn't enough to keep me away the first time, the 1 hour wait for our bill AFTER we had finished our meal certaintly sealed the deal this time.  The fish is decent...certainly nothing above the sushi you'd find at Safeway.  While they do make an attempt to be creative with their rolls, we found the chicken in the "chicken teryaki roll" (yes, we were going out on a limb) to be supremely sketchy.  In fact, we haven't eaten chicken in 2 weeks because of it. Sorry Sushi Hunter, I wanted to like you, I really did.
author: margaret n.

description: If you love sushi, Sushi Hunter is the place to be in North Beach!  I have been there two times now, and I will for sure be going back.  On both occasions, I have indulged in the all-you-can-eat menu.  While you might at first think this 65-item viking-style menu at around $26 is pricey for one person, consider that the same amount of sushi any other place in the City would be at least double the cost.  All orders are made fresh.  The sushi---from sake salmon and maguro tuna to ebi shrimp and hamachi yellowtail---melts in your mouth, the tempura is just right, and the kuraage, that's Japanese style fried chicken, is soft and warm on the inside and perfectly crispy on the outside.  Fun and amiable staff along with top-notch, knowledgeable chefs will complete your Sushi Hunter experience.  Not feeling like all-you-can-eat? Not to worry!  They also feature a separate a la carte menu with the sushi staples and additional specialty items to boot.  Try the sushi, try the rolls, try it all...at Sushi Hunter!
author: Tim D.

description: Who woulda thunk it? - all you can eat GOOD sushi for $22.95 in SF! This place really delivers the goods. Fresh fish and great appetizers all for a low price. I went with one of the pickiest of picky sushi eaters (a Japanese citizen), and she approved. While Sushi Hunter will not be winning prizes for creativity, at the end of the day, the quality of the fish matters the most. Oh yeah, for an extra 10 bucks, you can get all the sake you can drink too...
author: Neil K.

description:
This places service is the worst I've ever had. All you can eat huh??? More like let's give them one roll so they aren't starving and then 30 minutes later let's give them another.

Stupidest "all you can eat", ever!!!!

I'd rather suggest a place like todai, simply put the service would be better and you might actually get food.

Id rather have an all I can eat at mcdonalds
author: Andrew P.

description: I've walked pass this place many times and always made a note to check out its reviews on Yelp and then go try it if it's good. well I finally did, and I was not disappointed. We did the 24 bucks all you can eat thing, it's fucking amazing! the fish was fresh and the selection was great! Service was excellent too. def gonna go back...
author: Andrew N.

description: It's not the BEST sushi place, but for All-You-Can-Eat, it's up there.  While I scanned the AYCE menu, I was a little disappointed that not everything was AYCE.  Naturally, all the standard nigiri, maki, teriyaki, tempura were on the AYCE menu...but no sashimi, no uni, no amaebi, no toro, no hamachi kama.  I know, they'd go broke if they did that.  However, despite that flaw, EVERYTHING we ordered was great...although the eel came out a little cool.  The tempura was light and crispy.  The chicken karaage was crisp, yet moist.  I did have to order a uni nigiri separate and it turned out to be very good.  I didn't think we'd drink that much sake, so we skipped the the all-you-can-drink special.  Five sake bombs was enough for me.  All in all, a very enjoyable AYCE experience.  Four stars would truly be given if they added a little more to their AYCE menu.
author: JeFF T.

description: Yum. All you can gorge yourself on sushi. Is the fish the best? No, but it's good enough for the price and everything is made to order. I thought the rolls were better than the nigiri, but still worth eating. My boyfriend filled up valuable space in his stomach with nonsense like egg rolls, but I stuck strictly to the fish and feel I got my money's worth. And, we also opted for the $11 all you can drink sake (just FYI, everyone at your table has to get the all you can eat/drink deal).  I left feeling full and tipsy -- just how I enjoy feeling after leaving a restaurant.
author: Rebecca H.

description: food was bland, rude waitress even though we tried to be nice and smile at her etc. still left a good tip. won't go back.
author: Jeannie C.

description: Definitely not the best sushi in town, but for the price, the eat-all-you-can-eat isn't bad!  Sushi and appetizers made once their ordered, so at least there's no being "iced" effect.  Service was outstanding.
author: Mark D.

description: Exactly what one should reasonably expect from an all-you-can eat place.  Not great, way better than bad.  Don't take anyone here you're trying to impress...you won't.  Unless, of course, you're trying to impress them with your sushi eating ability.  If 3.5 stars was an option, that's what I would've chosen.  Good but not great applies to all components of an experience here: wait staff, options, ambiance, etc.  Totally worth the time if you keep your expectations reasonable.
author: Thomas K.

description: Considering that it's all-you-can eat sushi and other Japanese dishes for $25.95, we were expecting pure crap. But, since we're piglets, we had to try just once. We were pleasantly surprised that the place wasn't crap - in fact, it was a lot better than it needed to be. The service was great - they were super friendly - and the food was solid. Don't get me wrong, it wasn't stellar...the rolls leave a lot to be desired...but I've had much worse sushi in the City (much, MUCH worse...I don't know how some of these restaurants survive) for a lot more $$$. If you want a good meal, I would skip the rolls and stick with the nigiri, curry tonkatsu, veggie croquette, beef teriyaki and fried tofu.
author: Adrienne C.

description: I came here to try their famous $22.95 all you can eat sushi menu.  It looked good on paper, so it's time to meet the real thing.  We sat down, ordered a bunch of stuff and truth be told, I was a little disappointed in the food.  The food was fresh and hot like all the yelpers said, but it's not that good.  The chicken entrees were just fried meat.  You can't really tell it's chicken.  They could be serving us rat meat for all I know.  The fish was fresh though.  The problem was that I hated their rule "We will charge for wasting food or rice balls".  It's like, suck MY balls.  Oh wait, I don't have any.  Seriously.  Anyway, I was a little miffed about that and wasn't too happy that my eating style is hampered in such a way.  When you are a dining customer, you just want to have a nice happy dinner.  I was not happy and I did not feel nice.
author: AhLin C.

description: I had the worse service of my life last nite. We did the all you can eat/sake thang, and the bill came out to be roughly 190. After we paid, the "new manager chick" paces by a few times and consistently ask us if we were going to finish the 10 pieces of what was left of our tuna roll. It's like are you serious? At this point I started to get really  annyoyed because she tried to charge us 10 extra dollars for a measly 10 piece of sushi after I just paid the broad over $200. Screw this place, bad sushi = death. Watch out for Cristy, the "New Manager" as she proclaims, she's shady as F!@#
author: Mikey N.

description: If you want quality sushi, do not go to Sushi Hunter.  The fish was not fresh.  The only positive part of our dinner experience was the service.  The people who work there are very friendly and helpful.  Great location, good service, bad food.  Save your money and go somewhere else.
author: Patty M.

description: $25 for weekend sushi all you can eat that was just mediocre.  All of the rolls were small mostly with rice to fill you up.  Selection was limited (for the all you can eat menu), but service was fast. I got in trouble because I was not eating the rice.  There's an extra charge apparently if you waste food.  If anyone has a better sushi buffet in SF to recommend, please send it to me since this place isn't worth the $25.
author: LT B.

description: I didn't get a chance to try the all you can eat menu because a friend of mine wasn't in the mood for it and we all had to order from the same menu.  However, the sashimi plate that i ordered turned out fresh and delicious!  The price is reasonable too!  I definitely will go back!
author: Vivian H.

description: I recently had a chance to check out Sushi Hunter's All-You-Can-Eat Menu and thought this was a great deal for under $25.  The dishes are made to order and the service was very good.  For the best value out of the buffet, one might load up on just the sushi but I enjoyed making as many bento boxes as possible.  My first bento box was salmon rolls, salmon nigiri, miso, and tempura.  My second bento box was salmon rolls, teriyaki chicken rolls, tamago, and udon.  The eating just continued from there.  The sushi was good but for me it was more about the variety of dishes one could order on Sushi Hunter's All-You-Can-Eat Menu.
author: Josh K.

description: Not bad, not bad.  For the price of two sushi rolls at any other sushi restaurant, you can eat yourself stupid at Sushi Hunter instead.  They have a good variety of hot food items (curry tonkatsu, veggie croquette, tempura), sushi rolls, and nigiri.  And the fish is not too shabby.  I mean, clearly it won't knock your socks off, but I've had much worse, and if you're going for quantity with decent quality, this is probably the place to go.  Much better than your Todais or Moonstars of the Bay Area.
author: Kalista W.

description: Love the 'hunter. Consistent quality, nigori sake, and friendly ambiance. Best sushi in North Beach.
author: gaby g.

description:
went last night for all you can eat sushi.  considering location, it's not bad.  they have a TV and are always playing whatever game is on, so this is a plus.

the food isn't bad.  it IS all you can eat, so i do expect the fish to be thinner, and the rice to be heftier, as they're trying to fill you up on what is cheaper.  the fish quality is run of the mill.  the agedashi tofu was pretty good, and the chicken karaage was quite good.  I would go back, but i wouldn't go out of my way to get out here.  i just happen to live down the street, so i will definitely be back when i'm in the all-you-can-eat sushi mood.  The rolls i thought were typical, and so was the nigiri.  There wasn't anything we ate that i thought "jesus get me out of here"

overall, its $23 or so for all you can eat (Fri and Sat nights are more i believe).  reading from the other reviews, Fri or Sat are not the nights to go, as it's super crowded.  this was definitely not my case (Tues night), the service was friendly and fast.  considering other options in SF, this isn't a bad deal.  and believe me, we ate a lot - plates and plates and plates.
author: Jason J.

description: I ate here early last week and I was horrified. Something about the food tasted funny and it took me awhile to track down the source. The sushi tasted almost chemical. My friends and I think we pinpointed the taste in the rice. It was certainly not fresh and had likely been kept in plastic tupperware for an extended period of time. The plastic was what lead to the severe "chemical" quality of the food. I would NEVER go back!
author: Ashley B.

description: Sushi was ok here.  Not good but decent.  Service however was terrible.  Staff was too busy on the phone to tend to us.  Go to Sushi on North Beach a block away for better food and service.
author: Buddy R.

description: Sushi hunter was pretty good. There were 5 of us in our party and we had the all-you-can-eat. When we first got there, the service was really good although a roll didn't get sent to us, but no big deal. As the restaurant got a little busier, we noticed that the service became average (they would forget to bring us stuff and we would have to remind them). The food itself was pretty good. The gyoza was delicious. The Udon was the perfect size. It was nice that they had appetizers, entrees, and sushi for the all you can eat rather than just sushi. Nice atmosphere and very friendly staff. Would definitely eat there again. :)
author: Shar L.

description: Just went for a bachelorette party.  All you can drink sake for an extra $2.  All you can eat sushi and hot japanese food.  The Sushi was ok.  The hot japanese food was great.  I loved the chicken katsu.  They used white meat for thier chicken dishes.  All of the food was made fresh as you ordered.  We had a pretty large group, the hot food came at a pretty decent rate, but the sushi takes longer.  The variety was decent and everything on the whole was good.
author: Julie Y.

description: I love this place. The service has been great, the food was delicous and came quickly. It will definitely be a regular spot for me.
author: Jan S.

description: This place is awesome to go to if you're REALLY hungry.  They have an all you can eat menu; so come hungry.  However, know that if someone in your party orders the all you can eat, everyone at your table must do the same.  I find this irritating.  I like the bento box there.
author: Sarah F.

description: We went for "all-you-can-eat" sushi, and were very satisfied. Although, I have to say it was little slow. I saw at least 2 sushi chefs, and the restaurant wasn't packed. It took about 15-20 min to get our order and I was just little bit disappointed. Convenient location!
author: Jelly G.

description: It's only alright.  Don't get the all you can eat because its on a special limited menu and the cuts are smaller than the normal nigiri they offer.  If you live in NB and have a sushi craving and a broken leg then go here, otherwise check out another place.
author: Nagoo N.

description:
Note to self: When a place offers an all you can eat menu, you can expect sub-par fish. Sushi Hunter is no exception. My friends took me here swearing it was the greatest thing, and after two pieces of sushi I begged to differ. The maguro was previously frozen, the sake was mushy and the saba was too oily.

All in all I give it two stars. Meh.
author: Charlie K.

description: The all you can eat deal is pretty good. $23.95 for all the sushi, appetizers and entrees you can eat.  Also $10 all you can drink sake.  The food was would you would expect for this type of restaurant, decent, not great.  Service was extremely slow though, although the waitress was nice enough to apologize.  It was also pretty loud, and I had to shout to make myself heard.  I recommend the edamame and beef terriyaki.
author: Dennis S.

description: All you can eat sushi?  Yes please!  Very fresh and a good deal (20 bucks for all I can eat when normally specialty rolls are about $10 is a great deal in my mind).  You can also get all you can drink sake for $11 if you are feeling crazy.  Would recommend to a friend, or a stranger.
author: Janelle S.

description: Decent, fresh sushi. All the typical rolls and fishes that one would normally find.  Nothing special, though.  Miso soup was particularly tasty, but could have used more tofu.  On the plus side, this joint is wallet friendly...you should have no problem getting out of here for under $30.
author: Mel B.

description: I will say that for the price, the quality was way better then I expected. The service is really inviting too. They have a small kitchen staff so the wait for your food is obviously longer the busier the place is. I would recomend like a Tuesday evening or Saturday afternoon as the right time to enjoy this places best qualities.
author: Victor B.

description: Still the best in the bay area for the px pt.  Fresh fish, all u can eat across full Japanese menu, great svc, good ambience.
author: Tim A.

description: Something about this place just didn't seem right to me.... I can't really put my finger on it.... Maybe it was the funky smell that was permeating from my menu while I was trying to decide on some rolls.... or the weird air freshener smell that was so strangely strong that it seemed as if they were trying to hide something....And just for the sake of sounding totally crazy... I felt as if everything in there had been tainted with fish (which I am not a fan of)... While the restaurant appeared very clean for some strange reason it didn't feel that way.... Maybe I'm crazy.... Well yes I am, but besides all of that it just was off.... The name Sushi Hunter doesn't help either... it just conjures up crazy mental images in my head for some reason..... On the plus side the staff was uber friendly, they have soy paper for their rolls which is a huge plus in my book, and they had really yummy iced tea.... Nothing was really wrong, but it just wasn't really right.... That makes sense.... Right?
author: Jennifer B.

description: Sushi is middle of the road. Nothing amazing that I would recommend to friends, but good location, friendly waitstaff, and good amount of reasonably priced sushi options, including veggie. Would probably go back b/c for myself and veggie BF, bill was only $45, including tip.
author: Kiren K.

description: Sushi hunter gets four stars for the all you can eat menu combined with the fact that it's retardedly close to my house.  The trick here I've found is that you should factor in approximately two hours to eat, since they are a bit inconsistent with prep times.
author: Tony C.

description: Fresh made to order all you can eat sushi. The selection covers the basics plus a few special rolls. I get my monies worth every time.
author: TheYster A.

description: I've gone to Sushi Hunter only once, so I am writing this base on that experience.   We were a group of 7 people, and went to have all you can eat sushi.  The server was nice and service was quick.  Sushi was a OK... but some raw fish came out warm, which was very strange to me. You can tell that the quality of fish wasn't that great, but for the price and  all you can eat, I think that's OK.
author: Chelsea O.

description: The service was great. My waiter gave me extra tamago (egg sushi) for free! But when I ate it, it was TERRIBLE. And that wasn't the worst, I also ordered California Rolls it was EVEN WORST THEN THE TAMAGO! Now I know not to go to eat there again.
author: Jacob A.

description:
Knowing that this place was in northbeach, i was hesitant to try it, but we were looking for a japanese restaurant where they served decent sushi and sake with a group of friends. First of all, we did not order the all you can eat menu, though we ended up dropping approximately 35 dollars each and was not satisfied with the amount of food ordered. 

The rolls priced between 10 - 12 dollars each were considered small and unfilling in comparison to other restaurants where they serve up bigger rolls with more fish in each bite. We tried the oyaku don, which was mediocre. There were chunks of chicken in some egg mixture atop rice, but there is nothing to rave about in that dish. We ordered a couple bottles of sake and sapporo and had a good time, but the food was disappointing. It tasted okay for some of my friends since they were drunk at that point. but it really wasn't worth the money.

The reason for the 1 star rating is largely due to the fact that the service was terrible! They wouldn't seat us until our whole party was there even though we had made reservations. Knowing the parking difficulties in north beach, i would assume they could be a little more lenient and understanding when we told them our friends were parking. 
Also, they sat our 5 person party at a 4 person table even though there was a bigger table available and when a 6th person came to join us, they refused to add a chair to our table. So we just grabbed the chair from the nearby empty table and accommodated ourselves. This really puzzles me: How can a restaurant refuse a customer that is joining a party? 
After they took 10 minutes to give us menus, they took another 45 minutes to serve our food after we ordered! Good thing we were all drinking alcohol and some of us were too drunk to notice the long wait. After eating quickly and asking for the bill, they took another 15 minutes to bring us the bill and the whole dinner took more than 2 hours because of the horrible service. 
I'm sorry sushi hunter, but even though you're one of the few japanese restaurants in North Beach, I would rather pay the extra money that was spent on the tiny amount of over priced sushi on a taxi ride down to the marina for some authentic japanese fare and welcoming service.
author: Florence T.

description: decent all-you-can-eat sushi in north beach for $25. lack of an all-you-can-imbibe option unfortunate.
author: Clover Dan ..

description:
I had been to Sushi Hunter previous, but it had been a few years since I last ate there, so my memory was a bit fuzzy. While I don't remember it being anywhere near the best food in town, I remember it being reasonably good. Well, either my memory failed me horribly or the place has gone downhill, in either case, I will never return. Although the place was clean and the atmosphere was reasonably good, the waitress seemed bothered by any questions, including a simple one, like, "is this appetizer enough for two people to split?" She rolled her eyes and said, "it's $6, it's small, I don't know if it's enough for two." Ok fine, I'm not expecting an entree-sized portion for $6, but is there not a more polite way of answering the question? Anyway, the food was bland and lukewarm, even though it was not busy at the time. As for the sushi, the fish was suspiciously mushy and the tuna appeared to have been put through a food processor before it was put on the roll. 

In a city with more great restaurants than any one person can ever enjoy, I see no reason to make this part of your to-do list.
author: rob h.

description:
my guy and i walked in here ready to eat...and it smelled like a mildewy, really rank mop. i'm not one to be too nit-picky...and even i had to bail.

ewww. not appetizing. the smell was enough to make us leave.

...as I'm sure many others did. it was saturday night and NO ONE was in there.
author: Lady L.

description: Usually..sushi hunter isn't a disappointment. It's not that great, but for its price it's decent. Last night though was my first BAD experience there: ordered 4 rolls for takeout, got home started eating it...and the fish was definitlely NOT FRESH (had a disgusting fishy taste to it, had to throw it out). This might be the first time it's happened to me there...but it definitely turned me off from going there any time soon. Just keep in mind that you get what you pay for..and what you're paying for is mediocre sushi quality.
author: l c.

description: We went there for all-you can eat sushi. Moderate to good sushi. Good dishes such as tempura and fried pork.
author: Amy C.
